PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

support both the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989 to provide a method of altering the Constitution on the initiative of electors, and the Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 to provide for the holding of referenda on bills proposed by members of the public;
and your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion Funding Abolition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1988/89 the Federal Government paid $6.9 million from taxpayers' funds for 64,788 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by supporting the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Romania, whose Human Rights Record had been worse than that of South Africa's even before she embarked on a diabolic village destruction program, deservedly attracts worldwide condemnation. The systematic cultural genocide of the peoples affected must be prevented.
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. the Australian Parliament establish whether or not Romania has satisfied fully her obligations under the Treaty of Trianon (1920) and the Peace Treaty of Paris (1947),
2. if found that Romania violates these agreements, the signatures representing Australia jointly or singularly be withdrawn from the thus invalidated documents,
3. Australia table her findings at the appropriate forums of the United Nations.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Environmental Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled.
The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully declare:

That there is an urgent need for the Commonwealth of Australia to have an Environmental Bill of Rights based upon the recommendations in the report of the United Nations 1987, World Commission on Environment and Development.
We pray that Parliament pass an ``Australian Environmental Bill of Rights,'' therefore making Australia a leading light in the environmental protection.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Military Aid to El Salvador
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia humbly pray that:
1. The Parliament heeds our profound concern regarding the Penal Code Reforms of the ARENA Government in E1 Salvador.

2. We request that as these reforms breach the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and in consideration of the escalation of human rights violations by E1 Salvadoran Armed forces, the Australian Government convey to the United States that all forms of military aid to the Salvadoran Government should be suspended.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned, having great concern that Canberra is now the ``Porn Capital'' of Australia and because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to introduce immediate legislation in support of existing State Legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over the importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes particularly in the A.C.T., with the open sale and/or hire of only G, PG, and M-rated video cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale or hire of R rated video-cassettes, so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated or ``N.V.E.'' rated video-cassettes, which would allow the legal sale and hire of hard-core pornographic videos for viewing in the homes of our nation, which would endanger our children; and
2. To give whole-hearted support to Senator Walters's Private Member's Bill to implement the recommendations of the Select Committee on Videos; and

3. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc., or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects, And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Harradine (from 2,201 citizens) and Walters (from 310 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most womens' groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R' rated video pornography in Australia.
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported.
that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the A.C.T. Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material.
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 15 citizens) and Harradine (from 33 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crichton-Browne (from 1,222 citizens) and Jones (from 160 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and the members of the Senate. We the undersigned oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe there should not be two levels of Medicare rebates for general practice. We also believe there should be upgraded undergraduate training and postgraduate training for general practitioners to obtain appropriate skills. Current and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate, and there should be appropriate Medicare rebates for doctors who provide out of hours consultations.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support general practitioners to achieve the above.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Botanic Gardens, Education Unit: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's decision to abolish the Education Unit of the National Botanic Gardens is a betrayal of the Federal Government's professed commitment to conservation, protection and management of Australia's unique flora.

The Education Unit fulfilled an important role in increasing the knowledge, appreciation and enjoyment of Australia's plant heritage of visitors to the National Botanic Gardens, including many school children.

Therefore your petitioners request that the Senate require the Government to recognise the importance of the work carried out by the Education Unit and reserve its decision to withdraw funding for the Unit.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the Senate of their concern regarding proposed changes to the laws governing credit reporting, as suggested in the Bill `The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989'.
The proposed reforms will:
Restrict the legitimate use of credit checking by businesses which sell/supply goods and or services to their customers on credit terms.

The proposals/reforms will prevent businesses from determining the solvency of their customers and will increase the financial risk of credit providers, leading to an increase in company liquidations and individual bankruptcies.

Additional costs to business from bad debts due to the lack of adequate credit checking information will result in increased prices/charges and will result in credit providers refusing credit facilities.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will call on the Government to refer these proposals restricting credit checking to a Senate select committee for further consideration before proceeding with the matter.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I give notice that, 12 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: No. 1-That the Health Insurance (Vocational Registration of GP's Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 270 and made under the Health Insurance Act 1973, be disallowed.
No. 2-That the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 267 and made under the Migration Act 1958, be disallowed.
No. 3-That the Quarantine (Animals) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 272 and made under the Quarantine Act 1908, be disallowed.

No. 4-That the Interpretation Ordinance 1989, as contained in Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands Ordinance No. 3 of 1989 and made under the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933, be disallowed.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the Committee's concerns.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Health Insurance (Vocational Registration of GP's) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 270 and made under the Health Insurance Act 1973

These Regulations provide for entry on, and removal from, the Vocational Register of Practitioners. Only general practitioners on the Register are entitled to use certain new item numbers in the Medical Benefits Schedule. The Committee was concerned at the lack of external, independent review of the merits of discretions which may be exercised pursuant to the Regulations.

Regulation 14 provides that the Minister may terminate the appointment of a member of an Eligibility Committee or an Appeal Committee, which are committees established for the purposes of the Regulations, ``for misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity''. Each of these grounds contains an element of subjective judgment and there appears to be no avenue for independent review of this decision. Membership of such Committees does not have financial advantages but, as all members are themselves medical practitioners, removal on any of these grounds would be a very serious matter.

In addition, all the review process in relation to entry on, or removal from, the Register appears to be internal. There seems to be no external avenue of review of the merits of decisions either for refusing to admit a practitioner to the Register or for removing a practitioner from the Register.

Practitioners who are on the Register have substantial reputation and professional prestige. Removal from the Register, on the other hand, would involve personal stigma. The Committee believes that in such cases an external right of review, possibly after internal procedures, should be provided. The Committee has often expressed its preference for such review to be conducted by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is an external, independent, expert body able to underwrite the fairness and integrity of in-house procedures. The Committee will accept that an internal appeal mechanism is more appropriate than external merits review only in exceptional circumstances.
Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 267 and made under the Migration Act 1958

These Regulations provide for the payment of a fee for a temporary entry permit. Refugees, persons under a special humanitarian program and the spouse or child of an applicant are expressly exempt from payment of the fee. The Committee has no concerns with these objective classes of exemption.

The Regulations also exempt, however, ``a class of persons in respect of whom the Minister has determined in writing that no fee is to be payable''. This is an open-ended discretion with no criteria to limit and guide its exercise and apparently no provision that classes of persons determined by the Minister should be subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. The power to exempt a ``class'' from an obligation, or to grant some other privilege, or to impose a burden on a ``class'', is a typically legislation function and, as such, should be subject to disallowance. If such a power is in respect of individuals rather than a class, then a right of external review of the merits of an adverse decision affecting an individual, would be appropriate.

The Committee was also concerned that the power may be subject to delegation. If this was the case the Committee would be particularly concerned. While a Minister is subject to personal questioning of his or her actions in Parliament, a delegate is not subject to such rigorous scrutiny.
Quarantine (Animals) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 272 and made under the Quarantine Act 1908

Apart from correcting a small grammatical error, the sole purpose of these Regulations is to remove mandatory quarantine Forms from the Regulations themselves and thus not only from the possibility of Parliamentary disallowance but even from tabling for the information of Parliament. In addition, the Forms in future will not be approved even by the Minister, but by a public official, the Director of Quarantine. Failure to use the forms is punishable by a fine of $1,000. The Explanatory Statement only advises that ``There is now a need to update these forms to bring them into line with current forms design. To effect this and to facilitate any future changes which may become necessary, amendment of the Quarantine (Animals) Regulations is desirable to enable a form to be revised without amendment of the Regulations''.

The Committee has requested a full explanation from the Minister as to why the amendments cannot be made by Regulation and why it is ``desirable'' to exclude Parliament from a full supervisory role in respect of the Forms in favour of instruments made by a public official.
Interpretation Ordinance 1989, as contained in Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands Ordinance No. 3 of 1989 and made under the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933

The concerns of the Committee relate to the legislative policy which determined the form of this Ordinance. The Committee is not concerned with the policy merits of instruments it examines, restricting its scrutiny to matters of personal liberty or Parliamentary propriety. Where the legislative policy behind a particular instrument affects its terms of reference, however, then the Committee will raise its concerns with the Minister in the same way as with any other instrument.

In this case the legislative policy is the form of drafting of the Ordinance which makes it extremely difficult to ascertain the state of the law. The drafting policy of the Ordinance is to incorporate substantial provisions of other legislation from four separate Commonwealth, State and Territory jurisdictions rather than draft a separate ``stand alone'' instrument. This is generally effected by mere reference to section numbers of particular instruments. Sometimes these provisions are amended without any discrete reference to the substance of the Acts which are so affected. In addition, most of the incorporated material applies as amended from time to time. The result is a confusing instrument which requires substantial legal research to ascertain the state of the law. The Committee is also concerned at four definitions in the Ordinance which appear to be circular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, to incorporate into that Act an excise tariff proposal tabled in this Parliament during the last sittings, and to effect a minor technical amendment to take account of the fact that the Australian Capital Territory has attained self-government.
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The excise duty for naturally occurring LPG is adjusted six-monthly on 1 April and 1 October each year in accordance with the Government's LPG excise policy announced in April 1980. The excise rate is calculated as 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 a tonne. The realised price is based on the weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sales of LPG during the immediately preceding six months.

Under the petroleum excise arrangements introduced from 1 July 1987, LPG produced from onshore fields is exempt from excise, so the excise now only applies to offshore fields-that is Bass Strait. No excise is payable on refinery-produced LPG.

Clause 4 of the Bill will amend the excise rate with effect from 1 April 1989, from $6.25 a kilolitre to a rate of free. The decrease reflects the fact that the excise threshold of $147 a tonne has not been reached on average over the immediately preceding six months.
Minor Technical Amendment

The opportunity has also been taken to effect a minor technical amendment to Item 10 (a) of the schedule to the Act. This amendment concerns the treatment under the act of government business enterprises established by the Australian Capital Territory Government, now that the Territory has attained self-government, and is explained in more detail in the explanatory memorandum.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The Government will not raise any revenue from excise on naturally occurring LPG for the six months from 1 April 1989. With a zero excise rate to apply from 1 April total LPG excise receipts for the 1988-89 financial year are estimated at $11m compared with receipts of $19.8m in 1987-88. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
