Powers of arrest
``60b. Section 13 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subparagraph 2 (a) (ii) and substituting the following subparagraph:
`(ii) the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963, the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972, the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1976 or the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973;'.''.
(3) Page 1, title, after ``Police'' add ``and the Australian Protective Service Act 1987''.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the amendments made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the amendment, which concerns the Australian Protective Service. However, we add the proviso that we will watch closely the administration of this change. I remind the Committee of our law and justice policy, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: In consultation and cooperation with the States, the responsibility for and level of security at major ports and airports will be re-examined so that the most effective service is provided and that the best possible use is made of the available physical and financial resources.

That statement of policy stands. Therefore, in supporting the changes concerning the operation of Australian Protective Service in relation to airports, we do so with the proviso that we will watch closely the administration of the Government's program in this regard and make such changes upon coming to government as we think are in the best interests of protection at airports.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 28 November.
GROUP D
Department of Veterans' Affairs
Proposed expenditure, $1,241,762,000

TALK.START.PARA: —Late last night three sets of anomalies were noted, and questions were posed to the Minister at the table and, through her, to the advisers. Perhaps it might be appropriate to the remainder of our discussion on this portion of the Appropriations if we could hear what their responses were to those three issues raised by Senator Reid and me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night a letter to Senator Macklin was tabled. It identified the need to clarify what appeared to be a misunderstanding in relation to totally and permanently incapacitated veterans. Where a veteran dies in the circumstances described in the letter to Senator Macklin, his wife would be entitled to a lump sum equal to seven times the combined service or age pension which the couple was receiving at the time of his death, less any ongoing age or service pension paid to the widow. As at 1 January 1990, this would be up to $1,247.40.

SPEECH.PARA: The second entitlement is a lump sum equal to six times 100 per cent of the general rate of disability pension as at the date of royal assent of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, which would be $1,126.20, the war widows pension, currently $291.20 per fortnight, and a funeral benefit of $550. In relation to the question Senator McLean asked last night, I think I responded on advice from the officer that there was a misunderstanding, either in relation to the interpretation in the letter, or in relation to the article the honourable senator quoted from Age Pension News. But that is the advice the officers have come to me with this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek Senator Reynolds's assurance that the interpretation that war widows would be disadvantaged in comparison to age pensioners is a misunderstanding, an incorrect interpretation.
—Yes.

—I thank the Minister for that assurance. My understanding is that, through an editorial process in Age Pension News issue No. 2, that anomaly arose because something was deleted, or what was previously to be a comprehensive explanation was reduced to one which created this misunderstanding. I wonder whether it would be a reasonable suggestion, through the Minister to the advisers, that something could be done through that particular publication to correct that misunderstanding because, as I say, it has come from several sources.

—Age Pension News is a Department of Social Security publication. We have asked that there be further clarification in the next edition of Age Pension News because it seems that it has quite legitimately created misunderstanding. There needs to be an absolute clarification in the next edition. That will happen.

—Another area of concern, particularly among Vietnam veterans, is the ongoing vexed question of agent orange and exposure to chemicals in Vietnam. I know that the Minister and advisers are well aware of the fact that there has been a considerable shift in the climate in North America according to North American studies. North American legal findings in the last year or so have given rise to a series of judgments which have been substantially in favour of veterans and which have substantially shifted the frequency of compensation in favour of veterans. In view of the fact that what happens in North America has in the past been the yardstick upon which the Department and governments have taken positions here, can the Minister give me some guidance as to whether there is acknowledgment in the appropriations that these shifts are occurring? Could the Minister also advise me as to what level of appropriation has specifically been directed to the Dapsone study and in what timeframes it is anticipated by the Department that the Dapsone study will come to conclusion and, therefore, be in place as a policy base?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget provides $325,000 for the study. It is to start before Christmas and it will take approximately three months. I am well aware of Senator McLean's interest in and concern about this area because he has raised a number of questions about it in the chamber before. The Dapsone study was recommended by the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. In fulfilment of the Minister's undertaking on the Royal Commission recommendation, the Department of Veterans' Affairs asked the National Health and Medical Research Council for advice on the study. The matter was referred to the Australian Institute of Health, which has agreed to investigate whether it would be able to carry out the study.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Donovan has been selected to carry out the investigation. This has been based on a preliminary investigation of the study's feasibility and likely costs. An appropriation was made for the conduct of the study during this current financial year, as I have indicated. A detailed protocol for the study is presently being developed. The Minister has stated that ex-service organisations will be given the opportunity to comment on the protocol before its finalisation. As with previous epidemiological studies relating to Vietnam veterans, the Minister will be appointing a scientific advisory committee of distinguished scientists to provide him with independent advice to guarantee the objectivity and scientific validity of the study. The Minister has asked for nominations from the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Australian Epidemiology Association, the Australian Public Health Association and the Australian Statistical Society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the terms of reference of the advisory committee to which the Minister has just referred be specific to the Dapsone study or will they be monitoring, on behalf of the Minister, developments in, say, North America, in the United States in particular, in relation to exposure of veterans to chemicals? A growing interest there concerns the conclusions regarding the effects of 2,4-D, which has been a very widely used chemical in Australia, in civil and commercial use as well. I am wondering whether the advisory committee that the Minister has just referred to has that ongoing monitoring advisory role beyond the Dapsone study.
—I am advised that, while obviously the Department is monitoring the developments in North America, there is a separate issue here and the Dapsone study is quite separate.
—Therefore, the Committee is specific to the Dapsone study?
—It is specific, yes.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 1 November.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)-by leave-agreed to:
That, in the Committee of the Whole-
(a) leave be given to Senators to move motions expressing opinions or making recommendations based on the Report of Estimates Committee A;
(b) where more than one motion is proposed, the motions may be debated together, but in all cases a motion or motions shall be disposed of before the Question is put on the Vote before the Chair; and
(c) any Resolutions be reported when the Chairman reports to the President at the conclusion of proceedings in Committee of the Whole.
Department of the Senate
Proposed expenditure, $15,993,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Estimates Committee A in dealing with the parliamentary departments generally, and in particular the Department of the Senate, found several matters that were of some considerable concern. Concern was expressed that the method of setting the appropriations for the Senate itself could lead to the Senate's business being curtailed by simply not sufficient money being allocated for the running of the Senate. Indeed, the Clerk, in answer to a specific question from me, said that the time could be reached in the future when the appropriation that was fixed for the Senate might be insufficient to allow proper staffing for committees which had been established by the Senate, and therefore the Senate could be unable to carry out its work properly if appropriations were not sufficient. This is of a good deal of concern to members of the Committee, and to some members in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the wording in the report, I think it is quite significant to say that Opposition senators did not feel it necessary on this occasion to prepare a reservation as has been necessary after previous Estimates Committee hearings, because there was a commitment made by both Government senators and Opposition senators as to the serious nature of the matters that are raised through the report. So the fact that both Government and Opposition senators are in agreement on these matters I think is most important. I ask the Minister whether he shares the concern of the Committee that there is a risk-that in relation to the Executive arm of government appropriating funds for the Senate, the time could come when we are curtailed in our funding because of the inappropriateness of those appropriations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there is absolutely no substance to what Senator Bishop suggests may be a rationale behind government. Whether that is the result of actions is a separate matter. There is no desire by the Executive wing of government to curtail the activities of this chamber or the Department of the Senate or in any way to restrict its operations. I can only say that on the basis of my own experience in the Budget process, which is not as extensive as that of some. The fact is that no-one likes stringent fiscal times. The amount of gross domestic product devoted to government expenditure, or expenditure by this Parliament in the ultimate, has been reducing, and everyone and every department has had to share some of those cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: If anything, I think it could be argued that the Senate in general has fared better than the House of Representatives in terms of funding. That is certainly an argument I have heard put with some bitterness from the other place, that in fact funding here in the Senate has held up better than it has in the House of Representatives. It raises the age-old question of the Executive versus the Parliament relationship. It raises the question of whether Parliament should be able to allocate its own money-which I have never agreed with and could never agree with-and have just a carte blanche arrangement. Also, probably the whole argument has been somewhat exacerbated by the move to this place, where the running costs are inevitably higher in an architectural place such as this, with costs being higher than original estimates, et cetera.

Getting back to the central point, it is not the intention of the Executive, of the Government, to squeeze the Senate. If the Senate has to make its contribution to economic restraint, it should; it should not be exempt. It would be very strange if the Senate allocation was increasing in real terms when everyone else's was reducing in real terms. That would be a very strange thing. Again, I warn Senator Bishop, in a friendly way, that this sort of incestuous concentration on our own role sometimes does distort public policy and too often diverts our attention from what the real issues are. Senator Bishop has asked me whether that is the intention. No, it is not. She then asked me to make a judgment about whether it could ever happen. Although anything could happen, I do not think it will be the case that the Senate Department would be so constricted.

I also have to say that this place is not run efficiently. This Parliament is not run efficiently. It was only a year ago that we had five departments-five little departments. We have 17 departments running the whole of Australia, and this place has to have five departments to run it, with five departmental heads, all jealous of each other, with no-one wanting to concede an inch. It reminds me a little of the amalgamation of councils in Victoria; the only ones ever in favour of it are those that would absorb others. That is the problem we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we have altruism here.

—Look, the honourable senator is a Senate chauvinist. It is not something I criticise him for because I see such passion when he enters these debates. He shows more passion when he talks about this chamber than when he talks about the gold tax.
—Would you care for a situation like Queensland? Is that what you are suggesting?
—No, I am not suggesting we get to a situation like Queensland, where the honourable senator's political allies indulge in the grossest form of corruption ever seen in the history of this country.
—You don't want to talk about Western Australia.

—I am not suggesting that at all. Let me get back to the point. There is a responsibility-and it does not devolve just to this chamber, by the way; it would be very unfair to say that-to have this overall building and Parliament run with some efficiency. I think there have been enormous attempts by the Presiding Officers and their advisers to get more efficiency into the system. Of course they will make mistakes from time to time, and those mistakes will probably be criticised by Estimates Committee A.

SPEECH.PARA: But I have to pay tribute to President Sibraa, Speaker Child and Speaker Child's successor for attempting to get this whole place to run more efficiently. It must not just be a big building on the hill at which we throw a bucket of money every now and again. On the other hand, it also has to have enough money to operate efficiently. Do not tell me that this place operates efficiently when, on the sixth day of debate on the Estimates in the Committee of the Whole, we are going through a perverse and perverted process, and when 90 per cent of the questions that should have been asked during the sittings of the Estimates committees are being asked in the Committee of the Whole. It has become a joke. It was a crisis when it was thought that the Supply Bills would not be passed by 11 November. We are now approaching 30 November and there is no certainty that we will get the Estimates through by tomorrow night.

I have even heard it said by some honourable senators opposite that, because we are not jumping up and down, we are not serious. That does not happen to be my style-it was the style of Senator Gareth Evans. Seriously, if this chamber and the other chamber want more money, a bit of productivity would not hurt now and then. We are approaching 30 November and we have hardly passed a Bill. The only reason we have passed a few Bills-and I have to thank honourable senators for that-is that we are coughing them through on a Thursday at lunchtime.

Getting back to the point, I think that there is a more efficient way of running this place and that it could be run on the basis of one or two departments, with all the economies that that would bring. The real problem is that no-one wants to give up his turf. The Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Joint House Department and all the rest of them were very sensitive when these issues came up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which department would the Library go into if you had two departments?
—I do not keep a dog and bark myself; I will leave that to others to work out.
—You just have the rough details, have you?
—Order! I suggest to Senator Crichton-Browne that he ask those questions through the Chair.

—I would rather deal with interjections, but I certainly acknowledge the wisdom of your remarks, Mr Temporary Chairman. Senator Crichton-Browne is trying to help me by asking which department the Library would go into. I have been to only one or two Appropriations and Staffing Committee meetings.
—We miss you, too.

—Well, I am not an official member. In terms of baseball, I am a designated hitter. I will come back to Senator Bishop's general point about whether there is enough money. If the Clerk is asked whether there is enough money, of course he will say that there is not. If my departmental head is brought in, grilled, and asked, `Do you think you have enough money?', of course he will say, `No', because he will want more. And why would he not want more-there are an infinite number of things that can be done?

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of progress has been made. The parliamentary education service, the modernisation of computer equipment-I admit, with the occasional blip-and other things that have been done have contributed a lot to the running of this chamber and the Parliament as a whole. I put that on the record, as I would hate to be thought to be answering in a negative way. But, I still say that surely some sort of parliamentary reorganisation could be done to make this place more efficient than it is and to meet some of its deficiencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the points that the Minister has just raised. I agree with him that this whole question raises the problem of the theory of the separation of powers, which breaks down under our parliamentary system because parliament represents the people and the executive government represents what, in the olden days, used to be the king. The parliament was put in place to restrict the powers of the king. Unfortunately, under the Westminster system the parliament, in effect, was corrupted when the role of the king was taken over by certain members of parliament who became the executive officers. So the people, when they vote for the Parliament, think they are voting to put into Canberra or Westminster, or wherever, their representatives but in fact end up, in the case of the House of Representatives, electing an electoral college that then chooses the government of the day. That government of the day purports to be the representative of the people but in fact is standing in place of the king or a dictator.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that that raises problems. I am not suggesting that there ought not to be more efficiencies in this Parliament; clearly there should be. But, I make the following points to the Minister: first, the creation of megadepartments is not necessarily the way to go to achieve efficiency. Sometimes, it is more efficient to have small departments with a degree of actual responsibility, rather than trying to create some megadepartment. Salary structure must be considered. The salary structures of those administering small departments should not be the same as those who administer some megadepartments. That is one way of looking at the matter.
The Minister seems to confuse the question of the efficiency of administering a department with the ability to get Bills through this place. Of course, there is no relationship between--

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't suggest there was.

—With respect, that is what the Minister was saying. He was talking about the efficiency of departments. He then said that we are approaching 30 November and we have not got the Supply Bills through. There is no relationship whatsoever between those two matters.
—I was talking about the productivity of honourable senators opposite.

—All I can say is that there is no relationship between the two matters. If the Minister reads page 3 of the report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing he would see what has gone wrong. The Senate set up that Committee to resolve these matters. The Committee met and came up with a sum of money that it believed was necessary. It may have been an ambit claim; it may have been too much. The problem is with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). Senator Ray might say that in the Budget processes the Government is trying to be fair to the Parliament. But the truth is that the Minister for Finance ignored the recommendations of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. He treated them with the usual contempt with which he treats everything to do with this Parliament. Senator Walsh is interested only in executive government. He is not interested in the Parliament in any way.
—That is not true; he is interested in the management of taxpayers' money.

—All right; he is interested in the expenditure of taxpayers' money. But he has no respect for or interest in the processes of this Parliament, which he has repeatedly ignored. The Government has made Senator Walsh responsible for these matters, and he is frankly not doing the job that he ought to be doing.

SPEECH.PARA: On the day before these matters were to be considered, over six weeks after this Committee had reported and far too late for there to be any consultation, Senator Walsh wrote a letter to the President saying, `We are going to cut $1.8m off your expenditure'. It was not `Please, Mr President, come and talk to me. We think we ought to cut $1.8m off your expenditure', but simply a blank statement saying that the Government intended to reduce the expenditure by $1.8m. I will not enter into an argument as to the merits of the reduction of $1.8m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will.

—Senator Crichton-Browne will no doubt do that in due course, but I am not entering into that argument at this stage. I am saying to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that this is no way for the Executive government and the Parliament's Committee to resolve the problem of the conflict which occurs under the Westminster system and to which the Minister has already referred.

SPEECH.PARA: What is needed is consultation. Ultimately, what had to happen was that Senator Button, representing the Government, and Senator Chaney, representing the Opposition, had to get together and ask the Minister for Finance whether he would please meet with them and with the President in order to resolve these difficulties. At one stage it looked as though Senator Walsh was going to ignore Senator Button, his Leader, and Senator Chaney and not meet with them. Finally, as a last desperate gamble, he did meet with them and they were able to confer and come to a resolution of the problems. If Senator Walsh had done that six weeks earlier there would not have been the conflict which is reported in the Committee's report.

I say to the Minister that the Government is absolutely without a defence in this matter. It is the Government's President who was trying to negotiate with Senator Walsh. I have no doubt that he telephoned the office of Senator Walsh and probably tried to speak to him at various places, but Senator Walsh ignored him because of the feelings that Senator Walsh has about the Parliament in that, as far as he is concerned, if he were to cut all the expenditure of the Parliament he would have done his job. That is not the way to resolve these situations. That is why we will be moving the motion proposed by my colleague, Senator Crichton-Browne-and I hope the Australian Democrats are listening to this debate, because I hope they will support the motion-confirming the October 1985 statement passed by the Parliament that there must be negotiations, and that the Government must face up to its responsibilities in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points I would like to make in supporting the remarks made by my colleague Senator Lewis. Firstly, nobody in this place-particularly on this side of the chamber-has any argument with the need for efficiency or for things to be done in a more efficient manner. However, one of the unfortunate things about democracy is that it does get in the way of the Executive government. It does involve the people and it does involve having proper forums where work can be carried out for and on behalf of the electorate. It is also important to point out that the Clerk, in giving his evidence, did not ask for additional money; he was simply pointing out that the situation could arise where the Senate would simply not have sufficient money to carry out its task because of the action of Executive Government. I do not think we have heard anything which says that may not occur at some time in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne's motion reaffirms the position reached in 1985-which is a time before I came into the Parliament-and here we are, about to enter the 1990s, still in this unfortunate situation. I again stress the important point that the report of Estimates Committee A was a joint report by Government and Opposition senators. At page 3, it simply states:

Several Senators expressed the view that the Senate cannot be master of its own destiny if it does not have the ability to raise its own funds. The constitutional situation is that appropriations have to be introduced by Government and these appropriations have to be approved by both Houses of Parliament. It therefore follows that an appropriation for the Senate has to be determined by agreement between the Executive Government and both Houses of Parliament:

That is exactly the point that Senator Lewis was making when he said that there was no consultation as to the method of making this place, in the Minister's terms, more efficient, or whether the cut which Senator Lewis mentioned was justified. It was simply a statement which came down from on high which said, `This shall be so'. The fact that there is an Appropriation and Staffing Committee in existence, which is charged with the task of entering into those proper negotiations, and which has been totally ignored in this situation, is yet another example of the arrogance of this Government.

As the Minister has said, here we are, at this time in the month, still debating the Estimates. I intend to restrict myself basically to the report which has been put down in this place, but the point is that, if democracy is to work, perhaps greater attention should be given to drawing up the sitting program at the beginning of the year. It was a long time before we came back at the beginning of this calendar year. It could be that we ought to have been sitting for longer periods earlier in the year so that we would not have got into this ridiculous situation which has occurred since I was elected to this place in 1987. The problem seems to me to be badly managed time. The Government has care and control of that and I would be pleased to see it more efficiently handled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not press the point too long, but I put an extra sitting week in for this particular program, an extra two days in for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation and now we have scheduled five weeks, but I cannot say that progress has been marvellous so far. If Senator Bishop wants me to I will do an analysis and give it to her of how much time this chamber has spent on Government business and how much on Opposition and other business. I think she will be surprised by the percentages.
—That is what happens when you don't have the numbers.

—It is not only when one does not have the numbers in this chamber. It is when one does not have the numbers to bring something to a resolution that things meander on forever. If the Opposition ever wins government it will find it very frustrating sitting here, unable to get legislation passed and having legislation with start-up dates which become inoperative. That is a debate I will have another day, and maybe I was at fault for introducing the matter originally.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop and Senator Lewis have stressed the point about negotiations. I am hardly the one to discourage negotiations between the relevant people and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) over the appropriations. I think that point is well taken. In the normal course of events those sorts of negotiations are desirable, but I do not believe that this chamber should have the right to set its own expenditure. It really does not specifically raise the money. I do not know how such a system could be controlled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the motion provides an answer.

—I am not sure it ever has provided that answer. It seems to me that Senator Bishop is talking about democracy-it is democracy sweetened with self-interest. That is the difference. I would not trust us, sometimes, to set our own expenditure levels. I think that would leave us open to an enormous public attack.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, in this debate so far Senator Bishop and Senator Lewis have indicated that they are unhappy with the way the last round occurred. Obviously, I will draw that to the attention of the Minister, and I do not suppose it will come as a surprise to him. It is probably a little unfair to single out just the Minister for Finance, because these things must go through a Budget process to some extent. If there is anything wrong-and I am not conceding there is-the blame would have to be shared among the Executive rather than just one Minister who is the target of all criticism. If honourable senators think their criticisms are tough, they should come and listen to the other Ministers when they talk about the Minister for Finance. There is only one thing worse than the Minister for Finance and it is not that one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate reaffirms the resolution of 2 December 1985 relating to the determination of appropriations for the Senate, and calls upon the President, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for Finance to observe and comply with the procedures set out in the resolution.

I am obliged to move that motion because the terms of the resolution of Estimates Committee A on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1985 reaffirmed the provisions of the resolution in the Senate on 25 March 1982. Those provisions have, thus far, been totally ignored by the Government, more particularly, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). I want to pick up one point that was made by Senator Robert Ray. I am not sure what caused him to meander off on the track of amalgamating the departments of the Parliament, but he will perhaps remember that a Bill was introduced-the Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Bill of 1988-into the House of Representatives which was designed to amalgamate the three parliamentary departments. Senator Ray says that that is a step towards cost saving and greater efficiency. I just remind the Committee of what was stated in the explanatory memorandum to that Bill:

The amendments are not expected to have a major effect on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. Some minor savings are expected from the amalgamation of the 3 parliamentary departments, but the amount is not easily quantifiable.

In other words, there was to be an amalgamation of three departments with no savings. As the President and perhaps honourable senators will well know, there have been a number of inquiries into the efficiency and effectiveness of the Parliament and the cost of running the Parliament. But not one report of any commissioned inquiry has demonstrated any savings, least of all efficiency savings. I say to Senator Ray that it seems from the argument that he has put forward thus far that he thinks accountability ought to be substituted for efficiency. The truth is that democracy is not necessarily the most efficient way of running a country or a society.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a joke.

—Quite frankly, Senator Ray's exasperation does not change the facts. At the end of the day what is important is that the Senate has sufficient funding to fulfil its obligations and responsibilities. I will not saw sawdust by repeating what has been said in this chamber so often recently flowing from the conduct of the Government and Senator Walsh. But the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing has been charged with certain responsibilities which include setting the expenditure levels for the Senate. A motion agreed to by Estimates Committee A in 1985 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: the estimates of expenditure for the Senate to be included in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill shall continue to be those determined by the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.

Senator Ray says that he does not agree with that. But that motion was moved by Senator Richardson when he was Chairman of Estimates Committee A in 1985, carried unanimously and agreed to by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, and Senator Button. The resolution sets out the very clear mechanics in the event that there are disagreements between the Government and the Senate as to the ultimate level of funding required and the level of appropriations submitted to the Senate is less than those, in the view of the Committee, required for the minimum functioning of the Senate. We will watch with considerable care to see what levels of additional appropriations are submitted in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen The Hon K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think at this stage I should make some comments. I think the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) was right when he said there were some difficulties in reaching a base figure when we moved from the old Parliament House to the new Parliament House as far as the appropriations for the Senate were concerned. I just want to refer briefly to a meeting that took place between me, Senator Chaney, Senators Macklin and Coates, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. I thought that that meeting was quite productive. It probably took place too late for any great improvements on this year's appropriations, but it did take place and, arising out of it, the allocation that we were requesting for additional equipment, that we sought in the appropriations, has been agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also agreed on a formula for new policy items. That has followed discussions between the officials of the Department of the Senate and the Minister for Finance. Senator Walsh has told me that he will now participate in the negotiations for next year's appropriations. He will confer with us earlier than in the past to try to resolve the difficulties that we have had in the past. I think at this stage that that is all positive. Let us hope that we do not have some of the problems in the future that we have had to date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was listening to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, a few minutes ago talking about the role of the Parliament and so on, and the exchange between him and Senator Crichton-Browne. I was trying to find in the recesses of my memory what I suspect Senator Ray remembers very well, which is the history of the early parliaments and the struggle between the representatives of the people and the king in trying to get things sorted out.
—I was a leveller.

—The Minister says that he was a leveller. I am not quite sure what that means, but I suspect that it means that he was on the side of the people. In this argument I think Senator Crichton-Browne has been trying to argue, in slightly different language, for the representatives of the people. We have a genuine problem to which there is no neat solution. This debate is a reflection of the fact that there is no neat solution to the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The first problem is that the responsibility to raise taxes and to bring Bills into this Parliament which permit the disbursement of public money lies with the government of the day. That is a constitutional matter. No-one from the Opposition is suggesting that that should be changed. On the other hand, there is the responsibility of the Parliament to act as a parliament, as a legislature and at times as a check on the government. At times its role is to be unpopular with the government. Senator Ray nods and concedes that. There is always a risk. The risk has been above the table and made apparent during the life of this Government by some of the comments of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who, when he has been a bit cross, has actually implied that the Senate may not get the money that it needs to do certain things.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's usually extra things, like extra committees.

—That is right. But one has to bear in mind some of the things that are done by the Senate. In particular, committee inquiries are bitterly opposed by the government of the day. This goes back over many parliaments and governments. Clearly there is a problem in terms of maintaining the proper role of the legislature-our concern is for the Senate-and the role of the government in controlling the flow of funds and responsibility for raising taxes and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate directed itself to this matter and Senator Crichton-Browne has pointed out that the resolution which established the new procedure of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing was moved by a present Minister of this Government, Senator Richardson. It represented an attempt by honourable senators from both sides of the chamber to bring together those potentially conflicting elements. The procedure was aimed to bring the Executive and the Senate into dialogue in the preparation of appropriations. That is basically what is required and has been put down and supported by the Senate time and again, and I am sure will be supported by the Committee again today.

I accept the accuracy of and adopt what the President has said about the recent meeting. But the difficulty is that I think neither the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) nor the Minister for Finance sought to actively involve themselves in the process in the way that is required if it is to work. There were exchanges between the officials of the Department of Finance and the Department of the Senate which did not resolve the disputes. The political elements of the equation, that is, the Ministers, the President and the Opposition representatives on the Committee, were not brought into the dialogue as expected and hence we got to a situation where Bills were presented which did not represent in any sense an accepted view.

In terms of Senator Ray's concerns, anyone who has attended the Appropriations and Staffing Committee meetings, as I have done throughout this period, would have to say that the Committee has genuinely tried to accommodate the responsibilities of the Executive government. There has never been any suggestion that the Senate should ignore the general financial approach being adopted by the Government. There has never been any suggestion that the Senate should ignore the need to pay regard to the Government's responsibilities. We have sought a sensible compromise. I remember occasions when Senator Macklin for the Australian Democrats and Senator Crichton-Browne for the Opposition have thought that the Committee has been far too reasonable and so on. But there has been genuine dialogue at the Committee level.

The meeting that was referred to by the President represented a determined effort by the Committee-it was led by the President but I think he would concede that it was with strong support from me and other senators-to get the dialogue going that is required. I agree with the President that the meeting which we held and which involved the senior Ministers from the Government, Senators Button and Walsh, the President himself, Senator Coates, Senator Macklin and me did come to grips with those issues.

My purpose in standing to speak now and in taking time in what has been a very extended and extensive debate on the Appropriation Bills is to say to Minister Ray, who is at the table, and, through him, to his colleagues that the next period of a few months is actually vital to the sensible working of this system and to the avoiding of unnecessary friction.

The fact is that we have not yet finalised and got on a satisfactory basis the base level of funding, post the shift to this chamber. The Minister has very sensibly put forward a procedure which, once we get a satisfactory base, will involve an incremental change on that year by year and the avoiding of arguments of things which lie within the base. It is a sort of global funding approach, the sort that the Opposition, when it was in government, used in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, for example, to enable greater flexibility within the institution, if you like. I think that is a very appropriate approach for the Senate. I support the idea of there being, in a sense, an annual adjustment which does not go to the detail in the Senate's operation, because that is a matter which is relevant to the Senate's continuing institutional independence. I think in principle that is good and it avoids unnecessary argy-bargying between public servants employed by the Senate and public servants employed by the Department of Finance. There is a procedure for new initiatives which may involve additional calls upon the funds which are raised by this Parliament at the behest of the Government. That is a procedure which, again, I think is potentially workable, provided we have reasonable good faith and dialogue on both sides.

My point though is that, if in the next couple of months-and they are the critical couple of months-there is not a sensible appreciation from the Department of Finance and the Minister for Finance that we need to settle that base in a sensible way, then we will be back to having a real problem next year which will, no doubt, flow on. My purpose in speaking is simply to remind the Government, through the Minister at the table, that we are in a ludicrous situation where, if a bit of goodwill and commonsense does not prevail, this question will arise: does the Senate use a sledgehammer to crack the nut of the incremental concerns it has about its own financial program? The fact is that this Government cannot get any money-no government can get any money-without the legislative cooperation of the Senate.

The Senate has a role and, in a sense, has a remedy, but the remedy is, if you like, disproportionate to the problem which is being addressed. I think that a sensible approach which is based on an understanding of the respective roles of the two and a bit of involvement at the ministerial level is the way to go. I commend the original recommendations that were adopted by the Senate as being a very pragmatic approach which is completely in accord with the principles that the Government has to have regard to and in accord with the principles that the members of the Senate have to have regard to.

Finally, I thank the President for the leadership he has given over the last couple of months in trying to resolve this matter. I trust that that will see the satisfactory resolution and that the Supplementary Estimates next year will put to bed the major concerns that there have been in the Senate about the operation of this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to put one thing on the record before I leave the chamber. It is this: I do not know whether it is out of good taste or otherwise, but there has been something missing from this debate. It could be said that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) may be persecuting this chamber because he does not like it. In general it has been thought that that may have been a probability. To substantiate that one would have to compare the money allocated to the Senate and the House of Representatives and prove some disappropriate share. I just make that point. It may be out of good taste, because we do not normally look at the House of Representatives estimates in any sense in this chamber, that that may have been overlooked. I think that it is an important tool of analysis when one is looking for motive of the Executive or a Minister concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as I know, the House of Representatives has been treated equally with the Senate. We do not have a majority in the Senate; we do in the House of Representatives. One can ask: Having a majority there that effectively rubber-stamps-and I am not beating around the bush when I say that-why should it not be rewarded for being good, if the Senate is being punished for being bad? Yet there is no dichotomy at all between the funding; if anything, I suspect, the negotiators in the Senate have probably finished marginally in front on occasions. I do not know whether that is because Senator Sibraa is a good negotiator; I do not think so. I know that the previous speaker, Senator Chaney, was a marvellous negotiator as well. But that point is missing from this debate, and I make it in case people say that the Minister for Finance or someone else is trying to punish the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether that is a straw man, but you certainly set it up and knocked it down.

—I am still waiting for that. I will conclude on this point: the only explanation, other than that, could be the story of the two farmers who hate each other. The genie arrives on one property and says, `I will give you anything you like, except your neighbour will get double'. He said, `Knock one eye out'. I am not sure whether that is the same approach here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to lengthen the debate. I do not want to debate the last couple of matters that were raised by Senator Ray to the extent that they have been raised so far. To this point there has not been a sense of goodwill on the part of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Government in their endeavours to resolve the problems which the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing has been confronted with. I note here that on 6 September I was required to write to Mr Terry Brown, Secretary of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, following a telephone call from him one month after the Appropriations and Staffing Committee meeting where it was determined that a delegation should meet with the Minister for Finance. I wrote back and said, `Inasmuch as you have been unsuccessful so far in your endeavours to make communication with the Minister for Finance, cease your attempts and report progress to our Committee'. On that very day that this correspondence was delivered to Senator Sibraa, through his efforts and the efforts of one or two others Senator Button and Senator Walsh agreed to meet us. To that point we did not even have a commitment-not a date, but a commitment-that they were prepared to meet us; and that made it somewhat difficult and compromising, in my view, for the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the funding for the House of Representatives and the Senate, let me say this: the House of Representatives does not have an appropriations and staffing committee. Its method for determining funding is negotiations between the Speaker and the Minister for Finance. To say that to measure what is appropriate, necessary and adequate for the House of Representatives in terms of individual details is all that is required for the Senate is quite wrong. I have no doubt that, if the House of Representatives had an appropriations and staffing committee made up of representatives from all political parties who were giving input as to what they considered to be the minimum required for the effective and efficient functioning of that chamber, its level of expenditure would be considerably higher than it presently is. At present the Speaker negotiates, with no bargaining position, with the Minister for Finance, and that is where it is resolved.

As for these final expenditure items, the truth of the matter is that this was the first attempt by the Committee to come to grips with funding. Before we had a notion that the Minister for Finance was going to cut them further, we made cuts of our own volition. We made very significant cuts seeking to pare the level of expenditure to the absolute minimum required for the functioning of the Senate. We ultimately discovered that that was very unwise of us because the Minister for Finance totally ignored that and wrote to us that he had unilaterally decided that the funding would be a great deal less than the minimum necessary. Members of the Committee then went back to review its funding requirements, went through the items and really could not find another dollar.

The cuts in the items became notional; they became absurd; they were simply made-up figures. We were taking salary cuts that could not be sustained. We were reducing expenditure for committee outlays that could not be sustained. We were reducing operational costs that would never be sustained, and we knew it. In the end we just said to the officers before the Committee, `Make the cuts wherever you like because they are all pretend'. The cuts could not genuinely be made. That is the truth of the matter. That is why the supplementary appropriations are so important.

The sad thing is that, in the Committee's seeking to find a baseline figure-that is something that the President has been very conscious of-because of the move from the old Parliament House to the new Parliament House, it has been very difficult to comply with guidelines set down by the Minister for Finance. I might say that we did not get the guidelines until some weeks ago. Those guidelines set down for government departments are incompatible in terms of their implementation and their application to the Department of the Senate because we have moved buildings and we do not yet know what the minimum requirements are. I have no doubt that the Joint House Department is still agonising in trying to determine the minimum that it requires, because that baseline figure has not yet been arrived at. It is ever so true of the Senate's position. The Department of the Senate cannot yet say, `This is the minimum required', because that has not yet been determined. We are still settling into the building. We are still seeking to find what the necessary minimum requirement is. To simply say that departments will have a baseline now-and we accept the need for a baseline-means that we will be subjecting and committing ourselves to a figure below that which is the minimum necessary for the functioning of the Senate.

At the end of the day we know that these problems that we are confronted with now are brought on by the difficult and strident nature of the Minister for Finance and of the Government. For Senator Robert Ray to talk about efficiency in the Senate contrasts starkly with the conduct of the Government in terms of the efficiency that is required. When we have sought guidelines for funding, when we have sought negotiations and meetings, we have been scorned at every turn. It is caused by the failure of the Government to even now accept the motion.

It is interesting to hear Senator Robert Ray say that he now does not believe in the Senate being allowed, or it being appropriate, to determine its own level of funding. This flies in the face of unanimously carried resolutions in 1982 and in 1985. In 1985, as Senator Chaney says, the motion was moved by Senator Graham Richardson. We are now having that resolution overturned. When I interjected on Senator Walsh on one occasion and asked him why he had voted for it if he thought that it was wrong, he said, `I thought the resolution was as much a waste of time then and as useless and as irrelevant as I do now. So I could not care less whether or not I voted for it'.

If that is the attitude of the Government and the Ministers to the funding of the Senate, need we wonder why there is some difficulty in determining what the level of the funding of the Senate is? Ultimately we are confronted with levels below those necessary for the functioning of the chamber. As somebody said earlier, we are back to the days of the Stuart kings, of Charles I. When a government can arbitrarily, unilaterally, determine the funding of a parliament, the efficiency, the effectiveness and the independence of that chamber are very badly compromised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I am loath to prolong the debate but I want to make a few comments on what Senator Robert Ray raised and on the responses by Senator Lewis, Senator Bishop and Senator Crichton-Browne. The questions raised by Senator Ray had nothing to do with the challenging of the separation of powers. I do not think that anything that Senator Lewis, Senator Bishop or Senator Crichton-Browne had to say detracts from the thrust of what Senator Ray was putting because he was talking about the efficient operation of Parliament. Senator Lewis made the point that he thought that this was irrelevant and a separate question from the one at hand. I do not think it is separate because it is directly related in the sense that the efficiency of the Senate is very much part of what we are talking about when we deal with appropriations for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The process that we are currently going through is an example of a gross inefficiency, as Senator Ray has already drawn attention to: the double handling of issues, dealing with these things in Estimates committees separate from this place and then coming in here and asking exactly the same questions again or questions that senators forgot to ask in those committee hearings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give me an example.

—There are numerous examples; read the Hansard. Talk of a mega-department is quite ridiculous. Unifying the departments, as Senator Ray was suggesting-and I do not think that that is inappropriate to raise either, because it directly relates to the inefficiency of the Senate-would not produce a mega-department. In business or in Public Service terms, this organisation as a whole, involving about 3,000 employees, is a tiddlywinks organisation in terms of its budget. It could be very much more efficiently run if there were more unity and not so much double handling of things.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed that, in moving to a new, modern and efficient Parliament House with its new communications and other technologies, we did not at the same time modernise the procedures and the management processes. The management processes and the procedures in this place are in my view an anachronistic joke and leave observers, the visitors to this Parliament House, bewildered as to how the place works: people speaking in empty chambers; people running around to bells like Pavlovian dogs; the constant repetition of quorum calls or divisions. There are numerous examples of areas which we could reform, had we the will to reform them. I think that we need to look very seriously at that. As I have already indicated, there is room for reform in relation to Estimates committees. It seems absolutely absurd that we should repeat the process in Estimates committees and in the Committee of the Whole. There is room for reform in the way in which the committee stage is handled. For example, why can we not hold this stage of the process in committee rooms in a much more free and open way-they could be open to the public in the same way as usual-where we genuinely debate across a table rather than across a large chamber the minor differences that occur between us in relation to minor amendments to Bills?

TALK.START.PARA: —Minor?

—And the major ones too. We come back in here to debate the final stages in any case. Why can we not batch divisions as they do, for example, in the United Kingdom? Why can we not use electronic voting procedures to speed up the process of voting? Why do we have to go through the silly processes of quorum calls as we currently do?

SPEECH.PARA: We have to look at some of the causes of these inefficiencies. I think that part of it is the inherent conservatism of the Opposition, which will make it very difficult at any stage to get any sort of change. I am not suggesting that some of our own senators have not at times been very old-fashioned when it comes to such change. I remember a debate in the old House which related to design of the chamber. I believe that even some Government senators wanted to bring the old chamber into this one complete with its old seating and its old colours and furnishing. I thought that that debate, which went on for an awfully long time, was totally irrelevant, not to say tasteless; so we have that problem of the inherent conservatism of the Opposition. We also have the business paper itself. We are always so busy and there is a constant backlog of legislation. This simply does not allow time for debate of procedural questions. We will never have the time set aside by agreement between parties, when there is a legislative program backed up behind us, to have the full debate that we need to have about the processes and the efficiency of this chamber.

I think it also has to be said that, from time to time, we have obstruction from parliamentary officers-not all of them, but certainly some of them. There are territorial arguments that we have to overcome. If we are to be sincere in our attempt to get this Parliament operating as efficiently as we can, we have to address all those problems and give them some serious thought. If, as Senator Chaney said-and I agree with him-dialogue is not working, we really have to make sure that we get dialogue working at the highest levels of this Parliament and that this chamber and the other chamber make their own determinations about how the processes should work. We should not allow ourselves to be manipulated by the territorial claims of individuals within this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution that Senator Beahan has just made is really quite irrelevant to this debate. The question of reform is quite separate from the question of the funding of the business of this chamber. I refer this chamber to evidence given on 26 September during the hearings of Estimates Committee A when I asked a very specific question of the Clerk and the President. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, to be clear in my own mind, I wonder whether or not the establishment of a new committee, or the reference of a new matter to a standing committee, is considered to be a new policy initiative in terms of funding.
The answer from the Clerk was this:
Yes. Unless there is some way in which it can be met from existing funds by some savings, that would be regarded as a new item requiring additional expenditure.
I then said:
Basically, the situation that we are in is that the business the Senate can do is determined by the executive arm of government, namely, the Minister for Finance.
Mr Evans said:

There is a potential in the existing situation for that to occur. There is a potential, which has been identified by senators in debate, for the executive government to be in a position to have a veto, as it were, over some new committee activity, for example, that the Senate might determine.
I said:

Theoretically, if the said Minister or the executive government determined that they did not like a particular line of inquiry they could simply fail to provide the funds and that could stop that line of inquiry.
Mr Evans said:
There is that potential in the current situation.

That is what we are debating and that is the position that Senator Crichton-Browne is trying to remedy by moving his motion. It is a serious question. Nobody would like to see an extravagant allocation of money for the running of this place, but it is necessary to allow the free flow of information and debate to take place.

Last week I watched on television members of the communist regime in Prague sitting around a table doing what they had done for decades-that is, determining how the people would live their lives without the free flow of information. The Government of East Germany has been destroyed because the people of that country do not have the freedom to express their views. The matter we are now considering is one of efficiency versus the right of the people to have their views heard and expressed in a public forum. There is a need for proper financing to be made available so that this precious freedom, which is enjoyed in a minority of countries, can continue. People who suggest that senators are indulging in some sort of self-interest by saying that they are concerned to preserve the system which guarantees us freedom should be ashamed. It is a precious freedom, a precious right, and I, for one, intend to defend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that all honourable senators would agree that the functioning of this chamber is an important contribution to the pluralist and federal democracy we have in Australia. I am sure that, in particular, those who have participated in the committee system obviously would uphold the worth of those committees in helping this chamber, and indeed governments, formulate policies which are well considered and can enjoy the support of the Australian people. I think that is common ground and it should be emphasised as we look at the motion that has been moved by Senator Crichton-Browne.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply wish to indicate that the Government finds that the motion can be supported and ought to be supported by all senators in the chamber. There is no difficulty in reaffirming the resolution passed on 2 December 1985 relating to the determination of appropriations for the Senate. I believe that the reaffirmation by this chamber can be supported at this time. I certainly commend the motion to all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to make the terrible mistake of talking the Government out of agreeing to my motion. I should comment on the remarks of Senator Beahan. I can only assume by his fresh and flush contribution that he has not followed the history of this debate. He talked about amalgamations having a capacity for achieving greater efficiencies. He obviously has not read the hundreds of pages of reports, the comments on reports, the observations on reports and the reports on reports on the capacity for improving the functioning of the Parliament as a whole. The golden thread which runs through every single report and every comment on them is that amalgamation does not necessarily lead to any efficiencies and, certainly, any effective savings. As I said before, this determination was made by the Government when it introduced its legislation, I think in 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Beahan might think it is an anachronism to attend divisions, to be in this chamber to listen to debates when nobody else does and to argue that the forms of the Parliament are redundant and, therefore, ought to be removed. Perhaps he has been in Western Australia too long and has been infected by WA Inc., where big is beautiful. We have seen the disaster that that has caused in terms of taxpayers' funds.

The truth of the matter is-and perhaps I can be judged as a reactionary-that certain forms, standards, guidelines, baselines and parameters which are a measurement of decency, honesty, integrity, a sense of purpose and morality ought to be preserved as benchmarks. There seems to be an obsession by some to change fundamentally some of the systems for the sake of change; in the name of efficiency but simply for the sake of change. I am not opposed to changes which lead to efficiency yet preserve the integrity of the chamber and I do not think any reasonable thinking person would be. But to sweep something aside because it is a reflection of the past in my view leaves us in a vacuum when making judgments about what is proper and what is appropriate.

As I said earlier, democracy is not the most efficient, effective, and certainly the cheapest, form of government, but it is the fairest form I know. It can be best preserved by having parliaments and chambers of parliament that are able, unencumbered, to preserve and fulfil the obligations which are cast upon them by the system within which they work. When that nexus is broken, when we have a system where the Executive government determines exclusively the capacity for the Parliament to function, we will no longer have a parliament with independence and the people will no longer have a voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply indicate that I, too, support the motion that has been moved by Senator Crichton-Browne. I consider it to be an important issue. I felt that I should rise to indicate my support and to ensure that that was on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of the Parliamentary Library presented the Estimates Committee with several problems-two of them major. One of them related to the appointment of the new head of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO), and one related to the creation by officers within the Department of the Parliamentary Library of a secret and illegal account, which terms I will stick with as being technically correct by way of dictionary definition. I will deal with the euphemisms that the Auditor-General chose to use when I come to that item.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I will deal with the appointment of Mr Walsh to the position of head of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office, replacing Mr Goodall. Some disquiet surrounded this appointment, and I think it is worth while going through that disquiet and looking at the questions that were raised. I stress that the Estimates Committee report is a report of both Government and Opposition senators. We all agreed that these matters were of a serious nature. Without in any way questioning the right of the Presiding Officers to appoint whomever they so choose to that position, it is nonetheless necessary and prudent to examine what in fact occurred.

The Parliamentary Librarian, Mr MacLean, indicated in evidence that was placed in the report that he took the responsibility of advertising and establishing a selection panel in the normal way for the appointment of someone to the position of head of PISO. The interview panel was selected. It consisted of two senior parliamentary officers and two outsiders who had particular expertise. These people undertook a series of interviews and forwarded a report which identified four applicants as being suitable for the position. However, the panel recommended that only one of those people be appointed. When that report went to the Presiding Officers, we heard evidence that there were some significant concerns felt by them about the recommendation that had been made. So they put those concerns to the Acting Librarian, Mr Brudenall, because Mr MacLean was overseas. If my memory serves me correctly, the timing of his return from overseas and the timing of Mr Brudenall being asked for his opinion were very close indeed. One may ask why it was felt necessary to bring Mr Brudenall into question when he had not been involved in the panel selection process. In no way am I disputing the right of the Presiding Officers to appoint whomever they wish, nor am I reflecting on the person who was subsequently appointed to the position. But what is important is to go through the process.

There has been a distinct, concerted effort by the Executive arm of government to say that a distinction should be made between process and outcome-that somehow the process does not matter and that only outcomes should be looked at. Those statements have been made by departmental heads and they have been made by Ministers in a number of statements. There has been a distinct and concerted effort to do this. It is one I totally reject. If one does not look at the process one can have an outcome which is corrupted by a corrupted or improper process, so it is important to look at the whole scheme of things.

Where this position got very difficult is here. We heard evidence from Mr MacLean. I might say that it was very difficult to get evidence from him as he was what one might call a very reluctant witness. We did not have the opportunity to hear from the other members of that panel. One of the members of that panel was so concerned that that person felt an obligation to impart the view that the Senate Estimates Committee had been misled in evidence given. There was no avenue available under the Estimates Committee for us to subpoena or to call for those additional panel members to give evidence to it. I specifically asked the President whether, firstly, he would let me read the report; and, secondly, whether we could call additional witnesses. Subsequently, upon negotiation, the President did share information in a sanitised way-without my sighting it-with Senator Lewis and me. But the question of doubt remained. I repeat: in no way am I disputing the right of the Presiding Officers to appoint whomever they will. My concern was that it was also reported to me that the responsible departmental head, namely the Librarian, did in fact take some action to try to prevent that report in any way becoming public. I find in that a good deal of disquiet.

The report outlines three procedures that the Committee believes ought to have been followed. Firstly, the Presiding Officers could have sent their reservations back to the original interview panel for further consideration. Secondly, the Presiding Officers, given their reservations, could have simply overturned the original recommendation and proceeded to make their own recommendation on the basis of information before them, which they were perfectly entitled to do. Thirdly, the Presiding Officers could have referred their concerns to the head of the Department for his consideration and recommendation when he returned from overseas. The reason I have raised these matters in this sequence is, again, set out in the report of the Committee. We recommend that in the future, wherever possible, the Presiding Officers refer their concerns to the interview panel prior to making their decision. In this way credibility and confidence will be maintained in the normal interview and appointment procedures.

I repeat: none of what I have said is said to reflect upon the right of the Presiding Officers to make the appointment, nor to reflect upon the person who was the subject of the appointment. What I am saying is that in these matters-and it is a very sensitive office-things must not only be done correctly but must also appear to be done correctly, and the correct procedures must be followed. If we do not have guidelines and some system, we will lose the public's confidence or the confidence of this place. Indeed, during some of the evidence we heard there was a great deal about the electronic system in this building about which we do not know and over which we do not have control. It is not a new thing that I have raised that matter. From the time we moved into this building I have been concerned about security, about the ability of people to hack into our computer systems, what effect the addition of modems to our computer systems will have, and the fact that there is a more secure system for the executive arm of government than there is for ordinary members and senators. I still find those things of grave concern.

So in these sensitive areas I think we should be extraordinarily prudent that we follow form, that we ensure not only that things are done properly-that we get a good result-but also, indeed, that things are seen to be done properly and that proper processes and procedures are followed.

There are several other matters that I want to raise in regard to the Department of the Parliamentary Library. As I have said, I have already flagged the question of the secret account. I also wish to raise the question of the secret account. I also wish to raise the question of the appointment and use of consultants, and the additional information dealing with the question of consultants, that came to the Committee after the hearings were concluded. I seek your guidance, Madam Temporary Chairman, as to whether I should continue to use the five minutes available to me or whether it would be better to restrict the debate to the question of the appointment of the head of PISO at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

SPEECH.PARA: As I explained earlier, the Estimates Committee had no power of subpoena, as other committees of the Senate do. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be unfortunate, to put it mildly, if this debate in the Committee, proper though it is, should in any way be taken by anyone who might be listening or who might read the Hansard as reflecting on the capabilities and integrity of the successful candidates, or indeed of the unsuccessful candidates.
