SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I now turn to the question of the appointment of former officers as consultants. During the Estimates Committee hearings we heard of the example of one Dr Thistlewaite, who was an example of the classic Friday to Monday syndrome-that is, that person ceased to be a public servant on a Friday and began being a consultant to the same department, carrying out basically the same responsibilities, on the following Tuesday. The reason he did not commence on the Monday was that Monday was Anzac Day.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we have some guidelines and some understanding, which we do not have in place at the present time in a sufficient manner, as to how people who are public servants one day and purport to be the consultant the next day are to be dealt with. So that we know exactly what transpired: Dr Thistlewaite was on a salary of $46,000. He was then appointed as a consultant at the rate of $420 per day for one contract, carrying out basically the same work as he was involved in as a public servant. He then got a second contract, where his daily rate rose to $730.

During the period of examination of witnesses in the Estimates Committee hearings it became quite apparent that the job for which Dr Thistlewaite was paid at a rate of $730 was to assist various people in the various things that they were doing. In total, Dr Thistlewaite was able to earn in 11 months $101,270, as distinct from the $46,000 he had earned previously. Dr Thistlewaite did take the opportunity to turn himself into a proprietary company, which was paid the fee. Indeed, this met the classic example which Mr Boucher, Commissioner of Tax- ation, identified in one of his rulings as the Friday to Monday case. This was dealt with in a very severe way by the Australian Taxation Office, but we still seem to be able to have it in other parts of government.

No guidelines came from the evidence given to the Estimates Committee. The Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) has not adopted any guidelines relating to the re-employment of former employees and nor does it have a clear policy regarding the quarantining of employees who indicate that they will be resigning to take up a position outside the appointment. Indeed, that became relevant in the case of Mr Goodall himself, who was the previous head of PISO and who has gone off to join the private sector. We said in the report:
Without any such guidelines or quarantining procedures the potential will always be there for conflict of interest and the accusation that any future contracts were not undertaken at arm's length.

The concern that we have as a committee is that proper procedures ought to be in place. It was interesting to receive in November Estimates Committee A Additional Information Received, Volume 1. An answer was provided to a question asked by both Senator Michael Baume and me about the number of former government employees who have become consultants. It is interesting to note that the answer on page 50 says:
In respect of contract staff provided by Computer Power Pty Ltd during 1988-89 Computer Power has advised that 13 contract staff have formerly been public servants at some stage.

I do not know from whence they came. I do not know what their area of expertise is or whether there is any conflict system. I would like further information about that. However, I do find it quite interesting that 13 such people were provided by way of consultancies during that period. It is for this reason that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has been very concerned to ensure that government departments comply with the guidelines, and indeed the law, that require them to publish details of consultants in their annual reports.

When one finds a single example such as this the question which immediately springs to mind is: How many others are there? The question that flows from that is: How do you find out? The answer is that at the moment it is very difficult-one cannot. It could indeed be a quite useful and helpful addition if, when we are dealing with consultants, we could have published details of any background that they have had within the public sector within, say, a reasonable period of time. Certainly, with regard to the Department of Defense in the United States if someone leaves that Department they cannot become a consultant within a two-year period. It may be that we should be looking at something of that nature.

The whole question of who appointed Dr Thistlewaite and who approved his terms and conditions of employment seems to have been a little shrouded in mystery and difficult to ascertain finally. But, as I have said, my main concern is that I am certain that this is not a one-off example. I would like to find some way in which we could ascertain that we are properly served and that there are not any systems being worked that enable people simply to get a greater share of the public purse by changing their status. Again, Mr Temporary Chairman, I would like to ask whether I should move on to the question of the secret account of $88,000 at this stage or whether other senators might wish to contribute to the debate concerning Dr Thistlewaite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should take this opportunity now to make a brief point. I accept the points made by Estimates Committee A and by Senator Bishop this morning. Mr Walsh has informed me that a code of ethics is being prepared for the staff of the Parliamentary Informations Systems Office based on the code of the Australian Computer Society Inc. This will include re-employment and quarantine arrangements, and I would think that, once it is available, it could be made available to members of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the President for that advice; it is pleasing indeed. I now move on to that section of the report at page 7, where we deal with the matters under the heading of `The ``Unofficial'' Account-PISO'. I begin by referring to the definition of the word `unofficial'. It is defined by The Macquarie Dictionary as `not official; informal'. `Informal' is in turn defined as `not according to prescribed or customary forms; irregular'.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Estimates Committee hearings, I chose to use the word `illegal' and that was challenged by Mr MacLean, who told me that that was yet to be determined, so I settled for the word `secret'. I think it is useful to look at the definition of those terms. `Illegal' is defined as `not legal; unauthorised'. `Secret' is defined as `done, made, or conducted without the knowledge of others; kept from the knowledge of any but the initiated'. `Kept from the knowledge of any but the initiated' seems to be a very good working definition.

I put to the Senate that the use of the word `unofficial' is very simply a euphemism, and one chosen to be used by the Auditor-General in the report that he furnished to the Committee concerning the establishment and use of that secret and illegal account. I will stick to the term `illegal' because indeed the Auditor-General finds that the practices that established and operated that account were in breach not only of the Constitution but also of the Audit Act. I reckon that makes it pretty illegal and a hell of a lot more than unofficial.

The facts of the matter were disturbing indeed. When one sees the sort of temptations to which people can succumb, the sum of $88,000 is perhaps not so paltry as some may in the beginning think it is. The evidence given before the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales shows that Mr Ross, who was employed by the Department of Administrative Services, was tempted for sums far smaller than $88,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's your price?
—I beg your pardon; how dare you! How dare you, Minister! I ask that the Minister for Consumer Affairs withdraw that remark immediately.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that.
—I withdraw.

—I should think so. With regard to the question of the secret account, it was established that so-called obsolete Honeywell equipment, which was somehow inherited by the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO), was sold through Computer Power Pty Ltd and some $88,000 was received. This money was put into a secret and illegal account from which purchases were made and accounts were paid. One of those payments was to pay for four Canberra-based officials, including Mr Goodall, to go to the Sydney Hilton Hotel, remain there for three days and have a little conference together. They were allegedly to have spoken with people from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, but the Auditor-General found that somehow they found it was not necessary to talk to people from the ABC, and so no-one came to that alleged conference but the four gentlemen from Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Mullane, who gave evidence, told us that, in his understanding, Mr MacLean, the responsible departmental head, had known of these plans; that Mr Goodall had authorised travel by aeroplane for two of the four officers to fly to Sydney to stay at the Sydney Hilton Hotel so that they could have discussions with each other for three days; and that an office car was also made available. In evidence before the Estimates Committee, Mr Mullane also told me that Mr Goodall had not stayed at the Sydney Hilton Hotel. I specifically asked whether or not, as Mr Goodall left in July and as this function was held at the end of June, this might have been for the purpose of a celebration to farewell Mr Goodall. Mr Mullane told me that Mr Goodall had not stayed in the hotel, but yesterday he wrote to the secretary of the Estimates Committee, as follows:
CORRECTION TO EVIDENCE PRESENTED TO THE COMMITTEE ON 3 OCTOBER 1989

In answer to a series of questions from Senator Bishop on 3 October 1989 (Hansard page no. A124) I advised that the former Manager, PISO (Mr Goodall) did not stay at the Hilton Hotel to my knowledge. My answer was given in the context of questions which I interpreted as seeking to establish whether Mr Goodall had incurred expenses which were charged to the unofficial account. In accordance with my knowledge I advised the committee that Mr Goodall had not incurred any such expenses as his accommodation arrangements were private and my answer to the final question ``not to my knowledge'' was given in this context. This answer was, however, strictly incorrect . . .
It was just plain incorrect. The letter continues:
. . . as I was aware that Mr Goodall had stayed at the hotel under private arrangements.

I did not earlier advise the committee of this matter as I considered that my evidence was not significant to the extent that I was aware, following the committee's hearings, that Mr Goodall's accommodation arrangements were likely to be advised to the committee in any case through the Auditor-General's report. Nevertheless, I have considered the matter further and have determined that my responsibility to advise the committee was not discharged by the committee obtaining this information from the Auditor-General's report.
I trust this letter discharges that responsibility.

So the whole sorry story is that the use of this account-whereby some $1,600 was paid for this so-called workshop at the Sydney Hilton Hotel, together with the purchase of microwave ovens, having pictures framed, and other bits and pieces-was all strictly illegal, yet the Auditor-General chose to file a report in which his conclusions were not substantiated by his own report. I have been a very strong supporter of the Auditor-General and the Australian Audit Office. I was a member of the Public Accounts Committee Subcommittee that prepared the report entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament, yet so much of our system depends on the strength and courage of the Auditor-General. This report, couched in the terms it is, with the use of euphemisms, I find an affront to this Parliament. Accordingly, when the matter was dealt with by the Committee, there was shared indignation. Later in this debate Senator Childs, as Chairman of the Committee, will move that the whole sorry mess be referred to the Public Accounts Committee.

The Auditor-General found that there were several breaches of Finance Regulations, that there were breaches of sections 81 and 83 of the Constitution and that there was a breach of the Audit Act. He found as follows:
PISO officers-
including the responsible departmental head; and what is responsibility all about, unless that is where the final responsibility lies?-
had no cause to be unaware-
a nice double negative, but the message is strong-
that prescribed procedures must be followed by all Commonwealth departments, including the Parliamentary Departments and should have acted accordingly . . .

How can a departmental head conceivably have become aware, as Mr MacLean did in July, that this illegal account existed and do absolutely nothing about it with regard to calling in the Auditor-General until September? For the Auditor-General to come in and say, `It's okay, fellas; they really didn't mean it', is simply not acceptable. What messages are we sending out to the rest of the public sector? Is it that proper behaviour is not required? The report said:

There is no evidence to suggest that PISO officers, and the persons employed by Computer Power under the prime contract between PISO and Computer Power, acted in other than good faith, nor is there any evidence of fraud.
They may have indulged in illegal and highly improper practices, but the Auditor-General has said, `It's okay, fellas; you really did it in good faith.' What a ridiculous situation that is.

This is a matter of shared concern. A strong message has to go out that says, `This form of behaviour is unacceptable'. Just as the President has said that Mr Walsh is putting in guidelines for dealing with the appointment and quarantining of consultants who have previously been public servants because of the example of Dr Thistlewaite, so a strong and determined message should go out to the rest of the public sector to say that this sort of behaviour will not do, and the persons responsible will be held accountable without a whitewash. Without a strong Auditor-General our system cannot function. He is the interface between the Executive and the Parliament. In the earlier debate on the Department of the Senate we went through the history of why it is important that final power should lie with the Parliament. Simply to have a whitewash, and for the Department of the Parliamentary Library to go on as before, will not do. It is certainly pleasing to see that both Government and Opposition senators are supporting a call for a further and distinct inquiry by the Public Accounts Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw attention to the following statement in the report of Estimates Committee A:

SPEECH.PARA: On reading the Auditor-General's report, the Committee is of the view that the summary and recommendations do not address fully all the matters raised in the body of the report, particularly the findings and conclusions.

I propose to move a motion submitting a number of points to be considered by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I refer to that introductory paragraph because some of the attitudes that Senator Bishop expressed are her own. Her attack on the Auditor-General is probably going further than any of the other members of the Committee would be prepared to go. However, the Committee is concerned about the matters that have been raised.

First of all, I should thank the President, who acted with every speed to make sure that the Auditor-General's report was provided to the Committee literally at the same time as he received it. So we were able to look at that report, but, in the whole process, we were under some pressure because of the exigencies of getting the Estimates through and preparing our report. Also, because of the limitations of Estimates committees, our view was that it would be better for a thorough examination to be undertaken by the appropriate body, which is another joint parliamentary committee. I move:
That the Committee, having considered the Report of Estimates Committee A, recommends-That the following matter be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for inquiry and report:
An examination of the events surrounding the establishment and operation of the `unofficial PISO account' with particular reference to:
(a) the role and responsibility of the former manager of PISO;
(b) the role and responsibility of the Parliamentary Librarian;
(c) the role and responsibility of Computer Power as prime contractor to PISO;
(d) the role and responsibility of consultants employed by Computer Power on behalf of PISO;
(e) whether a conflict of interest did arise when a consultant, employed by Computer Power, acted in a line management position;
(f) the role and responsibility of other managers of PISO who were associated with this account;

(g) the apparent lack of involvement of the Finance Section, Parliamentary Library with the auditing procedures of PISO's accounts and the role and responsibility of the Auditor-General in oversighting this matter; and
(h) whether the breaches outlined in the Auditor-General's report warrant further action.

That is a comprehensive series of questions that will require further detailed consideration. I think that everybody agrees that this section leaves everything to be desired as far as efficient administration is concerned.

I am just as amazed as Senator Bishop is at this ridiculous letter we have received from Mr Mullane, the Director, Planning and Administration. A person who could write this letter after the specific questions that were asked at Estimates Committee A is a person whose word I would not be able to trust at any future meeting that I attend. He clearly ducked the question that was being asked and gave the impression that the person concerned was in some private place and not in the very hotel that he was being quizzed about. This is the sort of thing that justifies the President's concern about the administration of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO). I am fortified by the early response to the management control of PISO, and no doubt Estimates Committee A will keep this matter clearly under its purview in the future.

However, we are at a stage now where the appropriate decision has been made because, within a very short time, we can expect a detailed and thorough examination to take place. It is also fair to say that the Auditor-General's report had to be compiled very speedily. There was pressure from Estimates Committee A to have the report before it as quickly as possible and, if there are any further revelations, I think we will have control of the situation. The alarm bells have been rung. In those circumstances I commend the motion, which comes from Estimates Committee A, as a way for all the facts to come out under a thorough examination by a parliamentary committee, which can, with all the advantages of a joint standing committee, in the next parliament give us the information that we still require on the incidents that have occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I am restricting my comments at this stage to those matters that have been raised in the report of Estimates Committee A. Page 14 of the report deals with offsets and the partnerships for development program. There are several matters of a continuing nature concerning the offsets and partnerships for development program. They have been the subject of report No. 270 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which predated my coming into the Parliament. They have also been the subject of the report of the Inglis Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements, the subject of a Department of Finance minute and of a review of the Finance minute by the Public Accounts Committee, which will soon table its report. They have also been the subject of much discussion in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to one particular item that was dealt with in examination of witnesses concerning how the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC) operates these programs. In doing so, I am in no way looking at the question of policy. It is the right of the Government, as the Government, to set policy. However, it is the task of the scrutiny committees to ensure that the administration of those policies is effective, efficient and accountable.

Two particular aspects came to light in the course of the Estimates hearings which I think need to be dealt with today. The first relates to an item that was raised by my colleague, Senator Lewis, in this chamber in a question addressed to Senator Button concerning a report in a computer specialist publication that three of the partnerships for development had been underperforming. The report went on to say that advice had been given to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) that, if a news release was put out with particular wording, the fact that these three partnerships had been underperforming could be camouflaged.

In the course of Estimates hearings we were able to identify the person who gave that advice to the Minister. Where it became most important was, after looking at the annual report on offsets, one picked up an intention that there were to be audits and it became apparent that pilot audits were being conducted on three of the partners. In answering questions from me to the officer concerned, evidence was given that two of the firms that were subject to the pilot audit were two of the three firms that had been underperforming. A press release was duly issued by the Minister in the way in which he was advised, so the fact that these companies had been underperforming had been camouflaged. The really worrying aspect is the degree of close questioning that is necessary to find out the real answers. The question which I posed, which I was interested in, was whether or not at the time of writing the memorandum the officer concerned had the reports of the pilot audits. I received an answer in the negative.

On further examination it was shown that the officer knew what was in the reports of the pilot audits, although he did not actually physically have them. It is of a great deal of concern when one looks further at the partnerships for development process that one sees, again from evidence given in various committees in this place, which is all on the public record, that in seven out of 15 contracts which existed in June 1989, if my recollection serves me well, there was a clause which required the Commonwealth Government to maintain a healthy economy. They are not the precise words in the contract. The beginning of the clause states, `The Commonwealth of Australia shall'-not `may', `strive to', or any of those sorts of terms, but `shall'. Nobody in his right mind could say that we are maintaining a healthy economy in this country at the moment. Consequently it is quite open to any so-called partner-I refuse to call these agreements contracts because they are totally unenforceable-who feels that it is all a bit much to simply say, `Well, you haven't upheld your end of the bargain. The economy in this country is lousy. We are off the hook'.

The Department seems to argue in all the cases of offsets in partnerships for development that there is no way that it can give any meaningful penalties. I do not accept that. The messages that go out to industry are basically that the Government is not serious. Let us take a look at a specific example. Again, in evidence, we had a look at the way in which the Department values transfers of technology. We looked specifically at the question and one company, SNECMA. Examples are given in the report at pages 15 and 16 of the way in which the Committee was concerned at the sloppiness of the administration of these programs.

One of the other worrying pieces of evidence that came from those hearings dealt directly with the question of placing value on an obligation being discharged. An officer gave evidence of a figure that was accepted as discharging an obligation under an offset program. When we finally tested how he arrived at that figure, we found that it basically came from the company which had undertaken the obligation in the first place. It then passed on the figure to the Australian beneficiary who passed it on to the Department.

Dr Fitzpatrick from DITAC answered questions. We heard that there are still no guidelines for determining values of discharge of obligations in this area. We found that, although they had been talked about and were first raised by the Auditor-General in 1984, they are still being dealt with in a totally ad hoc fashion. The Committee was further critical of the results that failed to flow from highly expensive overseas trips of senior departmental officers. Although that information was supplied to the Committee in confidence, we can look at the global results without breaching that confidence.

As I said, it is the Government's right to set policy. It is the obligation of the scrutiny committees to ensure that the taxpayer gets value for money. There are those who argue that the way in which the situation has been set up now means that the costs incurred by people who wish to compete in the largest single information market in Australia-that is, the Federal Government-are enormous and the benefits which they receive are minimal. In looking at the offsets and partnerships for development program, one can question whether or not the Australian taxpayer is getting value for money. Basically the evidence that was given did not sustain that thought, at least for this member of the Committee. The Committee shared concerns in the areas that I have outlined in the report. As I have said on several occasions before today, it is important to note this is a joint report of Government and Opposition senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. No other senator having risen, I call Senator Bishop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I am addressing my remarks to the matters that we have dealt with in the report. Accordingly, I am concerned to deal with the question of the Australian Trade Commission, Austrade, and with some concern that we had regarding evidence that was given about development and oversight of strategies which Austrade uses. The Committee makes this point:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the Committee appreciates senior officers being available to answer questions, it defeats the purpose of parliamentary scrutiny if too many questions have to be taken on notice.

What occurred and prompted that comment was that we had appearing before the Committee the General Manager of the Export Development Group of Austrade. I was concerned to ask him questions about strategies which Austrade had developed for particular categories of export. I was particularly interested in the category of therapeutic devices. My interest in that stems from having sat on the Public Accounts Committee inquiry into therapeutic goods, the publishing of a report, the various debates that have taken place in the lower House and will soon take place in this place, and the effect that that legislation will have on any marketing strategy.

When we come to debate the Therapeutic Goods Bill honourable senators will find that I will take issue fairly seriously with some of the statements made by the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, Mr Tickner, about my attitude to what is in that therapeutic goods report. We have in the Public Accounts Committee a practice of publishing whenever possible-and it has been my experience that this is the case-a unanimous report; therefore, that means that we have to accommodate all points of view. I will be arguing those later. The long and the short of it is that the legislation which is before the Senate now and which has been dealt with by the House of Representatives will impose great cost burdens upon Australian companies dealing with therapeutic devices. Some people are unkind enough to say that it imposes a tax.

I asked the good officer who appeared before the Committee whether he had a strategy concerning the export of therapeutic devices, to which I got an affirmative answer. Then I asked him to tell me something about it. He could not. Then I asked him how many other strategies he had. He said that he thought about 15 or 20. I asked him whether he could tell me about any of those, and he could not. Then I asked him-seeing that he had a strategy and that he was the export manager-for how long he had held that position. He told me three years. I asked him whether or not he was aware of the Public Accounts Committee report dealing with therapeutic goods. He had never heard of it. Then I asked him whether he was aware of the fact that at that stage the legislation which will impose these cost structures was before the House of Representatives. He had not heard of the Bill either.
I find that of grave concern. It prompted this comment in the report:
While the Committee appreciates senior officers being available to answer questions, it defeats the purpose of parliamentary scrutiny if too many questions have to be taken on notice.

That is a polite way of saying that the officer was not on top of his area. Austrade is a very important part of Australia's endeavour to become a competitive exporting nation. Austrade has a vital part to play. I am sure there are very many other things which Austrade is doing which are highly successful, well-informed and serving the nation in a good sense. But when this sort of thing occurs in a public hearing, when somebody is simply not on top of the work that that person is supposed to be doing, we can forgive the public for starting to lack confidence. The comment that I read out from the report is a very polite way of saying that it just will not do.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly--

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that today's national accounts figures show that labour productivity has fallen for the second successive quarter? Does he agree that, in the absence of a changed economic strategy, Australian workers appear to be heading for yet another year of declining real wages?

—I must say that I am not aware of the productivity figure in the national accounts, but I will have a look at it as soon as possible and put myself in a position to comment on it. As Senator Chaney would know, a variety of factors affect productivity performance. I think the fact that there has been a slowing in the domestic economy would have some influence on those figures. I will look at the figure and I will give the honourable senator an answer as soon as I can.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his preliminary answer, but I draw his attention to the fact that the national accounts figures published today show that in the June quarter there was a reduction of 1.5 per cent in the gross domestic product per hour worked index and in the September quarter there was a minus 1.7 per cent change. So, that is quite a strong change in those two succeeding quarters. I ask the Minister whether he agrees that the implication of those figures is that, of necessity, there must be a decline in real wages.
—I have nothing to add to what I have said. I will look at that figure.

—Can the Minister for Resources report to honourable senators on any new developments regarding the Government's tree planting policy which is an essential component of its environmental policy? Can he inform the Senate what the extent of Commonwealth funding for this purpose has been so far this financial year? Can he advise the Senate of the role which planted and native forests play in controlling the effect of greenhouse gas emissions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform Senator McKiernan of what new developments there are in the Government's tree planting program because today I announced that $1.48m would be allocated to 20 tree planting projects throughout Australia. Those projects are located in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and South Australia and they involve activities such as tree planting to assist in controlling salinity, reversing the effects of eucalypt dieback, and rehabilitating land affected by over-clearing and mining. Tree planting is also undertaken on farms and for the enhancement of natural regeneration. The program under which we have allocated these funds is the national afforestation program. Already this year I have announced some 50 projects that have been funded under this program to the level of $6.5m.

ANSWER.PARA: All of that funding is catalytic in nature-that is to say, the Commonwealth is not bearing the full cost of any such program. The Commonwealth is contributing funds to programs in which other costs are being put up either by the States or by commercial interests. The value of the total program is much more than the Commonwealth's contribution, but the Commonwealth's contribution makes such a program possible.

To conclude my answer I need to reply to the last part of Senator McKiernan's question. Earlier this week I think Senator Puplick asked me a question relating to why we were funding hardwood plantations in the Australian Capital Territory for the purposes of trialling them for fuel for wood-burning by consumers. The contribution trees and plantations make to the environment is vitally important and, in announcing the grants that I have awarded, I have referred to many contributions. But the significant point is that trees are sinks or traps for carbon dioxide; they consume carbon dioxide and generate oxygen. In that sense they make a positive contribution--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is photosynthesis.

—Yes. I am trying to put it into words that some people in the Senate will be able to understand. The contribution is quite a significant one in terms of expelling oxygen into the atmosphere and reducing the total level of carbon dioxide emissions. I should point out that the energy requirement for the production of wood products is considerably less than for other materials. For example, the amount of coal required to produce a unit of energy to create one tonne of building material is for wood, 0.13 tonnes; for steel, 1.15 tonnes; and for aluminium, 6.12 tonnes.

—Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories confirm that it is the position of the Commonwealth Government that, as a result of a memorandum of understanding signed by Ministers Cohen and Brereton on 5 March 1986, the Government of New South Wales is absolutely liable for all construction costs in excess of $30m related to the National Maritime Museum, regardless of how great those costs may eventually be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The memorandum of understanding makes it clear that the Commonwealth's contribution was to be $30m, with the exception of costs which might have arisen out of design changes that came about at the Commonwealth's instigation, or with the exception of fit-out costs. I understand that the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, met with the New South Wales Minister a few days ago. The Commonwealth has made its position very clear; there is no doubt that the memorandum of understanding sets this down. We are surprised, particularly in view of previous discussions, correspondence and arrangements entered into between the governments, that at this late stage the New South Wales would make the claims which it has now made.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly, the Commonwealth holds strongly to the view that it should provide $30m, plus perhaps some small extra amount. There is an argument over whether the design of the American gallery alterations might have involved the Commonwealth in extra costs. I am not certain of the exact details of that, but we are talking of very small amounts-nothing like the $40m which was mentioned by Mr Hay yesterday. In fact, from estimates which the Commonwealth has been able to discover, the $70m figure was right out of the blue. We had believed that it was somewhat closer to $50m or $55m than it was to $70m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I seek some clarification. Is the Minister saying that the memorandum of understanding signed by Ministers Cohen and Brereton, other than the way in which it relates to additional costs arising from changes in the design-which were initiated anyway by the Commonwealth-effectively amounts to a blank cheque making New South Wales responsible for all expenditure on the construction of this museum over and above the $30m, as agreed, and the minor amounts to which the Minister referred in his original answer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is correct. It has to be remembered that, when Darling Harbour was getting under way a few years ago, the estimate of $30m was considered to be pretty close to the mark. There were massive blow-outs in construction costs at Darling Harbour and this is but one of them. However, the difficulty for the New South Wales Government is that the memorandum of understanding makes it quite clear-and I reread the language this morning-that the Commonwealth is up for $30m. I understand why that State would attempt to change that, given that it does not like to pay the bill; but pay the bill it shall.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to an article on page 1 of today's Sydney Morning Herald headed `Coalition plans Medicare shake-up'. Can the Minister advise the Senate as to whether the Government intends to maintain its current system of funding the additional cost of Medicare by payment according to means through a levy on taxable income?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed `Coalition plans Medicare shake-up'. The article commences with a paragraph which perhaps the people of Australia generally, other than consumers of the Sydney Morning Herald, should hear. The article begins:

ANSWER.PARA: People who did not take out private health insurance would be charged a levy or tax penalty under the Coalition's health policy, the Opposition health spokesman, Mr Peter Shack, said yesterday.

I can advise honourable senators that the Government has no intention-despite what the Opposition says about its attempt to force millions of Australians into expensive private health insurance-of changing the way the additional cost of Medicare is funded through a levy on taxable income. The Medicare levy arrangements ensure that payment is made according to a person's ability to pay, providing health cover for each according to need. It redistributes from the rich to the poor and from the healthy to the sick. It is a fair system for all and one which Australians overwhelmingly support. There is more than sufficient evidence of support for Medicare by ordinary Australians. Indeed, annual polling on that subject has shown that the incidence of approval has lifted from 55 per cent at the point of introduction to around 74 per cent now.

The Sydney Morning Herald article reveals an Opposition agenda to destroy that system of Medicare and to introduce regressive arrangements which favour the rich and hurt middle and low income earners. Another piece of its long awaited policy has now dribbled out, and it reveals that those who do not take out private health insurance will be forced to pay a levy or a tax penalty. That offers us repeats of the past, a rerun of the 1970s when Fraser had under his Government God knows how many versions of Medicare, which totally confused the Australian community.

In 1975 Malcolm Fraser said, `We will maintain Medibank'. He then broke his promise and in 1976 introduced a system, like that which is now proposed, under which those who did not take out private health insurance were forced to pay a higher levy of 2.5 per cent. In other words, it was the big stick approach. The Opposition is now offering the same, although it is yet to reveal the level of the levy, in its seventh attempt at a health policy by the fifth Opposition spokesman on health. The opting out arrangements would mean a redistribution to people on high incomes who could find payment of flat rate insurance cheaper than current levy arrangements at the expense of low income earners who would pay more through an increased levy to make up the shortfall. It would destroy the stability, security and simplicity that Medicare offers to produce a costly, confusing mess. Just as happened in the 1970s, it could not be sustained and inevitably there would be constant change. All this is to solve a problem that does not exist.

The Opposition says that its aim is to resolve imbalances between public and private sections which are supposedly occurring under Medicare. The fact is that more people than ever before are being treated in our hospitals-both public and private-and that under Medicare the private hospital share of the total number of patients treated has actually increased. The Opposition is therefore proposing to destroy Medicare to fix up an imbalance which has not occurred, the result being, again, that the rich will pay less and the poor will pay more. That, from the Opposition, has a very familiar ring about it. It is another example of the capital gains tax syndrome of helping rich mates at the expense of the poor and the needy. The Opposition's pledge to destroy the capital gains tax would bring about the most massive redistribution of income from the poor to the rich in this nation's history. Now it is proposing to do exactly the same in health. On that basis, the Opposition's policy will obviously be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) secretariat report on trading policies which has criticised the United States of America for its increased protection for various industries and its inclination to use trade retaliatory measures outside the general agreement. I also refer him to the decision of the disputes panel of GATT earlier this year which upheld an Australian complaint that the United States (US) quotas on sugar imports are illegal under the GATT rules, and the United States commitment referred to in the GATT newsletter of July 1989 to agree to the adoption of this report. I ask: firstly, has the United States changed its trading policies and its commitment as a result of the GATT ruling? Secondly, what has the Australian Government done to put pressure on the United States to change its trade policies, which are so obviously harming Australia's trading interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are still some problems with US sugar import restrictions. The US announced on 12 September that the current US sugar quota year, which was to have ended in December 1989, would be extended until the end of September 1990 with an additional global quota of 860,000 tonnes being established. Australia is entitled to ship some 70,000 tonnes in the extended quota period. On a pro rata basis this announcement represents the status quo plus an increase in access for foreign suppliers of one to 2 per cent-that is all. In announcing the change to the quota, the Secretary of the US Department of Agriculture, Mr Yeutter, noted that this was not related to the recent GATT panel case on the US sugar quota system, but was to cover a market shortfall in the remainder of 1989.

ANSWER.PARA: A GATT dispute settlement panel was set up at Australia's request in 1988. It found that the import quotas on sugar currently maintained by the US are, as Senator Macklin has intimated, inconsistent with GATT rules, and recommended that the US be asked to terminate these restrictions or otherwise bring them into conformity with the GATT. The panel's report was adopted by the GATT Council on 22 June this year.

The recent change to the quota system that I have described does nothing to bring the US into line with GATT rules. It leaves unclear the access to be permitted in the calendar year 1990. As to what we are doing about this, the endless process of bilateral discussions is under way again. Bilateral discussions on the means of bringing the US sugar import regime into conformity with the GATT have been held at officials level and, most recently, by the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Michael Duffy, during his meeting with US Trade Representative Carla Hills and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter in Washington in mid-October.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security inform the Senate of the take-up rate for the family allowance supplement (FAS)? What steps is the Government taking to ensure that all eligible families know of the availability of this payment and how to apply for it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov's question relates to a most important aspect of the Federal Government's family policy. It is important for two reasons: it is an aspect that is very well targeted to areas of need, and it delivers substantial payments to those particular areas of need. The Senate probably does not need to be reminded, but the importance of this aspect of policy was highlighted I think in September 1987 by Bill Kelty, who said:

ANSWER.PARA: Left to our own bargaining capacity, it would take at least 50 to 60 years to increase the lowest wage earners (to rates) represented in the family package.

Recognising the importance of the FAS, the Government has been keen to ensure access to it across the community. It should be said that the increase in access to FAS has been dramatic and impressive. In late 1987, in the vicinity of 60,000 families were receiving the family allowance supplement. This has now risen to 190,000 families. That amounts, on a general average over the two years, to something like 1,250 families per week signing up for FAS payments, which amounts to 7,700 children per week on a general average. There has been a dramatic increase in an area which delivers impressive financial support for families in need. At the moment, 190,000 Australian families are receiving benefits. That amounts to 1.2 million Australian children. It also amounts to more than 25 per cent of all children under the age of 16.

As I said, it is an enormous achievement in that it delivers tax free assistance to low income families. This increase in the number of those claiming has been brought about by a successful publicity effort by the Federal Government, particularly the Department of Social Security. As the average amount of FAS payments to families is about $50 per week and a quarter or so get extra rent assistance, we are really talking about a substantial contribution by government to areas of need.

Having achieved this, the campaign, as Senator Zakharov implies, needs to continue and it will continue. The strategy is to promote and encourage further awareness of FAS payments. It is a strategy which is targeted, for instance, to mothers in hospital at the time of the birth of children, to schools at the start of the school year and generally through radio and press advertisements. This is an important part of the Federal Government's social justice program. It is a responsible, well-targeted program which the Government will continue to promote in order to assist families in need.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to his statement at the end of Question Time on Monday in answer to my question concerning the Buy Australian-made campaign, where he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . When Luscombe and Partners and John Singleton Advertising made their presentations to the ministerial committee they were both rejected and asked to do better.
This morning, on Channel 9's Today program, Mr Singleton stated:
I made some minor modifications to the campaign, made them slightly more positive, but very minor cosmetic changes then resubmitted, along with the other agency.
He further said:
But the change was just simplifying the economic message. It was nothing important.

If only such changes were made, on what basis did Mr Singleton's final submission justify being awarded the $2.4m contract, given that the official assessment committee had rejected his tender? Is it true that Mr Singleton's firm stands to gain a substantial fee from this contract and, if so, what is the method of calculating the fee? Finally, at any stage of the selection process was the Australian Labor Party Federal Secretary, Mr Bob Hogg, or any other senior Labor Party figure-apart from the Minister-consulted on the campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Having failed so dismally to get this off the ground a couple of days ago and having got the drubbing Senator Bishop got on the Today show this morning, I can understand why she wants to keep trying. She will have to get a positive out of it, so she thinks. But she will not with this question. As John Singleton said, he did not change anything important. He changed the economic message. What may not be important to him is very important to us. When this was submitted to us we regarded the concept of the campaign as good but we found the economic message that he had delivered in it absolutely unacceptable. We would not have accepted it under any such circumstances. So he took it back and he revised it. When it came back it was acceptable and we acted accordingly.
—Ensured it was better.

—It was not just a bit better; it was a lot better from our point of view. From the point of view of the agency it is the concept work that is important. That, I concede, did not change at all. Then again, I never suggested that it had. I am asked what John Singleton's fee is. It is a $2.4m campaign. I will find out what the projected fee would be on that. As far as consulting Mr Hogg is concerned, there would have been no reason to do so and I did not. I did not consult anybody else. I had two colleagues to consult, Mrs Kelly and Senator Walsh. I consulted them and they were in complete agreement.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the Minister's answer, could he explain to the Senate why, if this great alteration was made, the transcripts for the commercials which are presently going to air have remained exactly the same as they were submitted to him in August 1989?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop is showing classic ignorance again. Senator Bishop is not listening; so I will repeat it. We were given a script and we rejected it. The script that is being used now is not the script that we rejected. That is a fact. Senator Bishop can pursue that at her own risk.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a newspaper report in the Courier-Mail of 28 November 1989 that a protest meeting was being planned against Queensland's repatriation hospital services being merged into the State's public health system. Has the Minister noted the comments of a Mr Bickle that repatriation hospital staff intended to meet `to show their concern about moves which soon could result in veterans and their families being deprived of their rightful care'? Are such concerns justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Humphreys is most concerned about the remarks attributed to Mr Bickle. I am not sure whether Mr Bickle was reported accurately, but his remarks are wide of the mark and could cause many in the ex-service community to worry unnecessarily about their future health care. As I have said before in this chamber, the Federal Government will always retain responsibility for the health care and treatment of veterans and war widows. Under this Government, veterans' health care is being sensitively and professionally delivered. This would not change with integration. It is, therefore, not true to say that veterans and their families might be `deprived of their rightful care' if the repatriation general hospital at Greenslopes were to be integrated into the Queensland hospital system. Both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs have said that there will be no integration if the ex-service community or staff associations have reasonable grounds for concern about the arrangements finally developed.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to concerns expressed by some members of the ex-service community about guaranteed access and quality of care after integration, the Government has circulated a proposal which, if adopted, would effectively give veterans a private patient health care scheme. Many in the ex-service community see real advantages in such an arrangement. I draw that to Mr Bickle's attention.

Finally, in the Courier-Mail-I am not sure whether it is yesterday's or today's Courier-Mail-an advertisement was placed by the south-eastern district branch of the Returned Services League headed `Keep the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital for the Veterans'. The Minister is disappointed that this advertisement, which has appeared on the eve of the Queensland State election, does not provide an accurate picture of the facts about proposed integration. He wishes to repeat the Government's assurances to the ex-service community that it will remain responsible for their health care needs and that it will continue to consult with senior representatives of major ex-service organisations at every step along the way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories will recall that, following answers I received from his Department in Estimates hearings on 28 September, I wrote to him on 3 October 1989 asking to be provided with copies of the tender documents submitted by advertising agencies in connection with the Buy Australian-made campaign in 1986 and in 1989. He will also recall his reply of 18 October, with which he provided what he said were copies of the submissions made by four of the advertising agencies, including Luscombe and Partners and John Singleton Advertising. In the light of the Minister's answer to Senator Bishop on Monday of this week in which he said that the ministerial committee rejected the submissions from Luscombe and Partners and John Singleton Advertising and that these agencies were both asked to come `back with their second versions', I ask: Firstly, why did he not advise me in his 18 October letter of the existence of these second submissions? Secondly, did he not thereby mislead the Senate by giving the impression that he had released all documents relating to the submissions by the advertising agencies? Thirdly, will he now provide me with the second submissions from Luscombe and Partners and John Singleton Advertising that he should have provided on 18 October? Fourthly, will he also provide the Senate with the documentation which recommended that the contract be awarded to Luscombe, including the report by Reark Research Pty Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not misled anyone. I got a request from Senator Short and I responded to it. There is no more or less that I can do. That we asked two agencies to come back and resubmit, do better, improve, I do not think changes anything. In the end we had to look at two concepts. We picked what we thought was the better one. We have released a welter of information on the matter. I will check to see whether or not there is any reason why the documents that the honourable senator is requesting cannot be made available on the basis of commercial-in-confidence. If not, then I will be happy to make them available.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's (BHP) steel division has announced its intention to invest $200m in a new continuous caster for its Whyalla steelworks? Is this investment designed to increase the supply of steel available for export? Will the investment also lead to the establishment of new employment opportunities?
—You don't know about this, do you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, Senator Lewis will be interested in the answer and so I will give him the benefit of a fulsome answer. Yes, I did know about this investment; I was advised about it this morning. It is important because this is a large investment that is taking place at Whyalla. It is part of a strategic export development program of BHP, and most of the investment by BHP in steel, which has been very large since the formation of the steel industry plan, has been at Newcastle and Port Kembla. The new investment is in a high technology continuous caster at the Whyalla steelworks. BHP believes that this investment will provide higher quality structural sections and rails for the domestic market and will provide a significant boost to its export capacity.

ANSWER.PARA: Work on the project will commence in early 1990 and provide over 200 new jobs during construction, and it will give a substantial boost to South Australian industry, with Australian content being around 80 per cent. I welcome this decision by BHP, which shows a high degree of confidence in being able to establish internationally competitive manufacturing operations in Australia. This latest $200m is in addition to the $650m already announced for new growth recently, and export projects for the steel division as a whole. BHP's announcement coincides with the publication today of the September quarter national accounts, which show that total private capital expenditure for the 12 months to the September quarter grew by over 13 per cent. This investment surge has come mainly from factory construction and equipment to fit out these factories. It represents, of course, a slight decline in investment in the September quarter, but from a very high base, and is an example of the productive investment phase currently under way in Australia. I should make the point that the October balance of payments, released last week, showed a 39 per cent increase for the month in the exports of machinery, transport equipment and manufactured goods.

This continued investment in the steel industry, an industry which produces cheap steel by world standards and which is based on both raw material advantage and technological advantage, is consistent with investments taking place in other sectors of the economy. For example, current investment in food processing is $225m in four different plants of which I am aware. In pulp and paper the investment currently is $300m. In chemicals it is $420m, with another $20m being announced today. Also, investment in basic metals is over $2 billion. In various sectors of the economy where capacity is desirably being enlarged, this investment is happening. The Government very much welcomes that and the BHP investment announced today is a further sign of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care to the proposal of the Health Insurance Commission to introduce a personal identification number for Australians as part of management changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Can the Minister please confirm that tenders for the supply of electronic equipment to be used in association with the scheme closed on 20 November, exactly the same date as the deadline for comments by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, which clearly indicates the farcical nature of the so-called consultation process? Is it true, as reported in the Canberra Times of 23 November, that the equipment being sought will include a magnetic card reader? Accordingly, can we assume that this plan by the Health Insurance Commission, supported by this Government, will result in personal medical information relating to members of the community being stored in a central computer in the Commission's office?

—I would have to reject any characterisation, as has come from Senator Calvert, and indeed from some people who wish to try to discredit the Health Insurance Commission, that this is any sort of Australia Card revisited or any intrusion into privacy. Indeed, the Health Insurance Commission issued a discussion paper about this matter before it proceeded. In the discussion paper the Commission rightly and properly raised the question of confidentiality and protection of patients' records. Government is about running things and protecting the interests of individuals. The carping criticism from honourable senators opposite, who try to denigrate and destroy the achievements of the Government, is what one would expect from an Opposition without one single idea to rub together. I reject entirely the criticism and the inference in the honourable senator's remarks. As to the other details referred to in the question, I will obtain some information and reply to him later.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask whether the Minister, following Mr Beazley's tour of the arms bazaar, AIDEX 89, yesterday, is aware of the fact that exhibitors include a number of companies who are currently involved in various corruption scandals in the United States and Europe. Is the Minister aware that stallholder FFV, a Swedish company, was named in a report commissioned by the Swedish Government this year as having flouted an official arms embargo for years by selling anti-tank guns and ammunition to blacklisted states, much of it via the United Kingdom? Is the Minister also aware that another Swedish company, Bofors, was partly responsible for the fall of the Indian Government this week after allegations that its officials used bribery to secure a $1.55 billion order for howitzers and that four executives of Bofors are currently facing prosecution for selling weaponry to Iran and other Persian Gulf states? Did the Minister meet Monsieur Serge Dassault, the Director- General of Avions Dassault, which sold arms to Iraq during the Gulf war, including Mirage F1 jet fighters, some of which, according to the Geographic magazine may have been used to drop the deadly poison gas bombs on Kurdish civilians, an act which Australia deplored? Finally, I ask the Minister whether it is true that AIDEX will be held every two years, despite community objections to Australia's involvement and an article in the Canberra Times of 2 October this year which reminded us that `the arms world is a dirty business, although run on the face of it by gentlemen and retired officers'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Vallentine thinks may have occurred and what has actually occurred sometimes differ. I do not believe that the Government is in any position to assert what companies may have done in other countries. I do not really understand how we could be expected to do that. It must be remembered that AIDEX was organised by a private company, not by the Government. As far as the Australian Government is concerned, breaches of laws in another country are a matter for that country and the company concerned-not for this Government. Obviously, if any of these companies broke Australian rules they would be pursued with vigour, but I am unaware that that has occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said here before in answering questions from Senator Vallentine and others, it is a fact that Australian regulations on arms exports are strict. They include the prohibition of sales to countries which are subjected to United Nations arms embargoes. Given that AIDEX was organised by a private company, I do not know that the Government can be held responsible for who attends. Whether there are any other exhibitions of defence equipment held in Australia is a matter for the organisers after they have evaluated the position. In respect of the person to whom the honourable senator referred, I am not aware that the Minister has had any meeting with that person.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am sorry, but I find the Minister's answer inadequate; so I want to ask further: Does the Minister know about the troubles involving the British company, Ferranti International, following its acquisition of the United States company, International Signal and Control, whose erstwhile partner, James Guerin of ISC, is currently under investigation for his association with a bankrupt defence contractor whose president has been gaoled for conspiracy to defraud the US Defense Department of $12m, while one of ISC's subsidiaries has been named in Italy as selling arms to Iraq, possibly against US laws, with unauthorised credits from an Italian bank? I probably will not get an answer to that part of the question, either, but I ask why the Minister and this Government are spending taxpayers' dollars to welcome to Australia companies which are known to be corrupt. This is a Government-sponsored exhibition. It might be run by private contractors but it is being promoted by the Government, it was opened by the Minister and taxpayers' dollars are involved in its promotion. So why is the Government bringing to Australia companies which are known to be corrupt in an effort to embroil Australia further in the negative weapons industry--
—Order!
—the end result of which--
—Order!
—at the point of impact--
—I raise a point of order, Mr President.
—It is not a supplementary question; it is a completely new question.
—And it is a speech as well, Mr President. I ask you to rule it out of order.
—If the Minister wants to answer it, I will allow it; if not, I will call another question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given that the role of the Reserve Bank of Australia traditionally has been to act as a lender of last resort to back up deposits and this role has been performed, first, at the discretion of the bank and, secondly, if the bank is of the opinion that it is necessary to stability of the financial system, I ask the Minister: Does the Reserve Bank role still apply in a deregulated environment to all banks in Australia, including foreign banks when they may have incurred large overseas debts that could jeopardise the security of the locally held funds of depositors?

—I do not know the answer to that question, but I will get a reply as soon as possible. I assume that the Reserve Bank applies its fiat with equilibrium to all banks. I will be as shocked as the honourable senator if the answer is that it does not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. As the Minister is no doubt aware, Myanmar, formerly Burma, is now reported to be moving towards reforming its trading practices by opening its doors after nearly 30 years of a centrally planned economy. The country's Trade Minister, Mr Abel, recently said that the Government realised that its trade and economy had to be boosted in order to move forward. He is also reported to have said that he was optimistic that Myanmar's friends in the region could help in enhancing its economy. Does Australia have any plans to assist Myanmar, and what form would this help take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the abandonment of the so-called Burmese path to socialism was announced over a year ago and an economic reform program has been commenced in Myanmar, it is generally agreed that the country will have to resolve its political problems before substantial progress can be expected in improving its economy. As I have made clear in this place on numerous occasions, certainly the Australian Government's policy remains one of unequivocal support for democratic and economic reform.
—Is the election process still on track?

—It has been announced for 27 May. It may not be a very satisfactory election process if people are kept in gaol, but Senator Hill should hold his horses; I can assure him that his huffing and puffing will not make any difference whatever to the process. Australia has been and will remain at the forefront of those countries encouraging authorities to hold free and fair general elections and to improve the observance of human rights.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian aid to Myanmar was suspended last year with the exception of some humanitarian aid under the United Nations Children's Fund and the Mandalay dairy development project on which work was resumed in March for reasons I have explained on the public record. As I said in Parliament on 15 August, I am not inclined to consider a full resumption of Australia's aid program unless and until there is substantial evident progress towards a restoration of human rights and electoral democracy. Australian Government assistance to economic reform in Myanmar must, of course, be subject to the same considerations.

As to the private sector, Australian companies are free to enter into joint venture agreements in the country on the basis of their own commercial judgments of the prospects and risks. The Government places no inhibition on such activity. Finally, I should say that it is clear that the opportunities for such activity will be much greater with the economic reform that would inevitably accompany political reform. That is the lesson being learnt all over the world at the moment from Vietnam to Czecho- slovakia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EDUCATION OF GIFTED AND TALENTED CHILDREN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Noting the Budget allocation of $230m for sport during the next four years, including in particular $53.1m for elite athletes, and the additional separate funding for the Australian Institute of Sport, I draw the Minister's attention to recommendation No. 6 of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children and ask, first, what approach the Government is taking to the recommendation of that Committee that a national research centre be established, initially supported financially by the Government and for consideration by the Australian Education Council in October this year. Secondly, does the Government believe that increased research, professional and curriculum development in this area of education would be in Australia's economic interest and is particularly important for talented children in disadvantaged groups?

—I can only say that the answer to that question has to be yes, but the circumstance in which that additional assistance is provided has to be a subject of government decision at this stage. I will obtain an answer from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and see whether I can provide it as quickly as possible.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. A report has been expected on this specific matter from the Australian Education Council. Can the Minister also ascertain whether the Government has received such a report? If not, when does it expect to do so?
—Yes.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Will he describe what practical measures Australia has taken in pursuit of the aims set out in United Nations (UN) resolution 43/75 and specifically Section S, conventional disarmament on a regional scale, which was promoted and voted for by Australia? Will the Minister assure the Senate that he will ensure that no Australian military equipment will be exported to countries guilty of human rights abuses, and that sales will not be made to countries that are acquiring arms at `levels that are well beyond those needed for self-defence', as described by the Minister in his speech before the General Assembly of the United Nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the subject of our disarmament credentials, I think Australia stands very proud. In the context of multilateral forums, our role particularly on nuclear issues is well known and appreciated, I hope, by Senator Dunn in regard to the comprehensive test ban, non-proliferation treaty, and so on. Of course, that has been translated into a regional context with our active support and promotion of the South Pacific nuclear free zone, which has recently been ratified into effect.

ANSWER.PARA: In the conventional context, the major regional activity in which we have recently been involved in pursuing, among other things, our obligations under the particular resolutions to which the honourable senator refers is, again, chemical weapons. Our hosting of a regional seminar and a series of associated activities involved in raising consciousness about the implications of chemical weapons has been widely acknowledged and applauded not only in the region but elsewhere around the world. It was the subject of particular attention at the Government-industry conference on chemical weapons a little while ago and is an example which has subsequently been picked up elsewhere in the world, with Venezuela in particular indicating that it is about to launch a similar initiative in a Latin American context. So, whether we are talking about nuclear or conventional arms, Australia's credentials are impeccable.

On the subject of defence exports, I think that Senator Richardson has already addressed that matter today. The Minister for Defence is primarily responsible for the administration of that area, although there is a process of consultation between the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Attorney-General and me before any defence exports are permitted in accordance with our present Government policy. Government policy provides that the so-called controlled defence equipment will not be exported to governments that seriously violate their citizens' rights, unless there is no reasonable risk that the goods might be used against those citizens. The whole policy is premised on the assumption that other countries have the same right as Australia to provide for their defence. The guidelines which govern this are quite elaborate and make it clear that we will observe United Nations Security Council embargoes.

The policy is applied and enforced in the context that we remain concerned at the destabilising international effects of escalating arms supplies but continue to play an active role in the UN on effective monitoring of arms transfers. At the end of the day, we do not think-as Senator Dunn appears to-that there is anything fundamentally wrong about defence exports in an environment where, unhappily, armies still have to be supported and maintained because of the potential situations in which they can become involved in this complex world. But within that general policy we acknowledge the need to apply stringency and rigour in the way in which our exports are directed, and that is the way the policy is administered.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the Minister's new position on Cambodia announced last Friday, devised for domestic political reasons and described in the Sun-Herald editorial as `naive in the extreme'. Is it the case that the Minister's proposal will require the support of the Hun Sen regime? Will it not also require the support of the Khmer Rouge? If not, how can it be implemented without the support of these two particular Khmer factions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to hear that Senator Hill is lifting his game and getting some policy input now from media publications as sophisticated as the Sun-Herald. I am sure that will contribute no end to his appreciation of foreign policy constraints in the real world and to the formulation of Opposition policy because, clearly, there is nowhere to go but up with that particular foreign policy at the moment. In the context of the Opposition's Cambodia policy, I am reminded again that as recently as two weeks ago-mid-November-there was a major shift in Opposition policy, articulated by its Leader, Mr Peacock, adopting a new, hard-headed realistic approach to the Cambodian settlement which involved, among other things, a quite explicit recognition of the desirability of the Khmer Rouge having a role in a transitional administration. That is the position that was adopted with absolute clarity and vigour and without equivocation by Mr Peacock, and he has been scrambling ever since to recover the ground that he lost on that occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: The policy adjustment that I explained in this place a few days ago was not premised in any way on domestic political considerations. It was premised on my judgment that, although there was a perfectly sound, logical and intellectual foundation for that particular aspect of the comprehensive settlement process, which involved a quadripartite transitional administration-an aspect obviously sound enough to appeal to Mr Peacock as recently as two weeks ago-the prospects of that approach being adopted were becoming more rather than less remote. This was not only because of the continued resistance of the Hun Sen administration in Phnom Penh to any suggestion of participation of any kind by the Khmer Rouge in a transitional administration, but also because of the way in which fighting was escalating, making it more and more difficult to contemplate those factions sitting down together and administering together the government of that country, and because of the way in which worldwide opposition was building up to the concept of any role being given to the Khmer Rouge in that context. Those considerations have been building up and becoming more and more apparent over time, but it was not until I had had the opportunity to canvass the concept of a United Nations (UN) controlled administration with a number of interlocutors that I felt it was timely to put that proposal on the public record.

This is not something that sprang full blown from my or my Department's brain in the last week or two; it is an idea that has been around for some time, advanced in particular by Stephen Solarz, the United States congressman, in one form. It is something I discussed with him in New York a few weeks ago. In particular, it was an idea that I felt it necessary to discuss and talk through with, among others, the visiting Deputy Prime Minister of Cambodia in the Hun Sen administration, Mr Kong Som Ol.
