As I have made clear on the public record, that conversation was very interesting because, notwithstanding my expectation that there would be an outright dismissal of this concept as not being realistic, to use Senator Hill's expression, in relation to a government that is exercising de facto control over the country at the moment, Kong Som Ol-I do not want to go into the details of the conversation-said that he accepted that this was something which might be worth considering further, and he undertook to consider it further, in discussion with Mr Hun Sen. No doubt that subsequently occurred, and I will be interested to see what the outcome is.

The initial reactions from elsewhere-through both public channels and private diplomatic channels-have not been in the slightest bit dismissive. Everybody, myself included, knows perfectly well what the practical constraints are in getting any agreement between not only the internal Cambodian parties but also the external parties. I have acknowledged frankly from the first moment that there are practical difficulties involved in getting Hun Sen to step back from his present position of de facto authority and, at the same time, getting agreement from the other factions, in particular the Khmer Rouge. I have noticed, as Senator Hill may have, Prince Sihanouk publicly expressing support for this particular concept. At the moment, he is working very closely with the Khmer Rouge, as we all know, within the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea. That is an interesting indication of what might happen. If the Khmer Rouge is to come further into this process it will need some incentive to do so in terms of the position that is adopted by China; but, again, that is true of every other proposal now on the table.

I make no claims for the practicability of this particular proposal other than that it is at least as practicable as any other proposal on the table. It is a darn sight more attractive than most such proposals on the table. I believe, not just on the basis of my own intuition but on the basis of the process of consultation I have already undertaken before putting this on the public record, that this idea will make a useful contribution to the further process of trying, not to score points about this but, for once, to bring to an end this tragic human conflict in Cambodia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to understand the Minister's answer to mean that he agrees that his proposal cannot be implemented and that a UN administration cannot be installed without the support of the Hun Sen regime and the Khmer Rouge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It obviously cannot be implemented without the support of the Hun Sen regime. Whether it can be implemented without the support of the Khmer Rouge remains to be seen. Much depends not just on the position of the Khmer Rouge but on the Chinese Government standing behind it and continuing to supply it. Whether people are prepared to take risks with an isolation scenario in relation to the Khmer Rouge-which is the favourite solution of many people-depends very much, as I say, on whether external supply will continue to it. The Khmer Rouge stands to gain something from this particular proposal if its rhetoric is to be taken seriously about its willingness to ultimately participate in free elections in that country.

ANSWER.PARA: The whole situation is very difficult and very complex-much more difficult and complex than the Opposition is capable of appreciating. I think we should note that, and not regard this whole thing as an occasion for scoring cheap points, but rather as an appropriate occasion for all of us to try to group together towards a solution which will genuinely stop the killing in that country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COOKE INQUIRY: APPEARANCE BY COMMONWEALTH PUBLIC SERVANTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Minister seen reports asserting that the Federal Government has prevented Commonwealth public servants from appearing before the Cooke inquiry currently operating in Queensland? Is there any truth in such reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to the report in the Australian of 29 November, the decision to refuse the Cooke inquiry subpoenas for three Australian Electoral Commission staff to give evidence was not made by the Government. The decision was made by the Australian Electoral Commission, which, of course, is an independent statutory authority established by the Parliament to conduct Federal and industrial ballots. I am advised by the Commission that the decision was made on constitutional grounds. On the basis of the Commission's legal advice, State commissions of inquiry are not competent to compel the attendance of Commonwealth officers. Any attendance pursuant to the subpoenas that were issued could create unwelcome precedents on that basis alone. Furthermore, the Commission has current industrial ballot prosecutions in train which could be prejudiced if the officers were required to give evidence and be subjected to cross-examination on these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the suggestion that the Government might authorise the officers concerned to give evidence, the position is that it is not a matter for a government; it is really a matter for the Commission. I should add that the Commission is cooperating fully with the Cooke inquiry and has made and will make available to it everything that is on the public record and anything that any citizen may obtain under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. On the other hand, the Commission has also made it clear to the Cooke inquiry that it will not make available any material that is exempt from disclosure under the Privacy Act. As the matter is still before the Cooke inquiry and may be subject to further litigation, I will not in general comment further on it other than to say that the Cooke inquiry was essentially set up as a political exercise. I do not really expect it to last another five days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Chaney asked me a question about what he described as the productivity decline revealed by the national accounts published this morning. He referred to the figure of productivity decline as 1.7 per cent in the last quarter. I undertook to try to obtain a detailed answer about this but I have been advised that the national accounts show a decline of 1.7 per cent in the gross domestic product (GDP) per hour worked index.
—That's what I said.

—I understand that. But Senator Chaney asked his question under the general heading of productivity. The GDP per hour worked index is not a productivity figure. It reflects stronger growth in employment of 1.2 per cent than in output which was 0.7 per cent. I provide Senator Chaney with that view today and I will give him a further answer tomorrow.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today in Question Time I was asked some questions by Senator Bishop and Senator Short concerning the Australian-made campaign and the Singleton agency. One of the questions I was asked by Senator Bishop was: `How much did the Singleton agency receive?'. As I mentioned, there is a $2.4m budget for the campaign. Of that, $2.02m is budgeted for the advertising component. The agency will receive $62,628 as its fee for media related head hours, plus a $3,000 submission fee. That makes a total of $65,628. It appears from the inquiries that I have made that we did more than the right thing by Senator Short by giving him the revised transcript and not the first one.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 October Senator Harradine asked me a question which could be broadly headlined as about housing affordability. At that time I gave him an answer and promised that I would supplement that answer. I now have that supplementary answer from the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. It is somewhat detailed and I therefore seek leave of the Senate to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Further to Senator Cook's response of 4 October 1989, I would add that median purchase prices paid by first home buyers are generally between 20 and 30 per cent below the median prices paid by all home buyers in all capital cities. Senator Cook pointed out in his earlier response that preliminary data for the September quarter 1989 show that house prices have stabilised in outer suburban areas of Sydney at around $100,000 for first home buyers.

Comparable data on first home buyer house prices in outer suburban areas of the other capital cities are not readily available. However, median prices paid by First Home Owners Scheme recipients during the September quarter 1989 (preliminary) were around $95,000 in Melbourne; $90,000 in Canberra; $75,000 in Brisbane and Perth; $60,000 in Adelaide; and $50,000 in Hobart. Figures for Darwin are not available. Data supplied by home lending institutions support these results. The Minister for Employment and Education Services has provided the following response to issues raised in this question concerning youth employment opportunities:

Youth employment opportunities are dependent on a wide range of complex economic, educational, social and other factors. Given the interrelationship of these factors, it is difficult to make valid projections of how they will affect youth employment into the next century.
the Government's policy of increasing education participation for young people will lead to enhanced employment opportunities for this group in the next century;
the labour force aged 15-24 is projected to decline into the next century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move a precautionary motion concerning a sitting of the Privileges Committee this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, if the Senate be sitting at 8 p.m. this day, the Standing Committee of Privileges have leave to meet during the sitting of the Senate, for the purpose of a public hearing.

Briefly, the Committee has scheduled a public hearing in relation to its reference of 9 March concerning possible adverse treatment of a witness before a select committee. The Committee's hearing is scheduled to commence at 7.30 p.m., subject to the adjournment of the Senate. Should, however, speakers on the adjournment continue to speak for a lengthy period, the Committee would appreciate the indulgence of the Senate to begin its sittings no later than 8 p.m., as two of the witnesses are coming from interstate. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter was raised with the Opposition. Although I indicated earlier in the week that our normal inclination is to resist such requests for leave, we think this is a reasonable request, as it is unlikely that the Senate will still be sitting, and we therefore will not oppose the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 29 November, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

In the interests of an early end to the devastating pilots' dispute, the need for the Government to instruct Australian Airlines to open discussions with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to test the sincerity of the AFAP's claimed willingness to negotiate on pay, productivity, hours and conditions.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: (3.05) I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

In the interests of an early end to the devastating pilots' dispute, the need for the Government to instruct Australian Airlines to open discussions with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to test the sincerity of the AFAP's claimed willingness to negotiate on pay, productivity, hours and conditions.

I am not surprised to see a large number of Australian Labor Party senators absent from this chamber because they have shown absolutely no interest in obtaining a settlement of this dispute. We are repeating the request that we have made consistently to the Government over a number of months to take a constructive approach to this dispute and try to get a settlement on proper terms. For many Labor senators it appears to be a matter which is extremely boring and not a matter of concern. I suspect that many people in the Australian community are also rather bored with the pilots dispute. But for others this is a matter of life or death. Many individuals and firms in the tourist industry have seen their livelihood struck down. If Labor senators are doing their jobs and spending any time in the community they will know that many people are desperate. I see that Senator Collins, who is going to participate in the debate today, is giggling away. Senator Collins comes from the Northern Territory which, as much as any other part of Australia, is being devastated by this dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't need you to tell me.

—I am glad to hear Senator Collins say that he does not think I can tell him anything about that. But I hope that Senator Collins is urging the Government to take a more constructive approach than it has adopted to this point and to make a more serious attempt to find a solution. As I go around Australia, I find increasing incredulity about the length of this dispute and at the failure of the major parties to seriously come to grips with the need for a settlement.

SPEECH.PARA: We find all this happening in a context of common ground that there will be a very lengthy dispute. The estimate of the airlines is that it will be over six months before they can see a return to 80 per cent of capacity. That estimate was given not by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots but by the airlines themselves. We have had a whole series of reports on the very limited nature of the services being provided. Many of the estimates that have been given in this chamber and elsewhere about the services have been proven to be absolutely false. They have been described as pie in the sky by some commentators. Others simply reserve for themselves the right to correct the claims of capacity which have been made both by the airlines and by Ministers speaking as mouthpieces for the airlines.

On 31 October we read a report of the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the pilots dispute was over. Of course, that brought a great horse laugh around Australia. But there was something less than a laugh on the faces of those people who have been directly affected. Within a day of the Prime Minister's saying that the dispute was over, Sir Peter Abeles told us that there might be a resumption of normal services by March of next year. More recently, the Australian Flight Attendants Association has told us that the idea of full services for Christmas is just a joke.

We have had confirmation after confirmation that this dispute is running on, that the capacity of the airlines to do the job that is required for Australia is not there and that for many individuals this is crushing. I was in Tasmania on Friday and Saturday. I met with people whose businesses and whose lives are being ruined by this dispute. They are completely bemused as to why the Government is not prepared to take some constructive step to try to encourage a full return to work. Over the last 24 hours I have been on the telephone with residents of the north-west of Western Australia who are suffering the most severe reduction in services available. Those people who are in businesses associated with the tourist industry are finding themselves decimated.

For example, the information which has come from Broome in the north-west of Western Australia is that accommodation capacity is down between 40 and 80 per cent-a 40 to 80 per cent downturn; hire cars are down 30 to 50 per cent; restaurants are down between 25 and 50 per cent; souvenir shops are down by up to 50 per cent; service stations are down between 10 and 25 per cent; the museum is down by 60 per cent; and so on. These are bare statistics but they reflect the destruction of an important sector of the Australian economy. They reflect a most destructive attack on the individuals who have put their life work and their life savings into this industry. Some people who have attempted a global commentary say that this will damage Australia to the tune of $3 billion-an Australia which is tumbling ever deeper into debt; an Australia, according to the figures published today, with reducing living standards and productivity. We have a situation where nothing constructive is being done.

We have speakers in this debate from the State of Queensland and from the Northern Territory. They can speak for their respective territories. But it ought to be understood by every senator in this place that in the north of Queensland, in the centre of Australia, in the north of Western Australia and in the State of Tasmania in particular, there is a total decimation of the tourist industry and there is, at the same time, an extraordinary long term blow being struck against the Australian economy. The impact on international tourism cannot be accurately measured as yet, but obviously it will be vast.

Everywhere I go I find this air of incredulity about what is going on. Everywhere I go I find the demand which has been made by the Opposition since August, that at least a testing of the possibility of a negotiated return to work on proper conditions be undertaken, picked up and examined by this Government. The most recent exposition of that I heard from Dr Brian Scott who, at a dinner held earlier this week by the Australian Manufacturing Council after he had received an award for export performance from a Minister in this Government, the Hon. Michael Duffy, presented a paper in which he talked about the things which need to be done in Australia. He talked about the imperative of this country coming to grips with internal economic reform. Let me quote what he said in that context about the dispute that we are debating here yet again in the Senate this afternoon. He raised the domestic airlines issue and he said:
It is not a dispute. In today's economic conditions it is a disgrace.

We as a country cannot afford to have it continue any longer. Why can't there be a conference of all the parties tomorrow afternoon? Why cannot a foremost jurist or independent conciliator be asked to work out a solution within seven days? I believe that if a deadline was set for next Monday to reach a solution in the interest of Australia and of all Australians, then it could be met. We simply cannot afford to have it drag on any longer.

Senator Collins will speak in this debate. He has spoken in a number of other debates. He has made the point that we should not advocate a surrender to the original unreasonable demands of the pilots. I make the point yet again that the Opposition has never believed that a surrender to the original industrial blackmail of the pilots was appropriate. The simple point that I make in the debate this afternoon is that it is common ground in respect of every commentator on this dispute, except the Ministers and the supporters of this Government, that the pilots were defeated on that demand months ago and, in fact, there is a capacity to deal with the pilots on the basis of full negotiations on all issues. I note that in earlier debates Senator Collins has conceded that in my statements-I have issued dozens during this dispute-I made the point that we do not advocate a surrender to industrial blackmail. We say that this is a classic situation where the pilots can get increased pay for productivity gains. Indeed, the contracts which have been offered by the airlines show that, because there are increases of up to 40 per cent for some pilots on the basis of the new schedules which have been put forward.

Basically there are three ways that this dispute could be dealt with. It can be dealt with by some form of effective arbitration; it can be dealt with by some form of negotiation and agreement; or it can be dealt with by toughing it out. The Government has chosen to support the third option. If the only alternative were surrender to an unreasonable demand that was going to do long term economic damage to Australia, I would be foremost in my support of that resistance. The point that I make is that there has been no effective arbitration provision put in place by this Government and it has left the Australian Industrial Relations Commission without authority to enforce its decisions. The Government has ignored the second constructive way out. Indeed, we say that the foremost way out is to have voluntary open negotiations between willing parties who, as employers and employees, seek to gain economic efficiency.

What we say should be done today is quite clear. We have repeated the point made previously by me since August and made by Mr Peacock on behalf of the Opposition. First, we say that the Government should direct Australian Airlines Ltd immediately to enter into discussions with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots or any other nominated agent of the pilots to test the claimed willingness to negotiate on pay, productivity, hours and conditions. We believe that such discussion should be held before an independent third party or parties to establish whether there is a basis for a prompt and orderly return to work which provides for the required productivity gains. Secondly, we believe that the Government should immediately end compensation payments to the airlines. Thirdly, we say that in the interests of increasing competition in the Australian airline system, the Government should also authorise permanent interlining with foreign airlines with them being permitted to sell seats through travel agents to provide them with greater access to domestic routes.

We say that there is absolutely nothing to lose and everything to be gained by that course being followed. The record makes it quite clear that at the same time as we have been urging a process of testing the capacity to obtain a return to work by negotiation-statements have been made from the beginning of this dispute in August through to Mr Peacock's nine-point plan put forward on behalf of the Opposition on 18 September and widely advertised in the national press a few days later-there were renewed demands through the months of September, October and November. Honourable senators will find on the public record plenty of evidence that it is not just the Opposition which believes that that is a course which is open to the Government and, indeed, open to the airlines. Michael Stutchbury, writing in the Australian Financial Review on 25 October, put it quite simply. He stated:
To the contrary, there is now nothing standing in the way of a quick resolution of the 10-week-old dispute apart from the stubbornness and grandstanding of the main combatants;
He continued:

The airlines, the Government, the commission and the ACTU clearly have achieved their primary and justifiable goal of defeating the pilots' original 29 per cent pay grab and preserving the wages Accord.
Instead of pay and conditions, the dispute has now degenerated into a stalemate over the federation's right to represent airline pilots.

While this Government and its supporters, including Senator Collins, are sticking by the tough it out philosophy and ignoring the possibility of a negotiated solution, the truth is that its constituents are going broke. The truth is that this country is being taken even deeper into a pit of difficulty.

We are saying that the Government was duty bound to test the offers which were made by the pilots. On 19 September, Captain McCarthy said on behalf of the pilots that they would return to work-first on a limited basis, and then full time if airlines began negotiations either directly with the Federation or through an independent arbiter. We find a similar offer being made early in October. How is that reported? It is reported that the Prime Minister crushed the pilots' bid to end the dispute. We find the pilots issuing a White Paper saying that there was a case for speedy resolution of their dispute. We find that in an appearance before a Senate committee clear statements were made by Mr McCarthy on behalf of the Federation about their preparedness to have their agreement certified in the Commission and to have it tested against the guidelines. Let me quote from what has been said within the last few days before the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute. I will quote Captain McCarthy:

When we were in the IRC on 12 September and had finally heard the day before-because we could not talk to the companies, they wouldn't talk to us-the companies' proposition that this 55 hours equals 25 per cent productivity, we withdrew our 29.47 per cent log of claims. We took our pay section out of our contract and reinstated the companies' 55 hours 25 per cent productivity.
He continued:

We were prepared to have other matters in our contracts or our awards argued or negotiated or conciliated. We were prepared to have the President of the Industrial Relations Commission chair that conciliation. We were also prepared to waive our right to have him as an arbitrator, bearing in mind he had conciliated. In other words, we were saying yes to that, so I believe our previous award and the 55 hours pay and productivity are all within the system. We did not have a problem. Our only problem was the companies would never explain what they wanted. They said there was no point talking to them and all we wanted to do was to sit down and discuss it.

If I have to, I will say again that we did not and do not support the original demand. But we ask: Why is it that this Government is totally unprepared to see any direct negotiations with the people who still appear to represent the bulk of those who could give safe and immediate air services to this country and relieve the great economic damage which is being done?

The problem with this whole dispute is that the Government has given the wrong lead and sent all of the wrong signals. We have talked about that over and over again in this place. The Prime Minister's destructive, incendiary role in this dispute is widely understood in the community. We have had him on Perth radio last Friday, mealy-mouthed, trying to get out of the fact that there was a damages claim against the pilots. We all know that on 20 August-the Sunday before the Industrial Relations Commission hearing-the Prime Minister gave his unequivocal support to the imposition of heavy penalties on the pilots. We all know that. I will not give the full quote again because we know that he gave unequivocal support to those penalties. We know that a day later he declared war. He said, `You go out, boys, and it is war. It is a different game'. This is the Prime Minister who said that the pilots were like bus drivers. I am not quite sure whether he was trying to criticise bus drivers or just to denigrate the pilots, but clearly his abusive approach was part of cementing this dispute.

A little later down the track we find the Prime Minister saying that his credibility is on the line and that he should give up his job; he would not deserve to be Prime Minister if he could not deal with this matter. Well, he has not dealt with this matter. The matter is totally unsatisfactory. The dispute is one which is standing to run through to next year to the great destruction of this country and its economy. I say that the Prime Minister should heed his own words and should get out of his office as Prime Minister. We have had nothing but intemperate outbursts from him. We have had nothing but the wrong direction being transmitted to all of the participants in this dispute.

I remind honourable senators opposite that we had one of their number debating us on the Thursday before the Sunday of the Prime Minister's pronouncement of his total support of legal proceedings against the pilots. We were being given the Labor line that that was the worst thing that would exacerbate this dispute. I just remind honourable senators opposite of how much forbearance was shown by the Mudginberri disputants and the Dollar Sweets disputants before there was a leap into the common law remedies which made those disputes so famous and provided some indication that there are limits to industrial action in this country.

We have had the declaration of war. We have had the abuse. We have had the leap into war footing before peace negotiations had been explored. We have had the refusal to acknowledge any role for the Federation. We have had the refusal to move when the original claim was defeated. I say again that it was clear within weeks of this dispute commencing that the pilots would not succeed in their dispute. We find the putting of the presentation of the accord ahead of all other national objectives and interests. We find the Prime Minister promising selective compensation and paying taxpayers' money in selective compensation to the airlines-again a disincentive to a realistic approach being taken to the settlement of this dispute. We find gross misinformation. We do not know whether the Government has been careless or dishonest. Senator Collins will no doubt have his catalogue of what he sees as misinformation coming from the pilots. But the truth of the matter is that Ministers in this place have had to correct their statements and have given conflicting statements because there has been a war of misinformation and confusion in this dispute.

We saw the destruction of the Federation being given primacy as a Government objective. The Opposition says that the prime objective should be to get a settlement of this dispute on proper terms. We believe that the pilots, having said again and again that they will negotiate all conditions through the Federation, should be put to the test on that. We believe that an early return to work could be negotiated. We believe that this is a situation in which the suffering which is being imposed on so many people could be ameliorated, and we believe that the Government has the blood of the tourist industry on its hands through the mismanagement of this dispute. We say that it is time that the Government washed some of this blood off its hands and encouraged constructive negotiations in this dispute. I believe that the Government should analyse the contribution that it has made to this dispute and should ensure that it does something to minimise the enormous damage which it has already caused to so many individuals and to our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear Senator Chaney say that he has been travelling about the electorate having people speak to him about the pilots dispute. I am delighted to hear that one of us has been able to do that. This morning I was working out that on 22 December, which is when we finish this current sitting period, I will have been out of my electorate for 14 out of 16 weeks; like every other senator who has committee commitments as well as the Senate sitting commitments, I will have been 14 weeks in Canberra, with two weeks in the electorate. I am delighted to hear that Senator Chaney at least can get about. What particularly intrigued me about what Senator Chaney said was that people were constantly asking him what has been happening. It is absolutely clear from what he has just said that Senator Chaney is not in a position to tell them.

SPEECH.PARA: The quite ridiculous impression has been created by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and picked up and run by this Opposition that the AFAP, and all the parties involved in this horrendous dispute, have not had endless opportunities to do precisely what Senator Chaney wants people to do: to sit down and to negotiate. The lie to that was given again and again in evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute, to which Senator Chaney has just referred. He has certainly been very selective in his reading of the transcript of evidence before that Committee. One other part of the transcript which I would like to refer Senator Chaney to sets out the very positive statements by the representatives of the peak bodies representing the tourism industry of Australia, which is suffering so badly, that the pilots' so-called offer to go back to work until Christmas, and then to put everything back on the boil after Christmas, is not an offer at all but a nonsense. It was the tourist industry and the representatives of the peak bodies of the organisations that are bleeding to death that asserted that to the Senate Committee. Senator Chaney, like Chamberlain coming back from Munich, waved around the piece of paper that the Federation waved around in front of our Committee. It is relevant to question the context in which they waved it around. Senator Chaney is perfectly correct when he says--
Senator Schacht interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will talk about conflicting statements. Just look at a few of these. Senator Chaney said:

SPEECH.PARA: Arbitration was a course of action that could have been used to resolve this dispute.

Correct. But why did it not succeed? Because the Government has not armed the Commission with the teeth it needs, Senator Chaney said, to give that arbitration. Senator Lewis is nodding in agreement. Of course, that is Senator Chaney's position. He is reported as saying it in the Australian newspaper on 1 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said it. I said it again today.

—Why does Senator Chaney not save his interjections for when I am disagreeing with him rather than when I am agreeing with him? I say again, for the second time: I agree with that. I have never been known for my dulcet tones. I thought that Opposition senators could hear me fairly clearly. On 1 November, in the Australian, Senator Chaney is quoted as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: According to Opposition Industrial Relations spokesman Senator Fred Chaney, during the first few years of a Peacock Government, the centralised wage system would rule.
Of course, that is a stark comparison with what Mr Peacock said, but nevertheless there it is. The article continues:
The Industrial Relations Commission would set wages for the majority of Australia's workers and-after being given new teeth to enforce compliance-would be stronger under a Coalition government.

Senator Lewis is nodding in agreement again. In other words, we have a picture drawn by the Opposition of a stronger Industrial Relations Commission able to enforce compliance with agreements made under it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—That is right. What did the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, say about the same issue? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why should the pilots feel bound by an agreement cooked up between Keating, Kelty and rubber stamped by the Commission? They had no say in negotiating the accord with the Government.
Once again, there is the so-called position of the Opposition. One shadow Minister says one thing and another prominent shadow Minister says exactly the reverse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis is not nodding now.

—No, Senator Lewis is not nodding now. Let us turn to the contribution that the Opposition might make to the industrial relations chaos that will so surely ensue if it takes government. In a document entitled A Federal Coalition Government-the First 12 Months-an interesting 12 months it would be-Senator Chaney delivered a speech to the Industrial Relations Research Centre symposium in Sydney and said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not surprising that the changes we will be pursuing next year are very close in shape to those that John Fahey has outlined for New South Wales.

Indeed they are. Let us have a look at what the reaction has been to this wonderful initiative in industrial relations-the John Fahey proposal in New South Wales that Senator Chaney says the Opposition's industrial relations policy is modelled on. Indeed it is. Another article with the headline, `Enterprise Tax Bill Won't Work Say Bosses and Unions' states:

Representatives of the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Australian Chamber of Manufacturers and the Employers Federation of New South Wales told Mr Fahey on Wednesday that the Bill would cause a wages explosion.
This is precisely what the Government has been saying about this idiot proposal of the Opposition. The article goes on to say:
They said that once workers moved outside the centralised wage fixing system and struck individual work agreements between an employer and a group of workers, only the militant unions would win.

Of course, that is a fact and it points out the absurdity of the Opposition's approach to negotiating something like this in its industrial relations regime. What the Opposition has not identified and the question that has never been answered in this debate is: With this combination of a rigid teeth-infested centralised system of wage fixation in association with a collective bargaining system-and how we have the two together I do not know-how do we determine who opts in and who opts out?

TALK.START.PARA: —They determine it.
—Ah, at last. Senator Chaney, by interjection, has just said that they--
—It is in the policy.

—I have read the policy. Senator Chaney has just said that they decide who stays in and who opts out. Indeed, that then determines who will win under the system. It is the militant unions. There is no more militant union in this country, nor has there been for the last 30 years, than the AFAP.

SPEECH.PARA: This then gets down to the point I am making. I am glad that Senator Chaney is making my points for me. Senator Chaney has said that it is up to the parties to opt out of the system if the parties make that decision. At the same time we are debating a motion in this Parliament that asks the Government to direct, not encourage, persuade or plead with, only one of the parties-and there are numerous parties in this dispute-to vary its negotiating stance; to remove the condition that it has placed to operate within the central wage fixing system; and to cut off its legs so that the AFAP, this militant union, will be able to dictate the negotiations on its own terms. Do honourable senators opposite call those negotiations?

I have to say that one good thing about the motion which is before us today is that it makes transparent just what a hypocritical Opposition this is in terms of this pilots dispute. The timing of this motion is a disgrace. Senator Chaney talked about people being given an opportunity to meet together. They will have the opportunity, as Senator Chaney knows, at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC). The Industrial Relations Commission has bent over backwards, as the transcript shows. To the best of my knowledge it has offered at least four olive branches to the AFAP. Tomorrow it will offer the fifth. The Industrial Relations Commission bent over backwards again last week, having set a deadline and, at the request of the AFAP, it extended by another week to allow that union to organise itself. But to bring this debate on and to move this motion-and I hope it will not be carried-does not assist in the resolution of this dispute one iota. The Opposition has brought on this motion less than 24 hours before the IRC is to consider this dispute once again and offer the fifth olive branch to the AFAP tomorrow afternoon.

The timing of this motion is transparent; it is hypocritical and opportunistic in the extreme. The suggestion that the Government should instruct one of the parties in this dispute to a given course of action, and none of the others, is at variance with the Opposition's general principles that government business enterprises should be free of political interference; and it contradicts the Opposition's own policy of keeping the Government out of individual industrial disputes. Senator Chaney has just said, `The parties opt out of the system'. Under this proposal, of course, the Government will then chase them. This is Stalinist stuff, not collective bargaining. It would unilaterally undermine the position of other employers in this dispute and it would cut across the proceedings that are currently under way in the most rational forum, I do not hesitate to say, for negotiating industrial agreements in this country, that is, the Industrial Relations Commission-I might add that the Opposition and Senator Chaney have supported that proposition-and it would also cut across all of the outstanding matters that are currently before the Victorian Supreme Court. In other words, it is an irresponsible and criminal suggestion to make to this Parliament.

I advise honourable senators, as they may not know this, that it would also undermine the efforts of the non-AFAP pilots to set up their own enterprise bargaining units by letting the AFAP back into the system under its own terms. It is not entirely clear what would happen if such an ultimatum were issued by the Government, as the Opposition wants it to be; nor is it clear from the Opposition's motion what the parties would be negotiating about once they got together. For example, what would the Opposition propose for the non-AFAP pilots who have indicated that they have no intention of being covered by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots? Would the Opposition wash its hands of any agreement which got the planes straight back into the air but denied non-AFAP pilots the right to be represented by an association of their choice? I can assure the Senate that that is going on at this very moment and the AFAP has no-one to blame for that situation but itself.

I would like to have a look briefly, because it deserves to be looked at, at the Supreme Court decision in this case. I am very familiar with the Mudginberri dispute. I was Leader of the Australian Labor Party in the Northern Territory when it occurred and I know what happened in that dispute. I think I could be forgiven for saying that it is my view that the one thing that the famous Mudginberri dispute, the Dollar Sweets dispute and this dispute have in common is that all the unions associated with each of these disputes have blundered badly in the industrial relations strategy and tactics that they have employed.

There are strong arguments for not getting too carried away, as the Opposition has been carried away, by this decision in the Supreme Court. I notice that certainly some people in the Australian Council of Trade Unions are not getting carried away with it. The facts are that this matter is still before the court and may be subject to appeal. The level of damages has not yet been set and we cannot assume that the full $10m claim will be awarded. I have noted that it has been generally agreed by all commentators, including Mr Michael Kroger on the PM program of 23 November, that the case breaks little new ground. It does not. By any standards, the action of the pilots is so extreme, and this dispute in terms of its duration so untypical, that it is hard to envisage any parallels arising out of this dispute that can be applied to other disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—I did. Of course, the court's decision has not resolved the fundamental differences between the parties. I have said in this Parliament before that litigation is the worst way in which to handle this dispute or any other dispute between anyone else in this country on any issue. We try to keep these disputes out of the courts if we can. The use of common law has not got the planes back into the air. I said in this House six or eight weeks ago-and the Hansard will show this-that it would not.
—Why did the Prime Minister advocate it?

—Despite the interjections of honourable senators opposite, the Labor movement has always asserted that legal action of this sort is of limited value-which is what the Government said-and a blunt instrument at the best of times. Last Thursday's decision and the reaction to it confirm the value of a consensual approach to industrial relations which is supported by this Government through the accord. The cost to industrial parties and to the public at large of going outside the accepted rules-that is, outside the system-is the only lesson we can safely draw from the decision handed down by the court last Thursday.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that pilots currently employed by the existing operators-and there are large numbers of them-no longer wish to be represented by the AFAP. Mr McMahon, in response to a question from me the other day before the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots Dispute confirmed a story that I had heard-I have since had it confirmed by Australian airlines-that active negotiations and discussions are going on among the hundreds of pilots who are currently employed by both airlines to form their own industrial association. I am told that East-West Airlines Ltd has already done it, as has the Interstate Parcel Express Co. (IPEC). It has been done in those cases on an informal basis out of sheer convenience. The employers need someone to talk to; they do not want to talk to their entire pilot body.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following our industrial relations policy.

—It is nothing of the sort. They are currently doing it. We also know that the Industrial Relations Commission has given the AFAP until 4 o'clock tomorrow to indicate whether it wishes to become party to any or all of the draft awards handed down by Commissioner Paine on 20 November. We also know that those currently employed by the airline operators are, at least at this stage informally, forming themselves into some sort of association or unit.
—That is our policy. We think they should agree to it.

—It is also my information-although I do not know whether it is correct-that 20 pilots employed by IPEC have written to Commissioner Paine. I stress that there are 20 of them. IPEC has now employed all the pilots it wants to employ. It used to employ 40; it now needs only 20. I understand-but I could be wrong-that the pilots have written to Commissioner Paine saying that they do not want a bar of the AFAP. That will be interesting in terms of a conference taking place before the Commission, perhaps on Monday.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no constitutional or legal impediment to these associations of employees seeking to become parties to those draft awards-or seeking other enterprise agreements with the airlines-under the existing regime and not, I say to Senator Chaney, under the Opposition's policy. Under the new provisions contained in the Industrial Relations Act, sections 118 and 196, the IRC has a wide discretionary power to decide whether it wishes to register such associations. Given that the AFAP currently has no members employed under the relevant awards, it is not unlikely, in my view, that the Commission would register new enterprise unions, even those with fewer than 1,000 members, and give them coverage of employees to the full or partial exclusion of the AFAP. I say this with no great joy: the AFAP has done what the article in the Australian Aviation magazine said in November that it had done. I quote from both the opening and closing paragraphs of this excellently researched article. The first paragraph states:

The latter half of calendar year 1989 will go down in Australian history as the period when the nation's single strongest and most successful union, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, literally committed industrial suicide.
The final paragraph of the article states:
Like a fight to the death there has been no winners in this most mindless and ill conceived dispute.
So strongly supported by the Opposition, I might add. It continues:

The once proud Australian air transportation system and the booming tourism industry that lived beside it lies in ruins as do the future of many of its principal players. That the AFAP could misjudge a tactical situation in so gross a manner is something that will go down in industrial relations history as being as poorly thought out as Hitler's attack on Russia in 1941. Indeed, for all concerned the results will be the same.

I, as do, I am sure, other responsible members of this chamber, plead with the AFAP, rather than this Senate passing this idiot motion, which will only exacerbate the dispute by cutting the ground out from only one of the parties in the dispute, to take the last opportunity that is being offered to go before the IRC tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock and agree to the three reasonable conditions that have been laid upon it-that is, to remove, as Senator Chaney wants removed, the barrier and intimidation placed on recruiting pilots for the airlines and to indicate that it will operate within the system and will abide by the decisions of the Commission. They are hardly onerous requests. If the pilots do that they may salvage their union, but that is about all they will salvage at this stage.

It is worth while having a look at what the AFAP has cost its members. It has so far cost its members their jobs, their seniority, their conditions of employment built up over the last 30 years, the redundancy payments they would have received under a restructured industry, an average salary loss of $30,000 and the respect of their fellow Australians and, I suggest, if they do not take this last chance, offered to them tomorrow afternoon, their union as well. It is almost impossible to conceive that, if the AFAP had gone into the IRC on day one and had not so drastically misjudged this dispute, its members would now have their jobs and existing conditions, all of the conditions built up over the last 30 years, their seniority, their bidding system, perhaps even the Ford LTDs they demanded as part of their so-called negotiations and, at the same time, a minimum in my view, of a 12 per cent increase in their salaries with a very good chance of 15 per cent. When we compare that position with the position I have just outlined, we can see that the actions of the AFAP are unbelievable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to this debate will be brief. It is the fifth occasion on which we have risen to discuss matters of public importance or urgency in relation to this issue, and I think the position of the Australian Democrats has been made perfectly clear to the Senate. We will not be supporting this urgency motion, for reasons which I will briefly state. I begin by giving the Senate an assurance that Senator Collins and I have not spoken about the positions and arguments we were going to advance in relation to this proposition. It happens to be a coincidence that I am about to make quite a number of the points that he has very forcefully presented in the last 15 minutes. Perhaps that is an indication that the points of rebuttal in relation to this urgency motion were so patently obvious that two independent people sitting separately came up with many of the same points.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, this dispute is very confusing. It is one which has evoked very divergent reactions. Clearly, it has become one of the most divisive issues that have confronted the Australian community in recent decades. Even the informed opinion about the issue is patently divided. By sheer coincidence about 15 minutes before I came in here the latest issue of the IPA Review crossed my desk. Most know that the IPA Review is produced by the Institute of Public Affairs. It is clearly stated on the cover that it is Australia's journal of free enterprise opinion. Therefore, its position is fairly obviously stated. On page 17 of the current issue there is a very interesting table which is an attempt to rationalise, if you like, the informed opinion in the Australian community about the pilots dispute. It states the position of various leading metropolitan dailies and the leading commentators. It cites them as supporting the accord, which is the Government's position, as being neutral, or as opposing the accord, which is the Opposition's position. It shows a scattering of opinion-and we are talking about informed opinion-of people such as Padriac McGuinness, John Slee, Paul Kelly, Laurie Oakes, Peter Costigan, Mike Taylor, Kenneth Davidson, Geoff Kitney, Bruce Jones, Max Walsh and John Wright, the leading commentators of the leading metropolitan dailies. In fact, the score comes out that about a third take one position, a third take the other, and a third admit to being neutral. Those who are in both positions admit to being confused about the nature of the issue. It is not a clear-cut issue. Senator Chaney began his delivery as he has every time he has addressed this issue, by stating essentially the same proposition, that the position to be taken is clear-cut, when quite obviously it is not. The issue is one of the most confused, confusing and divisive and evokes the most divergent opinion we have seen recently.

I would like to read the proposition before us because it suggests considerable bias. I do not suppose that that is surprising, invalid or unacceptable. We are debating as a matter of urgency the proposition:
In the interests of an early end to the devastating pilots' dispute-
there would certainly be no disagreement that we need an early end to it or that it is devastating-
the need for the Government to instruct-
and that is a key word-
Australian Airlines-
that is also significant because it is selective and exclusive to one of the two airlines-
to open discussions with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to test the sincerity of the AFAP's claimed willingness to negotiate on pay, productivity, hours and conditions.

The suggestion clearly is that only one party should be challenged about its willingness and sincerity and that only one airline should be instructed to pursue these questions of negotiation, sincerity and willingness.

The Australian Democrats believe-and obviously every Australian would agree-that this dispute has been absolutely devastating. However, unlike the Opposition, which chooses to blame the Government totally for this devastating dispute, and unlike the Government, which chooses to blame, essentially, the pilots for this devastating dispute, the Australian Democrats believe that no party to the dispute is without blame. In that respect the dispute is clearly different from many of the disputes which Australians are asked to ponder.

There is no party to this dispute which is without blame. The Government declared war on the pilots at the beginning of the dispute. Quite clearly, in one respect it was unwise in taking such a strong position. Perhaps it was unwise in its choice of words but in choice of strategy I do not believe that the Government was unwise. There was an enormous amount at stake. Virtually the future of the Australian economy in the immediate short term was at stake. We will pay the price in the short term. The outcome will be and is the devastation in the short term of the Australian economy. The Government was right to recognise that. It was right to take a strong stand. Perhaps it was wrong in its choice of words. Perhaps the Prime Minister's attitude and manner were unfortunate in some respects, for example, in his declaration of war at the beginning of the dispute.

The airlines, especially Ansett, have used the dispute as an excuse to restructure their organisations at minimum cost and inconvenience to themselves in terms of public scrutiny and actions in anticipation of deregulation. Quite clearly Sir Peter Abeles and Ansett are going to be the winners in this dispute. The ultimate winner will be Sir Peter Abeles.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the AFAP has handed its members to it on a plate.

—It has handed much to Ansett on a plate. The pilots started by saying that they would negotiate, but not within the system, not before the Industrial Relations Commission and not concerning the size of their wage rise. That was not an offer to negotiate at all. So when Senator Chaney said that there were three possible approaches to resolving the dispute-arbitration, negotiation and toughing it out-and cited that the Government took the wrong strategy by attempting to tough it out, suggesting that negotiation was the only way to go, that way to go was cut off by the pilots literally on day one. So it is not legitimate to say that there are three options open. The only option that is acceptable and that was ever acceptable in the first place is the one that is now in place. It is taking its time and it has not delivered the goods, but let us at least give it until tomorrow. I refer to the process of arbitration which is currently in place. We should not judge it at least until the next 24 hours see whether it will to some degree deliver to us.

SPEECH.PARA: No parties in this dispute are blameless. I would like to talk about the pilots' attitude. The attitude of the pilots at the beginning of this dispute was arrogant and high-handed. They assumed that they had the upper hand and were willing to throw the country into absolute chaos to achieve their demand of a 30 per cent wage rise. They were motivated by pure greed and they must have believed that they were so indispensable to the smooth running of the country that their demands would be met and that they would go back to work in a short period of time bearing the gifts and having reaped the harvest. Of course, the very opposite has occurred. Senator Collins, in the last minute of his speech, cited the extraordinarily devastating implications of the pilots having pursued that false strategy.

To a certain extent I suppose the pilots were right. The withdrawal of their services has thrown the country into economic chaos. Many small businesses have gone bankrupt. Many families have been massively disadvantaged. The lives of millions of Australians have been disrupted. The harm which this dispute has caused will continue to be felt by every one of us for a long time. So in some respects the pilots did have power, but they abused it to our disadvantage and to their own devastating disadvantage. However, we have now gone a long time without the services of these pilots. Surprisingly, we are even beginning to adapt to it.

In what extraordinary ways we have adapted to this imposition on us. We have called in our Royal Australian Air Force. We have devastated its morale, and tempted pilots out of the Air Force into civil pilot positions-many of them at the first available opportunity because they have had a taste of some of the rewards. But because they have not had all of them their morale has been dramatically affected. We have the ironic position of having had half the pilots exit from the existing system anyway. If one does a count now, one finds that half of them are overseas.

Another extraordinary irony was that just a matter of about three or four months ago I was in Yugoslavia with the President of the Senate and the Yugoslavs put a plea to us. `For heaven's sake, let us have one more flight per week into Australia' they said. This was JAT. What an extraordinary irony it is that now, when I and other Australians go out to get a domestic flight from Sydney to Adelaide, we find that Yugoslav Airlines is virtually our domestic airline. One could go on and on about the outcomes of this dispute.

Many business people have discovered that they can conduct most of their affairs just as easily over the phone, with the use of information and communications technology, just as efficiently and far cheaper than by turning up in person. It will be a long time before businesses go back to their former levels of airline bookings. That might be seen as one of the few pluses which have come out of the process. The pilots have certainly discovered that they are not as indispensable as they had thought.

Probably the most significant point to be made here is that the timing of this motion is desperately bad. It can only be borne out of opportunism-three days before a State election and with two broadcast days left. The Opposition grabs at this dispute to gain a few cheap political points in the time that is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost 4 o'clock. It is exactly 24 hours before the IRC is going to meet.

—Indeed. We have lost count of the number of times the Opposition has brought this proposition forward in the form of an urgency motion. It is ironic and perhaps extremely unfortunate that the Industrial Relations Commission has given the Australian Federation of Air Pilots the opportunity to rejoin the industrial award system tomorrow. An irascible union that has proven itself to be temperamental now finds itself being prodded and abused by a debate, an unnecessary debate in our view, in the Senate less than 24 hours before the processes of arbitration, hopefully, come to fruition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins has already cited the irony of the fact that here we have the Opposition advancing a strategy to resolve this dispute which is in complete contradiction to the principles which underlie-the Opposition says-its industrial relations policy. In other words, Opposition members say they are not centralists, that they are decentralists, yet here they are advocating centralism in its most extreme form. In fact, Senator Collins referred to it as virtually neo-Stalinism. I have long since stopped expecting logic in debate on this particular issue. Yet I suppose it is not surprising that when we look into the proposition being advanced here today, three days before the State election, cheap opportunism being its motive, we should not look for logic because there is not any there. In fact, there are profound contradictions. Frankly, I intended to be much briefer in my contribution to this debate because the Australian Democrats simply refuse to identify with this opportunism and with the contradictions which are fundamental to the argument that Senator Chaney has advanced today. Therefore, the Australian Democrats will be opposing this urgency motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in speaking to this motion which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

In the interests of an early end to the devastating pilots' dispute, the need for the Government to instruct Australian Airlines to open discussions with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to test the sincerity of the AFAP's claimed willingness to negotiate on pay, productivity, hours and conditions.

We are involved in what is now certainly the longest major dispute that this country has ever suffered. It is certainly the most expensive and the true cost of it will not be known for many years; indeed, the cost will not be borne for many years, but it runs into billions of dollars. It is a dispute as vicious as any in our turbulent history, and sadly there is no end in sight, given the Government's policies. This is a dispute that never should have happened. It should have been resolved months ago. Indeed, there have been many opportunities for it to be resolved.

The reason why it has not been resolved is the fault of the Federal Government. Initially the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) bought into the fight in a most inflammatory way when he had no business at all to be involved. We then had a generous compensation scheme, where the floodgates for taxpayers' funds were opened to the airlines, giving them an incentive to keep on with the dispute and not resolve it. Given those circumstances, there is no way that it is going to be resolved. The Government could have forced the parties to negotiate, because it is very clear that the national interest is involved. Instead, the Government has conspired to prevent any meetings taking place between the airline management and the Australian Federation of Airline Pilots.

I listened with great interest to the contribution made by the previous speaker, Senator McLean. I suggest to him that if this matter does go to arbitration there will not be any speedy resolution. This is a protracted matter. I say quite unequivocally that the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC) would welcome support from the Senate for this motion, because negotiations will certainly be involved in settling the dispute. It will not be settled just by a straight directive from the IRC.

The Opposition has made the point that the dispute cannot be resolved without discussion. If one believes that discussion is not needed, one is implying that the airlines can rebuild with new recruits, but that is palpably untrue. They have involved themselves in a massive recruiting campaign overseas, spending millions of dollars, and it has been a total failure. They are struggling along with numbers that are far below what they require even to run the meagre services that are being offered to the Australian public at the present time. In fact, well over half the aircraft flying and probably 60 or 70 per cent of the crews available to fly in Australia today are from overseas. That is a measure, 14 weeks later, of how effective the airlines have been in the rebuilding process. So, one is driven inexorably to the proposition that there has got to be discussion with the Federation to reconstitute the airline system in Australia.

When the history of this dispute is written, the Liberal Party and National Party will be seen to have followed the correct approach. Over 12 weeks ago the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was suggesting the proposition that is embodied in this motion today. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), the shadow Minister for tourism, aviation and sport in the House of Representatives, Senator Chaney, and many other of us right from the outset have been calling for reason and negotiation to take place so that this crippling dispute can be resolved. What have we got from the Government? Not even a hearing-just criticism for the creative moves that we have tried to make in the national interests.

I do not propose to dwell very long on the origins of this strike. It is really not terribly important, except that we must look at the origins so that we can make sure that the dreadful mistake that has been made over this dispute does not occur again ever in our lives. As I have said on many occasions, I believe that the pilots were very badly advised at the outset. I think they were wrong to have gone about the matter in the way they did, and it is reasonable that they should suffer some censure for what they have done. But to propose that they be treated as non-persons, that the union not be recognised, and to have them face total annihilation as a professional body is absolutely unreasonable and it does not help anyone.

On the other side, clearly, the airlines were spoiling for a fight. There is a very long list of management grievances that they have against the pilots. If I may be so bold as to say so, many of the problems that we face today arise from poor management decisions in the past, weak management decisions, decisions that simply were not thought through. A number of senior people in the airlines have admitted that to me privately. Let us not lay the blame all on one side. We are in a position today where the airlines simply will not negotiate. We have the pilots who are ready to negotiate.

I want to take a few minutes in this debate to read what has been put on the public record through the current Senate Select Committee into Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute. The President of the Federation said on Tuesday, 21 November-and I read from the Hansard:
At the beginning of this dispute we said to the companies that we were quite prepared to have our agreement certified in the Commission and to have it tested against the guidelines.
That was right at the outset. They were quite prepared to have it tested against the wage guidelines. He continued:

When we were in the IRC on 12 September and had finally heard the day before-because we could not talk to the companies, they would not talk to us-companies' proposition that this 55 hours equals 25 per cent productivity, we withdrew our 29.47 per cent log of claims. We took our pay section out of our contract and reinserted the companies' 55 hours, 25 per cent productivity. Because our old award was under the system, the 55 hours, 25 per cent productivity was covered by the guidelines, or so it was agreed by the companies and the Commission, and we said what we wanted to do was then have that as a new log of claims. We were prepared to have other matters in our contracts or our awards argued or negotiated or conciliated.

In other words, the pilots federation, by 12 September, was prepared to negotiate on any terms and it could find no-one to talk to it. It goes on and on. The Chairman of the Select Committee, Senator Cooney, said on two occasions:
You say at all times you have been willing to go to conciliation under the auspices of the Industrial Relations Commission. If that failed were you then willing to go to arbitration?
Captain McCarthy replied:
That is what we said on 12 September when we withdrew our log, put in our old award but took out the pay section and put in the companies' figures.
Again, the Chairman came back to him for confirmation, and I quote:

CHAIRMAN-When we come to writing the report we can say that at all times the Federation has been willing to go to conciliation under the Industrial Relations Act and, if that did not succeed, then to proceed to arbitration under the Act.
Captain McCarthy-Yes, but as a starting point we believed that we wanted to start with our previous award, not one that was a take it or leave it, non-negotiable private contract handed down.

That is the position of the pilots federation. We are not passing judgment on whether that is a true or false position. We are saying that, for goodness sake, let us have the commonsense to negotiate with the pilots and test it. The way to test it, as Senator Chaney has suggested, is by the Government directing its own company, the company that we all own, Australian Airlines Ltd, to enter into negotiations to see whether the dispute can be solved. Clearly, anyone with a modicum of commonsense can see the wisdom in that. The alternative that we are left with is that the Labor Party wants to continue with the dreadful economic morass that we are in. I have dealt with the matter of the wage guidelines. On Captain McCarthy's record, it was never an issue with him.

The central point I would make about the guidelines is that they are a creation of the Hawke Government. They have failed, Mr Deputy President. The proof that they have failed is the rampant inflation, the declining productivity, the intolerable interest rates and the huge and escalating overseas debt that we have today. One of the reasons the dispute has not been resolved is the central involvement of the Prime Minister. My own view-and I am happy to give this advice to the Prime Minister without charge-is that he should have held the high ground and been detached and objective about the matter. Instead, this man, whose reputation was built on his negotiating skills, has turned out to be a total failure. In fact, he even argues now that the dispute does not exist.

Like you, Mr Deputy President, I have a deep interest in defence. I spend a lot of time reading biographies of generals and military histories. It is a well recognised psychopathological state in failed generals that, when they are looking at unmitigated disasters that they have brought about themselves, they cannot recognise the dimension and magnitude of them. General Percival displayed in Singapore the syndrome peculiar to failed generals who are faced with an enormous disaster that their faulty planning has brought about. They refuse to recognise reality. Tragically, we are seeing today precisely the same psychopathology in the Prime Minister when he says that there is no dispute.

At the moment, the airline companies simply will not negotiate. Between the four of them they must be losing millions of dollars a day. I would estimate that the major airlines are losing more than $1m a day each. But this loss has been cushioned for them enormously by the subsidies they are getting. This Labor Government, with its strike breaking by allowing the use of overseas labour and the military forces, is paying a huge amount in subsidies to the airlines. So the airlines keep operating. They get compensation for not standing people down. They have received about $58m in subsidy from the Services in terms of the provision below cost of service aircraft. Also, Civil Aviation Authority and Federal Airports Corporation charges have been waived. This is not a matter of $10m or $20m, as Mr Keating says: they are the beneficiaries of hundreds of millions. We must cope with the absolutely enormous cost of this to the Australian public.

Again, I return to the point of view of the airlines. The airlines are doing nothing to recognise this national loss. We hear a great deal about their losses. But there is not a word of compassion from them about the travelling public of Australia or about the tourist industry, which is being reduced to bankruptcy because the airlines will not negotiate. All we get from the airlines are false statements and lies about schedules and pilot recruitment. In addition, there are all the vicious things that have occurred endlessly, such as the cancellation of advance purchase excursion fares and the abrogation of contracts.

Regrettably I do not have time to go too far into those matters this afternoon but I will say something about the detailed effects of this dispute on my own State because it is there that it pinches. Queensland is suffering more as a consequence of the dispute than any other State. It has already lost over $100m. Of course, the Prime Minister is so sensitive to the issue that he simply will not come into Queensland and the Queensland Labor Party does not want to see him there. He sneaked into Mount Isa-his sole visit during the current campaign in Queensland-and even then there was a riot. The union movement in Mount Isa bailed him up because its members simply cannot move out of that very isolated town. The Opposition Leader, Mr Goss, was challenged by the Mount Isa Trades and Labor Council representative and forced to admit that he supported the divisive and costly actions of the Prime Minister during the dispute. Since then, we have not had a word on the matter from Mr Goss, Senator Burns, Senator Reynolds, Mr Gayler or Mr Lindsay-the very people in the northern part of Queensland who owe so much to the people whose welfare they are looking after. What do they do? They go into the Caucus and put up their hands in support of $38m or $60m-whatever it is-for Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, a profitable American company. But there is not one red cent for the people in their own State in the tourist industry who are bleeding to death.

The time has long past for talking about this matter. The Government has the power, as it has always had, to show leadership, to show that it is concerned about the welfare of this great country. It must arrest this devastating strike. We will lose nothing at all by testing the bona fides of the pilots federation. This is not something that happened yesterday. We have on public record that, from 12 September-nearly three months ago-the Federation said that it was prepared to negotiate on all elements of the contract. For goodness sake, let us test that and work towards resolving this dispute instead of defending some archaic failed economic policies and defence of unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to speak to the motion and not wander all over the place as some other senators have. Senator Chaney made a couple of points that I would like to answer. He spoke about the need to return to normal. I read an article in the press recently which said that the airlines collectively had 2,000 empty seats and would have to do a lot of work to fill them. It is clearly understood that, as the dispute has progressed, considerably fewer people are flying or may fly when the dispute is settled. Therefore, I do not think there is such a really drastic problem now for people in the community and in tourism although, admittedly, there was a problem earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney talked about the question of testing the negotiating capacity to reach a solution. As a step towards that, he said the Government should instruct Australian Airlines Ltd to enter into those sorts of negotiations. The fact is that the pilots have shown that they have no sincerity in terms of negotiating, and I will show that shortly by quoting some of what they have said. Senator MacGibbon quoted a statement that the airline pilots were quite prepared to negotiate a registered agreement and have it tested against the guidelines. Let us look at what has actually happened. Initially, I want to make three vital points. First, the campaign by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) for a 30 per cent increase to their average salary of $78,000 was planned and coldly calculated for at least six months. Secondly, the AFAP remains a registered organisation under the Industrial Relations Act and is free to represent its members' views to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the same way as any other union. I understand that this will be done tomorrow. Thirdly, the single goal for the Federal Government has been to ensure that air services are restored as quickly as possible. Those three points are clear for everyone to see.

When one looks at this matter, one finds that, right from the beginning, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) urged the pilots to work within the guidelines and accept responsibility for the interests of the community in general. He was at pains to point out the way in which the trade union movement had done that collectively. At that time, the Australian Council of Trade Unions indicated support and, from a point of view of experience and wisdom, said that there was provision for more than 6 per cent within the guidelines. Based on my knowledge of the way the Commission works and the economic arguments that could be advanced in terms of changes, I am thoroughly convinced that that is clear and unequivocal.

Next, I want to look at the Opposition and its attitude and test its sincerity to see whether it is being hypocritical. On 28 November a matter of public importance was raised in the House of Representatives by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). He spoke about the importance of maintaining common law remedies to guard against unjustified industrial action, particularly in view of the Government's contradictory and confusing approach to industrial relations.
