The past 30 or 40 years of rule by the Liberal and National parties was an era of confrontation and penalties on unions. The coalition encouraged employers not to negotiate. When unions were called before the Commission, whether by way of a compulsory conference or some legal matter to be argued, at all times the question asked was: `Are you in dispute?'. It was not: `Why are you in dispute? Do you have a valid reason to be in dispute? Is it a safety issue? Are lives endangered?'. None of those questions were asked. The question was: `Are you in dispute?', and if the answer was, `Yes', then the penalties applied. It was #500 a day, which was a lot of money in those days. There was never any argument about whether one was right or wrong or how the dispute affected the community. It could be some tin-pot employer-I recall one instance, which is a typical example, of the Clyde Engineering Co. Pty Ltd which was forcing boilermakers to weld over red lead paint, which would be injurious to their health. There was no concern about whether the employees had a case; they were just ordered back to work to do it.

These are people who are telling us we should talk to people and negotiate. Although I am a very kindly person at heart, and look for the best in everyone, I am afraid I have to accuse honourable senators opposite of being absolute hypocrites. They have always accused the Leader of the Australian Labor Party, Prime Minister Hawke, of creating friction, encouraging the dispute to continue and being bloody minded. One should look at the record of Prime Minister Hawke as the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), and his record of negotiating and resolving disputes over many years-disputes that ran on for too long and which both parties wanted to settle. Admittedly, sometimes he might have got too much credit where it was not mentioned that the right time had arrived to settle these disputes, but that does not for one minute detract from his ability and skill, from that point on, in getting a solution as quickly as possible. That is his record.
What did the Prime Minister say in answer to a question in the Parliament on 28 November? He said:

Of course, the Leader of the Opposition does not want to face up to the fact that we have in this country an industrial relations system which provides a process for the resolution of industrial disputes, including strike action. This is not a country where there is no right to strike. Strikes happen around the country reasonably frequently. Under us there have been 60 per cent fewer industrial disputes than under the previous government . . .
That is the way to go-prevent disputes; do not settle them after they have happened. He went on:

The overwhelming majority of employers and trade unions use the industrial relations system sensibly and intelligently. Where there is strike action, processes are provided for the sensible resolution of those disputes.

Having had some experience over 20 years in these matters, I agree that that is absolutely true, unlike some people who want to debate these issues who have no experience at all, have been spectators all their lives and want to take cheap political points.
The Prime Minister went on to talk about the pilots going outside the system. He said:

That was done against the warnings that were given, including those by the ACTU. When the Federation decided to go outside the system which provides protection for action, including strike action, it then incurred, as it had been warned about, the processes of civil action. I repeat: no one gets any comfort from that.

So much for the accusation that he has contributed to the dispute. As I have said, even earlier on he appealed time and again to the pilots to stay within the system-that there was an opportunity there for a resolution which would give them some joy.

I suppose this is what happens when one talks to a group of people who I would not call trade unionists-not based on my experience with them. If somebody can show me one occasion when, in true trade union spirit, they defended the position of another union or the general trade union movement, then I will apologise. I cannot recall one. They certainly set out to destroy the system under which the unions collectively work.

During the period of office of this Government, under the accord, there has been a reduction in labour costs from a base measurement of 100 to 93. There was a 4 per cent wage increase which was cost neutral to employers. These things have been beneficial to the community and have cost the trade union movement reasonably dearly in the short term, but it is looking to the long term and the recovery and benefits that will accrue to its members in the community in general. The Government having got that agreement and those working arrangements whereby millions of people in the country realise that they have to accept some sacrifices, but sacrifices with equity-and that position must always be defended-a group like the pilots then says, `We will negotiate', but their dictionary says that `negotiate' means give the other people the opportunity to say yes and surrender. They do not realise, apparently-or are being dishonest-that `negotiation' means that either side has to give something and there should be some compromise.
At a press conference on 28 August the Prime Minister made these comments:

I go . . . further to say there's been no direction by Government in this matter in regard to Australian, an airline which we own. But the management of that airline has come independently to this position,

The Opposition wants to sell Australian Airlines Ltd and then, of course, the Government would have no influence at all. Because the Government owns it, the Opposition wants us more or less to say to the airline pilots, `Be our guest'. The Government has said it wants to make the airline efficient and that has occurred. There has been a much larger profit than when the airline was operating under normal circumstances. Management has created a better environment and capacity to produce profits which come back to the Treasury and go out in the form of outlays to the people of this nation. The Prime Minister went on to say:

That restraint which has been exercised by the Australian workforce generally is a restraint which has paid off over the last six years in the creation of some one and a half million jobs in the community and a level of economic activity which has enabled the creation of those jobs.

Obviously, the pilots dispute was going to create unemployment. We have been told that, and every union-if it has a conscience at all-is concerned about that. The unions do not want to see other people put out of work. What has really been the response of the airline pilots? The response has been, `Too bad. We have got our own self-interest to serve and we will take whatever action we feel fit'. They have done that and they have come unstuck in terms of moving outside the system and being penalised.

I do not accept-indeed, I strenuously oppose-the idea of using legal argument and fining people heavily or awarding costs in industrial disputes. When one goes into a dispute one loses one's income totally. Many people who are only on $250 or $300 a week cannot afford that. Then the system is used to belt them around the ears and take off them what is left. To me, that is pretty bad. One of the things that the Opposition had better understand is that when that happens, and people have nothing more to lose, they are in real trouble.

As the Opposition always does, it speaks half truths and misquotes people. When Mr Reith spoke on the matter in the House of Representatives he quoted something that Prime Minister Hawke has said, but he left a bit out. The Prime Minister is the one who is under attack and I think he is the one who deserves to be recognised for the positive approach that he makes. The Prime Minister said:
I expressed the strong wish and hope to the air pilots and their Federation that they will, on consideration, decide to stay within the system like the rest of their fellow Australian workers.

Now, if against that wish and that hope they make the decision to go outside the system then they must do so in the recognition, as I have said in the Parliament of this country, that they will have left the system which carries not only obligations to which I have been referring, but which also carries rights. Once they go outside the system, if that is their decision, which I hope they do not take, . . .
That is not somebody who wants to destroy the pilots. If I wanted to destroy them, I would encourage them and tell them to keep going-`Into the Valley of Death rode the 600'--

TALK.START.PARA: —They flew.
—They rode on horses.
—This mob is flying.

—Yes, thank you, Minister. Prime Minister Hawke has only tried to help the airline pilots all along. Admittedly, he did it for the reason that he believes that is the way to go. He did it because he has a responsibility to a lot of other people in this community.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I point out the airline pilots are not very good at history. I am afraid they went through a long period of years when they were able to win all their disputes and get wage increases and enjoy conditions far above those of the average person in the community. I do not knock that. It was an agreement between them and the airlines. Other unions were doing that at the same time to the best of their ability. Sometimes they got $20 a week and thought that Christmas had arrived and that they had really waged a good struggle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your wharfie mates.
—That is right. Senator MacGibbon does not have any mates. He should be a bit jealous about that. The wharfies are fine people--
—You wouldn't want to know them.

—I do; they are good people. They are my friends and I appreciate that. Those unions thought they were still in the position where every trade union was negotiating freely outside and inside the system, being beaten over the head and going back to work-the whole deal. They had not realised that the trade union movement had taken a different position--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday, 24 November, there was a half-page advertisement in the Australian signed by 36 prominent Australians and addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It read:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr. Hawke,
Australia has had enough.
The airlines dispute has gone on far too long.
The whole nation is hurt. Many areas, businesses, jobs and people are in real trouble.
We do not want to argue who is right or wrong.
The point now is to resolve it. To get the planes back into the air.
We ask you to call a summit meeting of the parties. Clear the slate. Start talking.
We don't even want to think of the national consequences if the dispute does not end soon.
Yours sincerely,
It was signed by Sallyanne Atkinson, on behalf of those 36 prominent Australians--

TALK.START.PARA: —She is pretty unbiased!

—They include a number of supporters of those opposite, and it would pay Senator Schacht to look at it. The Government has prolonged this dispute at great cost, particularly to the tourist industry. Immense economic damage and social disruption is being caused by this dispute. There has to be a commonsense settlement. It is possible for the benefits of higher productivity to be shared fairly between the airlines, the pilots and the consumers. Instead, we have a war of attrition. Today's sloppy comments by the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party spokesmen have been without any intellectual consistency. Let us look at the editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 24 October. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The losers, as usual, are ordinary Australians who cannot get flights when they want them, or whose air services have been cut or downgraded because of the high cost of the dispute.
The airline industry has been battered: tourism and foreign confidence in Australia has been seriously dented. And the situation is still far from normal.

The Prime Minister made this his dispute. As he was prepared to take credit for success, he must now accept his share of the blame for the present mess-and take the lead in a realistic reassessment of the most suitable way of concluding the dispute.

It is interesting to note that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) has moved quite a considerable distance from when the dispute first started, I believe 105 days ago. Whilst it certainly made an unacceptable ambit claim of some 29 per cent, it was just that-an ambit claim as part of considerations. What we now have to consider is the offer that is currently on the deck. In my mailbag in the last few days I have received the pamphlet from the AFAP-the case for a speedy resolution of the pilots dispute. The offer sets out a number of points:
* All pilots return to fly on pre-dispute conditions immediately;
* Cooling-off period;
* Return to full services for Christmas after which any matter regarding pay, productivity, pilot's hours, etc. would be negotiated;
* To facilitate harmonious relationships in the future;
* The AFAP would also accept and, believes necessary, an independent mediator to assist in talks after the cooling-off period;

* The AFAP makes this conciliatory offer in an endeavour to commence a resolution of the current airline dispute and looks forward to its acceptance by the people of Australia, the Government and the Companies.

That is the offer that is currently before the Prime Minister and the Government for consideration. What have we had? Today we had a contribution by Senator Collins that can only be described as a bob-a-job performance. The only acknowledgment he gave of problems of travel were his own. How selfish; how egotistical; how smug! I assure Senator Collins that the people of the Northern Territory expect far more from him than hot air. He did not once allude to the frustration, the extreme inconvenience, and in particular the cost to his own constituency. In an article in the Northern Territory News of 14 October, talking about the pilots dispute but really just bashing the AFAP, Senator Collins concluded:
The bottom line of all of this is that the pilots should go back to work under an award which is a fair return for their highly skilled labour.

It is a pity that Senator Collins has a constant preoccupation with only the pilots. He made no mention of the flying public or businesses going broke. His arguments are so similar to the arguments of Hawke the great conspirator. We need to look at who the Prime Minister has colluded with since the strike commenced. Of course, he has colluded with the airlines and Sir Peter Abeles, constantly. He has colluded with the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, in order to create the banana republic airline that we have had to operate with as a bandaid job over the past few months. He has attempted to gain access through the tourism leaders, so many of whom are in bodies and institutions that depend on Government largess. The Federal Airports Corporation has been required to do his bidding and undertake special considerations. Of course, the airlines have been propped up with subsidies that the Government seems to be chucking around. But the casualties and the tragedies are both personal and commercial. An excellent letter, which appeared in the Northern Territory News of 27 November, raises a new and very interesting point of view. It states:
How long is this farce of the fractured airlines going to be allowed to continue?
What a pathetic nation we have become when we have to look to other countries to settle our internal disputes.
Are aggression and arrogance permanently to take the place of common sense, leadership and negotiations.

The present approach has meant the loss of the greater part of the tourist industry, further unfavourable balance of payments and the replacement of our own citizens, people with the best flying safety record in the world, with people of unknown capabilities from other countries.
The bleak side of Christmas has always been the national road toll. How much higher will it be this year because many people will not have available to them the option of flying home?
How much extra traffic will our inadequate highways and byways have to cope?
Our pilots have always taken us home safely.
Our police force, ambulance and hospitals cannot prevent accidents. They can only pick up the pieces.
The pilots' offer to return to work over Christmas period and negotiate later was commendable, sensible and in both parties' interests.
In the interests of the people of Australia it should have been accepted.
At this stage it is not too late.
After Christmas for a lot of people it may be.
What is it to be, the probability of road carnage at Christmas or common sense and a happier new year right across the nation.

It was signed by Alice Hennessy, Ludmilla, which is a Darwin suburb. I cannot think of a better challenge to the Prime Minister for action to avoid his being dobbed the executioner. He has killed off the tourist industry and small business and is now putting at risk his very own constituents-Australians. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table of the holiday period road accident deaths for the three December-January holiday periods from 1986 to 1989. I have sought Senator Button's approval.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows that the average number of deaths in the December-January holiday period each year is about 500. I put the Prime Minister on notice: for any one death over 500 in this coming holiday period, I will hold him personally responsible. This is a very credible proposition that needs to be made. If there are more deaths, he will properly deserve the title of the executioner Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Why will Prime Minister Hawke not test the sincerity of the AFAP and the pilots? His actions are cynical and fraudulent and show nothing but indifference and incompetence. He consults with everybody except the pilots. Why is that? It is because of the subtle and hidden agendas.

Of course, there is the agenda with regard to the unions. It has always been established that the Australian Council of Trade Unions does not like the pilots because they have done their own thing, stood on their own feet and not pretended to be part of that club. The Federal Government has thrown subsidy moneys at the airline companies so that the unions would not have to face stand-down provisions. Therefore, there is no pressure coming from other unions that would normally have arisen for a solution in such a situation. But what about the hidden agenda of Ansett Airlines of Australia for the resorts that will obviously go bankrupt and broke over the next few months? It will be very interesting to see who buys them up and what commercial advantages there are as these sorts of things happen. Let Sir Peter Abeles be on notice that we will be watching for all those purchases.

What about international rights for Ansett Airlines of Australia when the shotgun marriage between Australian Airlines Ltd and Qantas Airways Ltd has to take place? Will Sir Peter put his hand up straightaway and say, `Hey, that is unfair. Ansett demands the same, and wants it.'? Therefore are the consequences of delay likely to provide another very subtle and hidden agenda? When we face the election campaign early next year and the Prime Minister has to account for his lousy economy, will he turn around and point the bone at the pilots and say, `They did it; it is their fault', rather than accept the responsibility of his rotten administration for the last seven years? Is he, therefore, using this dispute as a very subtle and hidden agenda?

It is incumbent on the Prime Minister to test the pilots' bona fides because the consequences of the Prime Minister's inaction are just so awful to contemplate. The regular scheduled services just do not exist. The false capacity figures that are thrown about so regularly need to be tested against the fact that in some instances, such as in the Northern Territory-from Alice Springs to Yulara to Ayers Rock-there are no services back on the records. What about the cancellation of the programs and the charter flights? The claims about the scheduled services versus the actual services need to be tested and proven. We will get those figures in due course but, unfortunately, too late to help the people in the street. What about the alterations, the changes, the block bookings that are made by the airlines that we can never get past? Block bookings are made which mean that nobody can get a seat on a plane. We end up with this great capacity, which is a waste.

The inconvenience and the cost to business of doing the bookings and scheduling has been just phenomenal. The positions of the major tourist resorts of Cairns and the Gold Coast stand alone. The principal holiday destinations have been deserted. I have seen figures on the occupancy rates at Yulara that horrify me. Internationally-in Japan, North America and West Germany where all our forward selling goes on-Australia is now a joke. The financial consequences will be disastrous. I know that there was a 90 per cent drop in the number of domestic passengers flying in and out of Darwin in September. It is interesting to compare the flight details for many of those areas against the schedules for the previous financial year. There were 71 Australian Airlines flights into Darwin in October 1988; in October 1989 there were 16. There were 136 flights into Alice Springs in October 1988; in October 1989 there were 18. Darwin had only 40 per cent of capacity and Alice Springs around 30 per cent. If the seat capacity in and out of Darwin is tested it is less than 70 per cent for Darwin and about 39 per cent for Alice Springs and, as I said, it is nil for Yulara. If we look at other bookings with regard to movements, we will notice phenomenal changes. Commercial visitor rates in all the hotels are down by about 40 per cent. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an expenditure losses chart which shows the impact the dispute had on Northern Territory tourism. It also shows losses of over $58m in the period to 17 November this year and details the daily rates of loss that are now well in excess of $300,000.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Confederation of Industry has highlighted to me its deep concern in a letter. Unfortunately, I do not have time to read the letter at this stage. It points out that the dispute is affecting the cash flow of all industries in the Northern Territory, not only those that can be classified as tourism. It is having a disastrous effect throughout Australia. It is very interesting to note that unless the Government addresses this matter urgently and properly we will have very serious problems. The Northern Territory Minister for Tourism has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The most urgent need, however, is for Federal authorities to get the airlines back to full operation-and in all corners of the nation, not just the Golden Triangle. The pilots' dispute must be settled, and it must be settled now. It has taken many years of painstaking effort to build the Territory tourism industry into what it was before disaster struck . . . Many men and women who have committed their savings and a life-time of effort to the industry are facing ruin. We are all being affected.

That was the comment of Mr Vale recently. I am very well aware of the serious consequences of the loss of very skilled people and expertise in so many industries right across Australia-from Tasmania to Queensland and the Northern Territory. It is important that Prime Minister Hawke does not continue to hang his hat on the words of so many. As Peter Costello summarised in an excellent article in the Institute of Public Affairs Review, `It really has become-sue the workers, call in the military'. That is how the Labor Government handled the pilots dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I saw this matter of urgency listed on the Senate business sheet today it certainly gave me a sense of deja vu. I do not know how many times we have had similar debates over the last three months. I can remember participating in a debate on 4 September. I read the Hansard to see what the Opposition members had said during that debate. After sitting here patiently for the last one and three-quarter hours I realised that they could have tabled their speeches from the debate on 4 September. They have not contributed one new idea about what is going on in this dispute. I suspect that before the Senate finishes in mid-December we will have Senator Chaney bringing on another urgency debate and making the same speech. He does not realise that the circumstances in this whole affair are quite different from what they were on 4 September.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney made great play in his remarks appealing to the Government to get on with the job of solving the dispute. If we had taken any notice of what the major Opposition spokespeople have said, we would be in utter confusion, as they are.

I want to draw the attention of the Senate to what I said way back on 4 September as to the performance of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock. We have not heard much from him over the last month or so about this matter. He made such a fool of himself at the end of August that I think he has been gagged by his Party. At a celebrated conference on 31 August, for which there are several pages of transcript, Mr Peacock contradicted himself absolutely. At page 11 of the transcript of the press conference of 31 August, he stated:

No, I wouldn't be imposing sanctions. I give people the right to go before the Commission or a court and argue. This is a right, this is a wrong, if they can establish their locus standi. But the reality is the real constraint on them is the economy itself and at root the market.
By page 19, a somersault later, this is what he says:
To settle that dispute today operating in the system that belongs to the Government I have said to you there should be a sanctions power.

In the same press conference he did a somersault and went from saying that there should be no sanctions to saying that there should be sanctions. He was severely caned by the press all round Australia the next day, which said, `It is clear that the Leader of the Opposition does not know what he is talking about on industrial relations, and does not even understand the policy of his own Party'.
Senator Chaney has had a couple of spectacular contradictions in this whole affair. In a media release on 21 August, Senator Chaney stated:
The Opposition does not support the use of coercion in industrial relations. That is not what voluntary agreements are about.
Then in a media release on 23 August, just two days later, amnesia obviously took over because he stated:

The Government should act immediately to use the power available to it under sections 80 and 45d (1a) of the Trade Practices Act to seek an interlocutory injunction from the Federal Court ordering the pilots to cease industrial action.

We have the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and Leader of the Opposition in the Senate absolutely contradicting themselves in a period of a couple of days back in August. No wonder Senator Durack wants to get the question of the Senate leadership resolved pretty quickly when in two days we have the Leader in the Senate and Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party doing two somersaults. He even beat Mr Peacock's record.

Then we turn to the remarks of the Opposition, which have clearly and overwhelmingly been in support of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, no matter what, whenever the Federation has wanted to say something in the last month and a half. Honourable senators only had to be, like I was, sitting at the Senate inquiry with Senator MacGibbon to see that he could be almost a paid advocate of the Pilots Federation. Honourable senators can bet their bottom dollar that every dorothy dixer that the Federation wanted Senator MacGibbon to ask he came in and crunched. He usually got crunched back afterwards from people who gave him answers. In particular, I want to draw the attention of the Senate to the public evidence given by Miss Shayne Nealon, the President of the Australian Flight Attendants Association. She said that the flight attendants had stayed within the wage guidelines. They are affiliated to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). They have made it quite clear that, if the pilots had been successful in their 30 per cent claim, the flight attendants would immediately have gone out and got 30 per cent for themselves.

There is the real input of why the Government stood up to the pilots-we would have had the great wages breakout, which, of course, those opposite want. They want to wreck the economy because that is the only way they think they can get elected. I have not been able to attend every session of this inquiry because of conflicting commitments on other standing committees of the Parliament, but I have sat through most of it, as have Senator Collins, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Brownhill and others. It has been quite instructive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was your excuse for not coming to meetings of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee.

—I must say that Senator Alston ought to be very quiet about his attendance at Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee meetings. We held three meetings when we waited for him to turn up and he still did not do so because he wanted to rewrite the evidence.
—We ultimately resolved that satisfactorily.
—Because you were not there. That is why we resolved it.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator get on with the debate.
—Tell us about the South Australian campaign you ran.
—Order! Senator Schacht, get on with the debate.

—I will certainly tell Senator MacGibbon: we won, you lost. For another four years Senator MacGibbon's mob will be in opposition. It will mean that by the time the next term is up, his mob will have had only five years of government out of the last 28 in South Australia. That is not a bad record for the Liberal Party in South Australia! I would like to see Senator MacGibbon speak here next Monday and tell us how many votes the Liberal Party gets in Queensland next Saturday.

SPEECH.PARA: I really want to refer to evidence given to the Senate inquiry. Most of the things that Opposition members have said have been covered before in endless debate. One of the things I found interesting in listening to the Pilots Federation contribution in the Senate inquiry was that it very much struck me, after hearing Captain McCarthy and other witnesses, how any group of people can delude themselves and lead themselves into disaster. While listening to Captain McCarthy I was reminded of a very relevant book published in the last couple of years by a very famous American historian, Barbara Tushman. The book is called the March of Folly. It is all about how, in history, on a number of occasions people have ignored reality and have suffered enormous consequences. She uses a range of analogies, from the Trojans allowing the horse to be pulled inside the battlements against all rational advice; to the American War of Independence, when the British Government ignored all rational advice; to the American involvement in the Vietnam war; to the collapse of the Reformation in the sixteenth century, and so on. Having listened to Captain McCarthy, I thought, `Here is a small example of the march of folly of the leadership of an organisation'.

I feel very sorry for the pilots. Why are they in this position of folly? Unfortunately for the pilots, they have had unlimited success as an industrial organisation since they got together after the Second World War. They used to pride themselves on the fact that they never lost an industrial dispute; they always won exactly what they wanted. They always said, `We can always last one day longer than the airline companies. We will never lose'. Those statements were in the espirit de corps of the union. So, unfortunately, the great mistake of Captain McCarthy and the leadership of the union is that they expected the same thing to happen again. That is why they could ignore the ACTU or their fellow trade unions in the industry. The Federation has never supported the Flight Attendants Association, the transport workers, or any of the other unions in the industry. Whenever those unions had a dispute, the pilots ignored them completely. The pilots never gave them one ounce of support. They said, `We do not need the support of anyone else. We can get what we want because of our industrial strength and because of the commitment of our union'. That led the pilots into this great march of folly.

If we talk to any experienced blue collar trade union leader who has been through victories and defeats in industrial disputation, he will say, `You never lead the troops out of the gate, up the hill unless you know there is a way back with a bit of honour-that you can negotiate your way back'. The problem is that the pilots said, `It is 30 per cent or nothing, boys; up the hill and the airlines will give in within two or three days'. Unfortunately for the pilots, when they got up the hill it was like General Custer at Little Big Horn. Who was waiting? Sitting Bull, and the massacre took place.

That is what has happened to the pilots, because they ignored all industrial experience of most other unions. They took that attitude because they had never had an industrial defeat in their history. Now that the pilots are faced with that defeat they are casting around to find who else is responsible. The pilots are blaming the Prime Minister. They are blaming Sir Peter Abeles. They are blaming the management of the companies. They are blaming the Labor Party. They are blaming the ACTU. They are calling everybody scabs. If honourable senators talk to a lot of other unions they would say that the Pilots Federation is one of the great scab unions in Australia. It never supported any of them when they had an industrial dispute. So the pilots cast around and the last thing they are left with, which we have paraded before us in the Senate inquiry, is that safety is at risk. The pilots' co-conspirator in this argument is certainly Senator MacGibbon. Again and again the accusation is made that safety is at risk.

I have no doubt that, if there is by some extraordinary calamity an air accident some time in the next couple of months in Australia and some Australians are killed, we will have cheering people on the other side of the chamber saying, `I told you so. It is all your fault'. Opposition members will use that as a justification. That is what I find distasteful about the way in which the Opposition has performed in this debate, not only here but particularly in the Senate inquiry. They are almost praying for a calamity to take place so that they can prove the point. I think that is disgusting. Every accusation the Opposition has made about incidents occurring has been overwhelmingly rejected. It was a great embarrassment to the Opposition and to the Committee when the evidence came forward from the companies about what this great professional organisation, the Pilots Federation, had been doing: the harassment, the scab patrols, and so on, which do put at risk safety in the air. We have had not one word of criticism or damnation from the Opposition against these scab patrols, against the interference with and intimidation of those pilots who are flying. We have had not one word of criticism of the Pilots Federation going into a briefing room and intimidating pilots, making them feel frustrated and angry when they are about to take off in a plane-all putting safety at risk. We have heard not one word from the Opposition. It has been a disgraceful performance by the Opposition.

I look forward to the Senate inquiry concluding its report and to it coming to this place before the end of this year. I look forward to that debate because, when it takes place, Senator Chaney and his fellow Opposition members will get one of the great baths in this debate about what they have been doing over the last couple of months. I said early on that the Opposition has contradicted itself again and again over what sort of policy it should adopt to overcome this dispute. At one stage Opposition senators have said, `No sanctions', and at another stage they have said, `Yes, sanctions'. In the first week of the dispute Mr Peacock said that he supported the Government's action. The Opposition has done it all; it has somersaulted and triple somersaulted. It has done the lot. Yet it has the temerity, for the fifth or the sixth time, to come into this chamber and accuse us of not doing anything. The airlines are restoring services-not as much as any of us would like, but they are restoring them. Ansett Airlines of Australia has said that by March next year it will have its services restored.

TALK.START.PARA: —March next year?

—Yes, all right. Senator Chaney would like the Government to capitulate to the Air Pilots Federation and wreck the industrial relations system and the wages system in this country. That is what Senator Chaney is about because he believes that the only way he can get into government is to wreck the wages system and the economy.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-A fascinating feature of this debate is that not one Labor speaker has expressed any concern for the enormous damage which is being done to thousands of innocent Australians by this strike. It has been a debate of point scoring and misrepresentation. It is improper to accuse an honourable senator of lying, but, since Senator Schacht, who has just resumed his seat, cannot be a liar, he must be a fool. For example, his total misrepresentation of the press releases put out by me shows that he cannot understand plain English.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) has said that there has been no word from the Opposition on allegations of intimidation. Let me say that there has been no action by the Government in the face of repeated invitations from me. As the Opposition spokesperson on industrial relations I have repeatedly said that there are remedies in the Trade Practices Act and probably in the Industrial Relations Act, and that, if those remedies are not adequate, the Opposition will join with the Government in amending the law to ensure that any such behaviour is treated in the most disciplined and punitive way. We have never supported such conduct. I have made it absolutely clear that there are courses open to the Government and the Government has done nothing. We have had accusations like those that have come from Senator Schacht but nothing has been done by the Government to enforce the law, if the Government really believes that that is occurring.

Let me say in the very limited time that I have to respond to this debate that the reality is that a great deal of damage is being done. We believe, as we have believed for months, that there is room for constructive negotiation which will terminate this dispute, which will bring it to an end on a proper basis. Mr Acting Deputy President, that is the course which has been ignored by the Government that you support, and it is a course which flies in the face of everything that you have ever said about trade unions in this place. I find the whole debate pathetically distant from the concerns of the Australian people.

The final point that I wish to deal with is Senator Collins's absurd suggestion that a direction to the Government-owned airline, which still enjoys duopoly privileges in this economy, to sit down and test the offer from the pilots could be described as Stalinist. I received an unsolicited letter from Mr E. R. Kelly, the former Chief Commissioner of the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission, who wrote to me in these terms:

The stand taken by the Government is fundamentally flawed because there is no legislative support for the proposition that all employees must comply with the centralised wage fixing guidelines, and there can be none because the Constitution does not authorise the making of such a law. That fact is recognised in the National Wage Decision in that the `decision' is simply an option which individual unions may accept (provided they give a `no extra claims' undertaking) . . . So when the Prime Minister insists that the pilots may not go outside the rules of the centralised system, it is not Commonwealth law but Hawke's Law (or perhaps Kelty's Law) that is being applied to the detriment of citizens who, whether or not we like what they are doing, are acting within the law. That seems to me to be dictatorship rather than constitutional government.

If we are going to get into the business of trying to classify what sort of dictatorial behaviour we are getting in this community, I think the fascist experiment of Mussolini is a far closer analogy than Stalinism, the description put forward by the senator from the Northern Territory.

As tens of thousands of Australians rot in businesses which are being destroyed, including at Yulara and in other parts of the Northern Territory, and as so many Australians find their jobs, their businesses and their life's work disappearing, I hope that they have noted the total ignoring of their plight by the Labor senators in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It is not possible in the space of five minutes to deal with all the matters arising from the two-volume report of the Australian Bicentennial Authority for 1989. This is probably the last report that we will have from the Authority. It goes to a number of matters concluding the work of that Authority and the winding up of various matters arising from the celebration of Australia's bicentennial year.

Any Australian who was involved in aspects of the Bicentennial will have cause to remember it. Certainly it was a great pleasure for me to have responsibility as the shadow Minister for the Bicentennial during 1988. Indeed, any honourable senator who was involved in the great celebrations on Australia Day 1988 in the forecourts of the Sydney Opera House and on and around the harbour will never forget that event. There are too many people to thank in terms of the work done on the Bicentenary, and I do not propose to try to do that other than to say that those who contributed, from those who were originally involved in this matter 10 years ago to those who saw it to its completion, need to be particularly noted. However, I will note the work done by Mr Peter Sarah, who was in charge of the arts program which went hand in glove with Bicentennial Authority activities. I believe that he is to be congratulated for an outstanding performance over many years.

It is more important, however, to say something in terms of looking to the future. We now face the prospect of celebration in due course of the centenary of Federation in Australia. None of the problems and criticisms which may have been involved with the Bicentennial can possibly be levelled at the centenary of Federation. Federation is one of the great achievements of the Australian people. It is a great achievement to create a new nation and to do so without rancour, without difficulty and without bloodshed. Certainly there were minor problems along the way, but the creation of a new nation out of disparate States and colonies is a signal achievement in the history of our planet, and the bringing forth of a functioning parliamentary democracy which has stood the test of time over the century is something to be very greatly remarked upon.

It is a pity that we have already lost the opportunity to mark and to properly celebrate some of those events leading up to the Bicentenary. It is a great shame that the Australian Government did not see fit to give proper recognition, for example, to the centenary of Sir Henry Parkes's Tenterfield speech, which was one of the great steps along the way. I hope that in government we will be in a position to put down a comprehensive program moving towards the celebration of that centenary. We will not play it in a partisan fashion. Events such as the centenary of the founding of the Australian Labor Party are events which ought properly to be marked. They are part of our national history. The centenary of the various constitutional conventions which went into the making of the Australian Constitution, which, regardless of the attacks which have been mounted upon it by the Australian Labor Party, has stood the test of time well, and the centenary of the creation and emergence of the Senate as a vital part of our parliamentary democracy, which derives very much from the efforts made by the Founding Fathers-I certainly regret that there were, in an historical sense, no founding mothers of Australian Federation-are similarly things to be marked.

There are many lessons to be learnt and many things not to be done in the way in which the Bicentennial Authority did them. There are, however, many good things which it did upon which we should build. I believe that it will be a challenge to the Australian nation in the course of the 1990s to establish a proper way of marking the growth and development of our country as a Federation, and the eventual celebration of the centenary of that event. I look forward with my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties to having charge of that program, to developing that program, to bringing it to fruition and to marking with proper celebration a thing of which we should all be extraordinarily proud.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPORT BY THE ATTORNEY-GENERAL ON THE OPERATION OF THE BANKRUPTCY ACT 1966

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) issued a media release on 10 November concerning provisional bankruptcy figures for the September quarter. In that release he claimed that the figures showed a slight decline in total bankruptcies and insolvencies under the Act compared with the trend in the last corresponding quarter. The Minister also claimed that verified figures for the full 1988-89 year showed that the total number of bankruptcies was down on the previous year. It is a bit hard to believe that that could be the case in the present economic climate, with high interest rates. So I was particularly interested to see this report and to learn a little more about what the Minister regarded as the declining bankruptcies that he spoke of.

Page 18 of the report shows the figures for a number of bankruptcy proceedings during the past year. The number of proceedings in 1988-89 is 7,435, and is down compared with 8,504 proceedings for the previous year. However, I emphasise the fact that the Minister has referred to the number of proceedings. At page 20 of the report one finds the statements:
The number of bankruptcy notices issued during the year was 14,469 compared with 14,187 for 1987-88.

This represents an increase in bankruptcy notices, and does not accord with the declining trend that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) referred to. With individuals and businesses clearly suffering from the present state of the economy, it would be logical to expect that that would be the case and that the number of bankruptcies would not be decreasing, as the Minister sought to claim. To further add to the confusion about the real trend in bankruptcies, we have the fact that the New South Wales Supreme Court recently released figures showing a 50 per cent increase in business bankruptcies. The figures were reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 November, just three days before the Minister tried to tell us the good news as he saw it. The New South Wales Supreme Court advised that by September this year it had appointed official liquidators for 2,184 companies. For the same period last year the number was 1,413. This information, together with the report before the Senate today, exposes what I regard as the Minister's transparent attempt to run a line that bankruptcies are on the decline.

The tragic fact is that bankruptcies are increasing. This report tells us the number of proceedings. The number of proceedings being dealt with may in fact be down due to the weight of numbers. But the reality is quite the reverse. The Government might seek to kid itself that things are improving for businesses and home owners, but the rest of us know that the situation is quite the reverse. The homes of thousands of Australians are on the market right now. These people cannot meet interest rates of 18 per cent. Some people who have already sold their homes have found that they are still in debt.

I commend to the Minister an article written by Max Walsh in the Sydney Morning Herald of Monday of this week. It gives a very realistic account of what is happening to ordinary families in this country. I suggest that the Minister for Consumer Affairs and his colleagues would do well to read it. Max Walsh talks about a property in North Sydney and what has happened to the family that formerly owned that house. The article makes interesting reading and makes many more significant points.

Ideally, one would think that Government members would be sufficiently in touch with what is going on in our community to be aware of the fact that ordinary Australian families are going broke and are being bankrupted. They should not have to be reminded of this fact by others. That the Minister for Consumer Affairs could issue a media release claiming that bankruptcies are declining, when this is patently not the case, is a sign of how blinded he and his colleagues have become or how they really try to hoodwink Australian families and small business. Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the press release of the Minister for Consumer Affairs dated 10 November and the article to which I referred in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 November.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
RELEASE OF QUARTERLY BANKRUPTCY STATISTICS
The Federal Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Nick Bolkus, today released provisional and unverified statistics for the July to September quarter 1989 (Attachment A).

Senator Bolkus said that the figures show a slight decline in total bankruptcies and insolvencies under the Bankruptcy Act 1966 compared with the corresponding quarter in 1988. The verified annual figures confirm a downward trend in bankruptcies.

``The published figures for the full year 1988/89 are now verified and final. They show that the total number of bankruptcies for 1988/89 is 15.9 per cent down on the total for 1987/88 and 6.1 per cent down on the total for 1986/87'' Senator Bolkus said.
``More comprehensive annual data will be available when the Annual Report on the Operation of the Bankruptcy Act for the year ended 30 June 1989 is tabled in Parliament shortly''.
Bankruptcies boom by 50pc
by DAVID McKNIGHT
Professions Writer
The number of companies going bust has jumped by nearly 50 per cent since last year, according to figures from the NSW Supreme Court.
By September this year, the Supreme Court had appointed official liquidators for 2,184 companies. For the same period last year, it was 1,413.
But while businesses bust, work for liquidators is booming.
Accountants at Peat Marwick Hungerfords's insolvency division are at their busiest in years, handling some of the better known failures such as Hookers, Equiticorp and Spedley.
One of its partners, Mr Chris Horn, said yesterday that staff were now working longer hours and recruitment of accounting graduates was aggressive.
Mr Horn blamed poor management, high interest rates and downturns in industry sectors for the boom in busts.
Company crashes bring their own particular form of low life.
He pointed to asset-strippers who prey on the corporations by posing as helpful advisers for companies in trouble.
``It's human nature to make a dollar out of someone else's misfortune,'' he said.
But company crashes also expose outright fraud by the directors themselves.
A partner in the accounting firm Bentleys, Mr Mark MacMahon, said it was difficult to tell if a business was going bad because of ``out-and-out incompetence or just devious criminal behaviour''.
Mr MacMahon described the present law on insolvencies as ``Dickensian'' because it does not protect all creditors.
Occasionally dogs are set on receivers and liquidators, though Mr MacMahon admits ``it's been a long while since someone took a swing at me with a wrench''.

Meanwhile, the number of company directors barred from holding office remains steady. In 1988-89, 126 company directors were prohibited from holding office as directors for five years, compared to last year's 124, according to the NSW Corporate Affairs Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Reid has said about the massive increase in bankruptcies taking place, and I refer not only to the number of them but to the size of the losses involved to creditors of bankrupt companies and the impact that that is having on the confidence of the business community and overseas investors in Australia. I agree with Senator Reid that the attempt by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to hoodwink the people of Australia by claiming that there has been some great success and a massive decline in bankruptcies, when all he is talking about is the number of proceedings that have been completed is, of course, ridiculous.
—Shabby.

—I accept whatever word is deemed appropriate. As Senator Reid has said, not only has the number of bankruptcy notices during the year increased considerably, from 14,187 to 14,469, but the number of creditor petitions presented increased from 2.954 to 3,202. So, we have evidence of the increase in the volume of bankruptcies, while at the same time we have clear indications that the size of corporations going broke due to this Government's high interest rates is such that massive losses are taking place, because of business and personal bankruptcies.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that as this Government continues with its deliberate policy of massively high interest rates the number of people who will go broke, let alone those who are going to feel enormous financial pressure, will continue to mount. Already we have seen evidence of falling house prices as the real estate market is beginning to suffer severely from the huge interest rates imposed in the mortgage area-despite the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has repeatedly said that interest rates will not rise. Of course, they have consistently continued to rise, despite the $200m-odd deal with taxpayers' money that the Government has done with the banks to try to hold down mortgage interest rates. This is inevitable as long as this Government relies so heavily and so entirely, in effect, on high interest rates as its only method of running the economy-its only method of dampening down economic activity, as it prefers to describe it. While the Government does this, it is inevitable that there will be further and horrendous increases in the number of people going bankrupt.

It is unfortunate that this report is grossly inadequate. Nowhere does it reveal the amount of total losses involved in these bankruptcies to make an appropriate comparison with the previous year. Obviously that would give a much more effective indicator to us about the consequences of the Government's present economic policies. This annual report would certainly give the Government no cause for any genuine satisfaction. Certainly some phoney satisfaction can be grasped by dragging out some individual figures that might appear to suit the government's book, but the fact remains that anyone who reads the finance pages of the newspapers can tell that there are massive business bankruptcies and huge levels of loss, which damages Australia's status. There is mounting unemployment as a result of the closure of many businesses. To some extent it could be argued that this might bring rationalised industry and greater efficiency. The fact is that what this Government is doing through its high interest rate policy is sending Australian companies to the wall, sending Australian families broke and forcing Australian families out of their homes. This report clearly dramatises what is happening.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CAREER PROGRESSION FOR OUTSTANDING AUSTRALIAN RESEARCHERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the second document in two days from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. Indeed, in the House of Representatives today another couple of documents from the Board were tabled. We will be dealing with those tomorrow. I wish to raise a couple of points on this quite brief and slim paper. I refer to the requirement in the Employment, Education and Training Act, which was passed last year, which required the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), with regard to advice and formal references, to ensure that any such advice received be tabled in both Houses of Parliament as soon as practicable.

When one looks at this particular operation, one sees that what the Minister's office may see as practicable is when it suits that office rather than when it suits the convenience of the Parliament. The original statement seeking advice was a letter to Professor Smith, who was the chair of the National Board, on 26 July 1989. The Board considered that letter and finalised its advice on 25 August. The Board conveyed its recommendation and advice to the Minister on 27 September. I am not sure why it took over a month for the Board to get its advice, which covers no more than four pages, in a form suitable to be conveyed to the Minister. Be that as it may, there is no obligation under the Act to do that.

That advice having been received by the Minister on 27 September-it is now 29 November, and this advice was received by the Senate yesterday, on 28 November-it took two months for that advice to come into the Parliament. Quite frankly, I do not think that can be said to be as soon as practicable, even bearing in mind that the Minister might have wished to review the matter before it came into the Parliament.

The second point I wish to raise, again briefly, is that the advice is reasonable in as much as it is seeking to give at least some range of what are called fellowships to a number of people in the area of skilled researchers. However, until some reasonable attitude is taken to the remuneration for academics across the board, this particular exercise will fall flat. It is merely a drop in the bucket of what is actually needed. To suggest that in some way this may assist the career prospects of outstanding Australian researchers is in fact to talk down the number of outstanding Australian researchers available.

We have already caused serious damage to research across the board by the attitudes that have been taken by this and the previous government to the funding of research and to the funding of research in the research institutions in this country. Of course, the vast bulk of those have been and will continue to be, at least in the foreseeable future, universities and in some cases colleges of advanced education (CAEs). Of course, CAEs have now been incorporated into universities.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY STANDING COMMITTEE ON PUBLIC WORKS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the following report: Sandfilling of International Terminal, Commercial and Operational Sites, Brisbane Airport. I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have just tabled relates to the preparation of sites for further developments at Brisbane airport. These include sites for an international terminal and aviation industry infrastructure. This report is the sixth report presented by the Committee regarding developments at Brisbane airport since 1979. I should also add that the Committee has spent more time examining this project than any other this year. What appeared on the surface to be a reasonably straightforward project, developed into a re-examination of the planning philosophy of the Brisbane airport and the master plan on which it is based.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is well aware that airports are an extremely sensitive issue in the community and Brisbane is no exception. The Committee recognises that any decision it reaches on this matter is likely to be controversial and arouse strong feelings in the community. Indeed, reflecting this, two members of the Committee have dissented from the final recommendation that the project proceed.

The Committee recognises that in many respects future developments at Brisbane airport have been locked in by past developments. The Committee is also conscious that its referral related to a specific project. However, the Committee recognised that the sandfilling project had the possible effect of closing off alternative avenues of development. The Committee therefore took the view that it has a wider responsibility to the Parliament and examined in some detail the basic philosophy of the master plan and issues such as runway directions, length of cross wind runway and noise effects.

As part of its examination, the Committee undertook detailed inspections of the airport and environs on 25 July and 10 August. These included the proposed site, the existing international terminal, and an aerial inspection which included the airport, the site for the sand dredging at Middle Banks and a simulated instrument approach to the airport. The Committee also travelled to suburbs south of the city to observe aircraft on landing approach and to experience noise levels.

On balance the Committee, with the exception of Senator Burns and Senator Devereux, has somewhat reluctantly accepted that the sandfilling project should proceed as proposed by the Federal Airports Corporation. In the report the Committee has recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation should undertake a thorough re-examination of the Brisbane airport master plan before further runway developments are undertaken. In making this recommendation, the Committee has rejected the proposition that extension of the 14/32 cross wind runway to accept heavier aircraft is not feasible.

The Committee has also drawn attention to the measures being taken to minimise the noise impact of aircraft operations at Brisbane airport. The Committee is aware of the considerable concern expressed to it by resident groups and by local Federal and State members on the issue of aircraft noise. I commend the report to the Senate.
