The document read as follows-
The 34th Conference held special significance for Australia, being held in our bicentennial year and in our new and permanent Parliament House.

Delegations from 104 Parliaments and legislatures attended the conference along with 106 observers from international organisations and CPA member branches. There was a total of 520 participants including spouses and unofficial observers. Visitors came from every part of the world-Asia (from Singapore to India), the Caribbean, Europe and the Mediterranean, Africa and North America and the Australasian/Pacific area. As well as diverse geographic locations the delegations came from the broad spectrum of parliamentary systems, including republics, monarchies under Queen Elizabeth II and national monarchies.

Sir Ninian Stephen drew on the theme of the geographic diversity of the countries attending the conference in his opening address. He told delegates that their presence was abundant testimony to the enduring vitality of parliamentary institutions throughout the Commonwealth of Nations. He encouraged those present to draw hope, from the gathering and the agenda that it had set itself, that the evils of the world could be eradicated.

The conference deliberations consisted of four plenary sessions and six panel sessions, the first plenary session, that on international peace and security was presented by His Excellency, Mr Shridath Ramphal, who presented an historical perspective on the world's troublespots before addressing the theme of the plenary session. He commented on the need for circumspection in talking of peace, especially in regard to the approximately 20 million people who have died as a result of armed conflicts in the post-war era, mainly in developing countries. He called on the Commonwealth to be a standard bearer for peace and to each parliament to reaffirm the Goa Declaration.

Among the key topics covered in the other sessions were drugs and what the Commonwealth can do to curb drug abuse and drug trafficking, the spread of AIDS, the current GATT discussions, the negative effects of the declining world economy on women and young people, and the establishment of a parliamentary branch of Amnesty International.

The Commonwealth of Australia branch delegation participated fully in the plenary and panel sessions. As members of the delegation of one of the host branches, we felt we had a special responsibility as well as the usual obligation to participate fully. We felt an additional obligation to our guests to assist and encourage them in their participation.

As well as the main proceedings there were other activities associated with the conference. The eighth Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference of members from small countries and the meetings of the society of clerks-at-the-table are of particular note.

The conference, in all its facets, was an outstanding success. The delegation wishes to record its appreciation of the efforts of the State branches and their executive committees and staff, the conference co-ordinating committee headed by Mr Browning, you Mr President and Mr Kieran Schneemann and the staff of the Parliamentary Relations Office. I also thank Mr Mark McRae, the Secretary to the delegation, for his efforts prior to, and during, the conference.
I wish to thank the leader, Mr Ben Humphreys, the Deputy Leader, Mr David Connolly, and my fellow delegates, both Commonwealth and State, for their support and co-operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be remiss to allow the report of the Commonwealth of Australia branch delegation to the thirty-fourth Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference to pass without mentioning that the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference that was held here was certainly seen not only by our own delegation but also by many others-and I have had confirmation of that since-as being one of the most successful of recent Commonwealth parliamentary conferences. One of the reasons for this is the fact that it was held within this Parliament House. This is not a usual practice considering that most parliament houses are not built to take a conference of that size.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people interested in the progress and developments of parliaments around the world-and certainly those with a British Commonwealth tradition-were interested to come to Australia to see this Parliament House, discuss how it worked and assess its benefits to parliamentary democracy. I think they were all duly staggered by the size of this Parliament House and the fittings in it. I talked to delegates from the British delegation who, after many years of seniority, had managed to graduate to a small desk in a corridor somewhere. They were very much taken with the fact that Australia had made very deliberate decisions with regard to the provision of services for the Parliament. Unfortunately, all too often we neglect to appreciate services that have been provided to the Parliament by various governments of all political persuasions. Those provisions, in many areas, exceed those which have been made in comparable parliaments anywhere else in the world.

Indeed, when listening to the debate today on the parliamentary appropriations, one may have been led to believe that such provisions had not been made. While there are many things that we might like to improve on, I think we have to acknowledge that it has been the tradition in Australia to provide adequate services for Parliament. The services that were provided in this building during that parliamentary conference were very much appreciated by all delegates.

I suppose one criticism that can be made of Commonwealth parliamentary conferences-and certainly it is made from time to time, as it is of the larger Inter-Parliamentary Union conferences which are attended by representatives from parliaments throughout the world-is that they are nothing other than talkfests. Having attended quite a number of conferences, not only during my parliamentary career but also before it, I know that these types of criticisms are raised from time to time. Undoubtedly, there is an element of a talkfest in every conference.

The other aspect of conferences which is sometimes missed even by delegates who go to them-it is almost always missed by those people who are not at them-is the chance to meet and discuss informally with one's colleagues, not only from one's own parliament but from other parliaments. One has the opportunity to see how they handle the matters of the day, the new procedures they are putting in place in their parliaments, the problems they are running into in terms of constituency advocacy and the ways in which some parliaments are able to facilitate the flow of information from the Executive to the parliament. All of those matters lead one to reconsider one's own practice and think of better ways in which one can do the job that one has to do.

The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), who is in the chamber, commented earlier today during the appropriation debate that it might be nice for us, on occasions, to look at productivity. That is a reasonable suggestion for the Minister to make and it is a reasonable suggestion for all of us to take on board. These parliamentary conferences, in many ways, enable us to look at that. Indeed, at the recent South Pacific regional conference of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association I gave a paper on some changes that have taken place in the Senate and the House of Representatives with regard to our Standing Orders and our practice on these matters. I was able to point to quite a number of changes that had taken place that had improved the efficiency and effectiveness of parliamentary operations.

Some of those changes have been brought about in this chamber as a result of motions moved by me and adopted by the Senate. Some of those ideas, indeed, came from my attending Commonwealth parliamentary conferences. I was able to test out on delegations from other parliaments some ideas that I had. I was able to establish whether they had adopted, in part or in whole, some variation of what I had been thinking about and wanted to propose to this chamber. In terms of that exercise, this is one of the methods by which this operation might be made more efficient.

The last comment I want to make relates to the costs of such ventures. These conferences are extremely costly undertakings. The Commonwealth, all the States and Territories, including Norfolk Island in a very small way, contribute to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. In the final wash-up, there is a considerable surplus of funds. It is probably a little bit like World Expo in Queensland-these types of things can either lose a lot of money or, sometimes, make money. The Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference last year ended up with a substantial surplus. It is unfortunate that it has not yet been determined how that surplus will be used. An extremely reasonable and, I think, important suggestion has been put to government in this respect. Oddly enough, given that Australia is a federation, that proposition has been agreed to, not only by the Commonwealth but also by all the States. It is a very odd occurrence, as I think any honourable senator would agree, to manage to get all the States and the Commonwealth to agree about something. They agreed about what should be done with this money, which after all was the money that they had contributed, and a very reasonable proposition has been put to the Government.

I believe that that reasonable proposition, which I know has had the support of a number of senior Ministers, will enhance the operation of democracy, and parliamentary democracy in particular, in our region. I urge the Government to move more swiftly than it has done until now to bring the matter to a final resolution. Hopefully, it will accept the proposals that have been put forward by the executive of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and by the executives of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association in every one of the States. It is a very reasonable, constructive and far-sighted proposal.

Technical difficulties are always put in the way of this, in a true Yes, Minister tradition, and we must obviously never neglect them. We are told that there are questions left unanswered, constitutional problems, technical difficulties and all the rest. We have heard all of those. We know what they are; they are not insurmountable. Every one of them can be solved if there is the political will to do so. I urge the Government to move, hopefully before the end of the session, to announce to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association executive and to this chamber and the other chamber a final resolution of what is now a twelve-month old debate about what use that surplus will be put to. I hope it will be put to the recommendations from the Government which, as I have said, are directed to the enhancement of parliamentary democracy within our region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pity that these reports tend to come in at the end of a session when one feels somewhat constrained from saying as much as one would like to. I refer specifically to the portion of page 3 which states quite simply:

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the credit for the success of the Conference must be given to the Conference Staff.

I was one of the delegates to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference and I was enormously impressed by and felt very proud of the way the staff of this Parliament organised and ran the conference. I am thinking in particular of Kieran Schneeman and his team, of Mr Browning and the Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans. Wherever we turned, there was somebody, mainly in an akubra hat or with a badge which identified him, able to assist. There were delegates from the home Parliament as well as the visitors. Some of us-perhaps most of us-from the Australian delegation stayed at the same hotel as the delegates from the South Pacific countries, which gave us a particularly good opportunity to get to know them-something which I appreciated when I went with our delegation to the South Pacific in August this year and had the opportunity to meet again many of those people.

One other perhaps insignificant matter, but for which we should thank Australia Post, is the stamp that was issued to commemorate the event. That did not occur without a great deal of effort. My friend Senator Puplick fought hard to make sure that that tradition of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conferences was maintained.

The report is worth reading. I believe that it is worth while to meet as we did and have the opportunity to talk to people. Undoubtedly, talking is one of the best ways of getting to know people and it is very worth while. I hope that the conferences will continue in a way that is beneficial to all of us. I certainly appreciated being one of the delegates from this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a delegate from this Parliament to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) conference, I would like to add my comments to those of honourable senators who have preceded me this evening. I would like to mention, as did Senator Reid, that it is unfortunate that these reports come at the end of the session and are not given the attention that they deserve. Whether one likes it or not, they ought to be debated. By all standards, the conference was a very sizable one, with 265 delegates and secretaries from 104 parliaments and legislatures. In total, there were 520 participants, including spouses and unofficial observers.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to canvass this because, as Senator Macklin said, when the President presented his report earlier this year-or late last year; it was certainly a fair while ago-we expressed our views and our congratulations on the efforts of the people who made the conference such a success. It would not be appropriate for me to repeat those remarks here, except to single out one person, and that was our Secretary, Mr Mark McRae. I do so because he is no longer working within this Parliament. He has been appointed to the new position of Clerk of the Legislative Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory. I am sure all delegates will join with me in acknowledging that Mark McRae was most efficient, courteous, knowledgeable and effective as a secretary. I would like to wish him well in his new job.

I also mention the aspect of the small nations conference which was held in Hobart, Tasmania, in September. That, too, was quite an effort and those people associated with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association in the State Parliament are to be congratulated for the effort they put into that. The President of the conference expressed an appreciation for the warmth of the hospitality that the delegates received in Tasmania. It was not all beer and skittles. There was quite a good deal of work done. There was an opportunity for discussion with delegates and, as honourable senators will see from the report, if they study it, quite a range of subjects was debated. I was involved in two aspects of the conference; in particular, the panel on acquired immune deficiency syndrome and the panel on environmental protection in relation to population growth, industrialisation and urbanisation.

I am rather concerned that at those international conferences some unthinking delegates appear to place the blame for the lack of food, poverty and a whole range of things on the fertility of the women. That is totally unjust, unfair and degrading for those women. It has to be challenged. The suggestion that the fertility of women in poorer countries is the cause of food shortages and problems is a nonsense; there is more food in the world than one can poke a stick at. The problem is not the amount of food that is produced; the problem is the distribution of the food. As an example of this, one can take Zaire in Africa where there are food shortages. The Food and Agriculture Organisation says that Zaire alone has the capacity to feed seven times the current population of Africa. But there are food shortages in Zaire at the present time. One of the reasons for that is that the urban elites are kicking the guts out of farmers. Another major cause of poverty and hunger is the lack of internal security in various countries, and outright war. What farmer will grow crops when one group will charge through his crop one month, and six months later the other group will chase back after them? We have to look at the facts and not just be carried away with the unfounded assertions of the population control elites in various international agencies.

The conference was not only a success in the friendships that it made and the opportunities it gave to individual delegates to discuss particular problems of parliamentary democracies in various Commonwealth countries but was also of use to expose the views of various delegates on particular topics. It was the first CPA general conference that I had attended. I was very pleased to do so in this Parliament. It might be thought that one would have desired to go to a CPA conference in some other part of the world, but--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had your trip. I was with you.

—Yes; I travelled up to Canberra! What a relief. Nevertheless, I felt that it was worth while. Again, I commend the leader, the deputy leader and all members of the delegation and its staff for the effort that they put into the conference, which made it such a success.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the section of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce that deals with the Australian Customs Service. I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to the Estimates Committee A report to the Senate, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General, in report number 17 of 1989-90, expressed concern about the level of security at Sydney International Airport. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to advert to the particular questions which were asked, but quite recently there have been discussions between the Federal Airports Corporation, the Australian Customs Service and other agencies involved in security at airports, particularly Sydney Airport. New arrangements have been set in train which I think are regarded by most parties as satisfactory. A little time will be taken to reach a conclusion on that.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Customs Service was instrumental in raising some of these issues, and the honourable senator was familiar with that at the Senate Estimates Committee. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. SPEECH.PARA: a number of questions were taken on notice by the Customs Service which when answered will give the Committee a clearer idea of the extent of the problem.

I am grateful to the Minister for telling me that the Australian Customs Service is now `content' with the arrangements that have been made since. The Customs Service clearly said that there was an inadequate situation. But it would be a courtesy if we could be told whether there is any intention at all to answer the questions that I put on notice at the time and for which I have received no answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am at some slight disadvantage. Because of the changed arrangements of the Committee in dealing with these matters, there are no Australian Customs Service officers present. I will give a personal undertaking that those questions will be answered and that that will be done within the next couple of days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. The reason that I express real concern about this matter is that, either intentionally or unintentionally, the appearance of some sort of cover-up about inadequate security seems to loom. We had a situation in which the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) put out a statement falsely claiming that everything was great at Sydney Airport, according to both the Auditor-General and the Australian Customs Service. Let us be certain that there is no confusion about that. The Auditor-General's report into the Australian Customs Service noted on page 5, paragraph 5.6, that Customs had advised that the overall level of airport security was of concern and that Customs' concerns had already been drawn to the attention of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Department of Transport and Communications. At Estimates Committee A, Mr Kelly, the Comptroller-General of Customs, replied:

SPEECH.PARA: The concerns generally relate to physical security. There are areas of fencing which are falling into a state of disrepair and gates that are incapable of being locked properly. In our view, the issue and control of security passes leaves a lot to be desired.
Mr Kelly goes on to say:

There has been a series of discussions since then and I am due to meet with the executive of the Department of Transport and Communications, on 23 October, I think, for further discussions. . . . We conducted a survey of security within the airport precincts. It was of major concern to us. In July we made a presentation to FAC representatives of our findings, using slides, pictures, et cetera.
I would like to see those slides, pictures, et cetera, but I guess I will not. Mr Kelly went on:

We have a strong presence at airports and security is one of the areas in which we are interested, even though we are not fundamentally responsible for it. It was merely an initiative of officers at the airports who determined that they should look at security per se.

I commend the Customs Service for the sense of responsibility which prompted it to take on a bit of concern about something that was not adequately being addressed by the Federal Airports Corporation and other government instrumentalities such as the Department of Transport and Communications which have this responsibility. At least we can say about the Customs Service that it has a sufficient sense of responsibility to pick up that ball dropped by other governmental agencies. Mr Kelly said:
There is an airport security committee and the issue has certainly been raised with that committee.

By inference, it was raised by Customs. Mr Kelly indicated further that it was correct that officers from the Attorney-General's Department had been able to gain access to the tarmac at Sydney Airport without any identification or authorisation and that they had been shown how to do so by Customs officers who had raised the matter with the Auditor-General in the first place. Many of the questions I asked relate to a number of authorities that issue ID cards. It may well be that the Customs Service believes that perhaps the Federal Airports Corporation should be the authority answering these questions. If that is so, it should say so. Among the questions are these:

Are vehicles searched on leaving and entering airports? Is it true that in some cases FAC and Customs staff do not have access to the gates that Qantas ID cardholders have? How do cleaners get access to the airport? Are several gates at Sydney airport left open and unsupervised?
I recognise that Customs does not have a direct responsibility for this but, as it had raised the issue and demonstrated the lack of security, I asked its representatives:

Will you provide this Committee with all documents relating to Customs' study of security at Sydney airport and in particular, any report prepared by the Customs staff at Sydney airport and copies of all correspondence between Customs and the FAC and the Department of Transport and Communications relating to that report? Can I also have all documents relating to the comments by the Auditor-General in his report?

Those reports related to the Customs situation. They are very important questions. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will recognise-although I am grateful for his assurances that the replies will be provided speedily-that it is particularly galling that we do not have such responses at a time when we debating the Customs Service's appropriations. Surely one of the points of Senate Estimates committees is to allow honourable senators to be informed about matters that concern them so that there can be, if required, an informed debate in this forum at this time when we are dealing with appropriations about the conduct of departments.

It is sufficiently important for the bipartisan report of Senate Estimates Committee A to stress the importance of those questions and how those answers will give a clear idea of the extent of the problem. The reason that I am being perhaps a little obsessive about it-the Minister has chided me about raising this matter over and over again, but I am certain the Minister will acknowledge this-is that, if this sort of thing is not dealt with properly, if our concerns are not resolved because information is not presented by the Government when it is asked for over and over again, there can be the reasonable suspicion that maybe there is a cover-up. I repeat: there was from the Federal Airports Corporation a press release which falsely asserted that all these matters had been corrected when the Customs Service said with great vigour that they had not been and when the Auditor-General said with great assurance that they had not been fixed up.

In that context there is a special requirement on the Government to solve this matter. If, as the Minister said, these matters were resolved at the subsequent meeting in October between these parties-the Australian Customs Service, the Department of Transport and Communications, the Auditor-General, I presume, and the Federal Airports Corporation-let us see the extent to which there is resolution and agreement. I understand how there are natural constraints on the resources available to the Government to provide advisers at a time like this but I would have thought that any department, recognising that a list of 28 questions had been put on notice and referred to in the report of the Committee as being outstanding, would have been prompted at least to have been aware of the fact that a question would be asked about where the answers were. I find it incredible that that sort of preparation has not been done by the Department and that we are left hanging in the air. It is a grossly unsatisfactory situation, almost as grossly unsatisfactory as the level of security at Sydney Airport, as demonstrated by both the Customs Service and the Auditor-General.

The statement was made in the course of an article, I think in the Australian Financial Review, by Mr John Lark who is the head of a major hard-core pornography distributor in Australia-a distributor of mainly United States produced videos. Because of that statement Mr Lark indicated that his organisations would be producing hard-core X-rated video material for export markets. He had previously indicated that the company was interested in buying the Asia-Pacific rights for many United States produced hard-core pornography videos. Mr Lark, in his statement, indicated that he would be seeking a grant from the Government for the export of the material that was being produced in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Broadly, that is the picture. I am anxious and interested to hear from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) whether any of the money which is currently being considered by this Committee would be finding its way, through that scheme, to the producers of hard-core video pornography for export.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as the Budget appropriates money for the export development grants scheme it is possible that, if Mr Lark, or whatever his name is, made an application for assistance in exports, he would receive money allocated on the basis of the export development grants scheme, as would any other exporter seeking to develop an export market.

SPEECH.PARA: The export development grants scheme is administered by Austrade. It is subject to legislation which does not allow the Minister any right of interference in its allocation. It is a scheme which is open for exporters generally and the Minister has no discretion or right to interfere in respect of any appropriate application which is covered by the legislation. I think that is a splendid restraint on Ministers because if Ministers were to be placed in a position where they could interfere with these things they would properly be open to a charge of interference and perhaps discriminatory conduct if people were aggrieved by the refusal of any application. So that is the position.

As I understand it-and this is largely hearsay-there has been no application or money appropriated in this Budget which would find its way to Mr Lark, if that is his name, unless it was a matter which he approached with great expedition.

TALK.START.PARA: —If a situation arose where videos were produced by Mr Lark which were refused classification by the Film Censorship Board in Australia and if an application were made for an export development grant by the producers of those videos, would that grant be made?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —An activity-whether it be manufacturing or the development of software, videos or whatever else in Australia-which is otherwise a lawful activity, would be eligible for a grant. If it were an unlawful activity, I think there is sufficient discretion in the administration of the scheme in that circumstance, not by the Minister but by officials administering the scheme, to act in the way in which the honourable senator would wish in the circumstances of his question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This raises a question of government policy. The Government, which is now faced with this situation, cannot run away from the issue of hard-core video pornography in Australia because it will be put right back on its plate again. Of course, the Government has tried to give the flick pass to the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly in respect of the sale and hire of this type of video in the ACT and it has attempted to wipe its hands of that issue. I would suggest that that is really an attempt to disguise the support that the Government is giving to this industry. This issue is now coming right back onto the Government's plate. Surely it raises a question as to whether the Government considers the effect that the material which largely depicts acquired immune deficiency syndrome high-risk behaviour-we have seen this from the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material-is likely to have on viewers.

SPEECH.PARA: It raises the question of Government policy as far as exports are concerned, particularly to the Asia-Pacific region. Leaders from the Pacific area have expressed to me their concern about this material being exported from Australia to their countries. One has to ask whether the Government is insensitive to these views. The Government might say that it is up to those countries, if they wish, to ban at barrier controls the material coming in. The Government cannot argue that way because it has already argued that barrier control in this country is inadequate.

The Government has to consider whether it wants Australia and particularly Canberra to be regarded as a hard-core pornography centre not only of Australia but also of the South Pacific and the Asian regions. The Government also has to consider whether it is prepared to pay taxpayers' money to a pornographer to produce videos which are to be sent overseas and which degrade Australian women. That is the issue that the Government has to face. The sooner it faces that issue the better. It is no good the Minister saying that he has no power to intervene in applications for export development grants. The Government must have a policy on this issue. It has been brought to the Government's attention that, if in the next few months it fails to take certain action about this and to have a policy on it, then the Government will have to live with the failure to make that decision. The Government does have power over this matter. It has the constitutional export power. It is no good saying that it has not got the power; it has got the power.

Now that this matter has been raised, I hope that the Government will take it on board. I can understand what the Minister is saying in respect of export development grants. He said that in normal cases it would not be appropriate for the Minister to intervene, but these are very major policy questions. I suppose one could say the same thing about the export of arms, which is another example. The Government has a policy on that matter and makes determinations as to whether it will issue export licences for certain commodities. So the Government does have the power. The question is whether the Government has the will to stand up against this pornography merchant who is making millions and who will seek to make more millions by degrading Australian women in the eyes of the rest of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer again to the Estimates Committee report and to the item on page 17 entitled `The Australian Bicentennial Authority (ABA)'. In the final paragraph concerning that topic the Committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any future authorities that may be established to co-ordinate any major events such as the centenary of Federation, should draw on the experience of the ABA and avoid many of the problems encountered by the ABA during its period of operation.

The words `avoiding many of the problems encountered by the ABA' is a nice, polite way of saying, `errors that were encountered'. We also said in the report that officers from the ABA were not subject to the same level of scrutiny. A great number of questions were put on notice. Many of those questions were put on notice by Senator Michael Baume on my behalf on 18 October. There were some 32 questions relating to a project entitled `Unsung Heroes'. They related very much to a claim by one, Mr Leticq, who said that the ABA had used his intellectual property-that is, his ideas-and had given out those ideas to be dealt with under the auspices of the ABA itself with the assistance of somebody else who has been the attention of this chamber today, one Mr John Singleton.

On Monday this week I asked Senator Richardson whether he would detail for me the amounts of money that had been paid to Mr Singleton out of public moneys since the 1987 election. Senator Richardson came back in the afternoon after Question Time and reported that no money had been paid to Mr Singleton. The following day he amended that answer and indicated that two amounts of money in excess of $50,000 had been paid to Mr Singleton concerning the True Blue campaign, the first payment, if my recollection serves me correctly, having been due and owing from the pre-1987 campaign. A subsequent amount of $3,000 was paid in the period 1987 to 1989 for the submission that Mr Singleton made for the Buy Australian-Made campaign. Senator Richardson told us today that there were two submissions. I am wondering whether Mr Singleton was paid twice.

In April this year when dealing with the question of the ABA and its use of intellectual property, which other people say belonged to them, we were told that a fee of some $9,300 was paid to Mr Singleton. That was with regard to the project which I think began on 7 May 1986. Mr Singleton wrote to the ABA mentioning 200 `Greatest Stories Ever Told' and `Unsung Heroes'. The proposal was outlined by Mr Singleton on 7 May and was very similar to the one that was first given by Mr Leticq. The question of how Mr Singleton was selected to take over this project was dealt with on page 105 of Hansard and the date is 11 April. I asked Mr Kirk whether the particular project was tendered for. I asked him whether there was a request for tender as there was a fee of $9,300 involved. The transcript reads:
Mr Kirk-For that one, no.

TALK.START.PARA: —So somebody just said, `I think we will have John Singleton'?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kirk-John Singleton was the best selection.

TALK.START.PARA: —What made him the best?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kirk-What made him not the best?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the criterion for this?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kirk-A good thinker on a subject such as this.

TALK.START.PARA: —So other people in the industry are not as good thinkers as John Singleton?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kirk-It could well be. It is a matter of judgment.

He then went on to find out who made the recommendation. It was one Wendy McCarthy, he thought, but he was not sure. The way work is handed out by the ABA seems to be rather similar to the way that the committee chaired by Senator Richardson overturned a recommendation by a committee as to who was to get the Buy Australian-Made campaign and simply decided that Mr Singleton ought to have the $2.4m contract.

The ABA was very controversial on many aspects. Not least was the First Fleet and the appalling way in which the Bicentennial Authority treated Mr King and the people who endeavoured to have a First Fleet re-enactment. Those of us who, on Australia Day, sat on the forecourt of the Opera House and watched as the First Fleet sailed into Farm Cove, with a surge of pride and emotion, will never forget it. Hundreds of thousands of Australians lined the shores of Sydney's magnificent harbour and watched with a certainty of pride and a swelling within the breast of the feeling that we had truly marked Australia Day in a memorable way. Yet the record of the ABA in dealing with the people who attempted that endeavour was truly disgraceful. The record is there for people to see, both in evidence that was elicited through Estimates committees and through the book that Mr King has now published. The Committee has said in its report that lessons must be learned from the ABA so that mistakes are not repeated-and difficulties, I think the report says, are not encountered-with such an event as the celebration of the centennial of Federation. That bias against individuals, that roughshod treatment by the Authority of individuals, should not be allowed to occur again.

There is no doubt that the Bicentennial as an event celebrated by Australians, and the effort that was put in to bring tourists here to share it with us, was a momentous and important occurrence in Australia's history. Nobody would want to take away from that. It is an interesting report that we have received today. There are two wonderful, glossy volumes with a glossy cover. If one looks at the colour reproductions one could be tempted to say that there could be eight colour separations, a very expensive process. There are many coloured photographs inside the report. Yet, look as I can, I cannot find a list of consultants who were used in the past year by the ABA. Had none been used, I would have expected there to be a statement within the annual report to say so because it is a strict requirement that the names of consultants used by government departments must be published in the annual report. Perhaps the Minister will be able to enlighten me as to whether consultants were taken on by the ABA in the 12-month period or whether the fact has simply been omitted. If it has been omitted, why has it been omitted in breach of the requirement of the law to so publish?

To go back to the Estimates hearing on 18 October, try as I will to look at the additional information that has been supplied to the Committee subsequent to the hearings-I dealt with some of that earlier in the day-I can find no record of answers to the questions that were placed on notice on that date. They relate very specifically to the question of Mr Leticq's claim against the ABA. I recall asking the ABA whether it had made any provision in its accounts for possible damages which may be awarded against it in any action which may be subsequently brought and be successful. I also placed questions on notice concerning School Mates and Schools Across Australia and the way in which that was developed.

The other thing that remains outstanding with regard to the ABA and has not been satisfactorily dealt with is that in the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts concerning the Auditor-General we recommended that an alteration be made to the Audit Act to remedy the situation whereby it was possible, as happened with the ABA, for a prospective auditee to refuse permission for an efficiency audit to be carried out by the Auditor-General. This has been an ongoing matter which first came to light in questioning in the Estimates Committee in 1987 when Mr Kirk told the Committee that, indeed, there had been an efficiency audit carried out on the ABA. In January the following year the Australian Audit Office wrote to the Committee and advised that this was not so and that the Committee had been given incorrect evidence. Subsequently, it was found and decided that, as the bicentennial was upon us, it was not practical to carry out an efficiency audit. Yet I believe it would have been quite worth while to do that in order to make a proper judgment of various projects that were carried out by the ABA to see whether we truly got value for money.

In the report that we have received today, at page 191 of volume 2, we see that the ABA spent during the period from 1980 to the present the sum of $240m, and of that $240m, $165.3m was spent on programs and $74.3m was spent on administration. One could be pardoned for asking: Was that money efficiently spent? That is exactly what efficiency audits are designed to find out. Therefore, it is essential that a body such as the ABA should be able to be subject to an efficiency audit by the decision of the Auditor-General and not by the decision of the body which is to be the subject of the audit.

The argument that was used to support the ABA not being subject to an efficiency audit was the same argument that was used to try to say that the ABA was not subject to freedom of information (FOI) legislation. In this Parliament at the end of last year an attempt was made by the Government to put a regulation through which in fact stated that the ABA, being included in the schedule as being subject to FOI applications, should no longer be so subject. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances felt that this was totally unreasonable and that, if there was a doubt as to whether the ABA was subject to FOI, then that should be subject to a fresh piece of legislation and that simply to pass a regulation to put it beyond doubt that it was not so subject was unacceptable. After a protective notice of motion was given, it was formally resolved in the Senate that that regulation be disallowed.

It is interesting that we have not subsequently seen any legislation, that the same legal argument was used to support that FOI regulation, and that it was also used to stop efficiency audits of the ABA during the course of its activity. Those are very significant lessons to be learned. I sincerely trust that when we do come to celebrate the centenary of the Federation there will be no such hanky-panky, as it were, that everything will not only be done correctly but be seen to be done correctly and that we will have a more obviously efficient expenditure of public moneys to achieve the desired result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the matter of quarantine, which I raise for four reasons. One is the quite extraordinarily impassioned defence of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) on Friday last and this Tuesday, and by his senior Minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), on Monday. Secondly, the Chairman invited me to speak in the Committee of the Whole. Thirdly, there seems to have been a very significant change of attitude on the part of Government towards quarantine. Fourthly, I think that, by any judgment, we would have to say that there was a less than forthright response from some of the officers at the Estimates hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go any further, I want to dispel any of this silly talk about a tax on AQIS and such things which have been raised in the last few days. I do not want to attack AQIS, and I will not have it said that that is my policy, as I believe the relationship we have had over a period of years would clearly demonstrate the contrary. However, I simply want to ensure that the job is done, that the standards are maintained and that protection is provided. For those reasons, I certainly support the quarantine service.

I have had discussions about quarantine in various places-New Zealand, the United States of America, Canada and the United Kingdom, amongst others. We expect our exports to be of the highest quality. We inspect them before they go overseas, and retain very high standards. Products such as fish, honey, meat, flowers and fruit are all inspected in Australia before they are exported. I realise that this is done both for our own benefit and for the benefit of our customers. I have no problem with AQIS; my problem is with the Government. Three dorothy dixers were asked, producing incredible statements from the two Ministers concerned. It is extraordinary. The Government makes the decisions. AQIS only carries them out. It is certainly not for the Government to hide under the AQIS skirts. AQIS needs no defence at all; the Government does.

This current doctrine that we have is built on four separate areas. I find these difficult to understand. The first is that we have to accept a level of acceptable risk. There are no published or predetermined levels of contamination in products. There is no agreement with exporters as to what these are, and there are no plans in place for when it all goes wrong. The second area is this rubbish about quarantine being seen as a non-tariff barrier. Any quarantine issue that is properly handled will never be seen as a non-tariff barrier by any respectable country of the world. There are no examples of its happening here. There is no excuse for sloppiness, and there is no credit at home or overseas for our taking stupid risks.

The third area is the legality question. Over a period I have had this put to me repeatedly; that is, if it is not allowed to come in legally, it will come in illegally. Again, I do not accept that. That, too, is totally unacceptable and there is no excuse for sloppiness. If there is a problem or even a doubt, the answer, as ever, is `keep it out'. Nothing less than that has ever worked. Ever since I can remember that has been the basis on which this has been determined in regard to quarantine and it should still be the case. The Australian producers are the Government's prime responsibility. They must come first. In the case of imports, it is the customer, too.

The last area, and the latest-this one sprang on me recently at the Estimates-is that we are waiting on an international forum. What happens in the meantime? How will we clean up the mess if we have an outbreak of some major problem-in this case as a result of the dumping of ballast water and what comes in with the ballast?

The next question is: for how many of these cases do we have a disaster plan? I know what the arrangements are if we have an outbreak of foot and mouth, but do we have a disaster plan if there is an outbreak of fire blight? Do we destroy the orchards? Do we destroy the host trees that also carry the virus? Do we just apply another spray? What do we do? I cannot find anybody out there who is privy to the sort of information that would cover that. What about transmissible gastroenteritis? I asked questions but got non-answers as to whether we destroy the whole herd, and whether we compensate. Can anybody tell me? I do not know. What is more worrying than my not knowing is that it seems that the Government does not know either.

I said that there were four reasons why I wanted to speak and I have dealt with one of them only-the defence question. I see no reason for the full defensive that we have had. There are slips as well. I drew attention to the fact that a herd of buffaloes got through the Australian quarantine system. We also had 248 cases of nashi pears that came through quarantine. Both the buffaloes and the nashi pears came through without notification or inspection. Also, what about transmissible gastroenteritis? AQIS's preferred risk factor figure is one in 3.3 million. All that the veterinarians' associations suggest is that it be one in 15,000. There is a difference of 200 times. Has there been any other check? I cannot find that out either. If there have been other checks, by whom were they conducted, and when were they done? If not, why not?

I do not blame the pig farmers, with hundreds of millions of dollars invested, for getting a bit jumpy. What would happen in the event of an outbreak? Who knows? Who decides? Who even makes recommendations? It is not covered by saying, `Let's wait for the next Agricultural Council meeting and we will discuss it'. While we are on the subject of pigs, Senator Brownhill, a day or two ago, raised the question of mecadox. Is there a potential problem in using this feed additive? If there is, we should ban it and the product, otherwise we should allow it to be used. It must be one or the other.

I come back to cheese. What about nitrates? For years and years, through the opportunity that Estimates committee hearings have offered me, I have raised the question of the use of nitrates in cheese. It is not permitted to be added to cheese made in Australia on health grounds. Yet cheese made with the use of nitrates is still allowed to be imported. Is it a health risk, or is it not? Is it, in fact, a means of putting some handicap on Australian cheese production that other countries are not stuck with? Why do we allow cheese to be imported which is manufactured in a form that is unacceptable in Australia? Who makes this decision? Why can we not get it carried through? It places our producers at a disadvantage. It costs them more because extra cleanliness and handling in manufacturing is required. It clearly puts our consumers of imported cheese at risk.

I was not given much help at the hearings about listeria. Thirteen batches of imported cheese have been declared to have been contaminated by listeria-a deadly complaint-this year. Three per cent of the batches that have come in have been contaminated. It was half suggested to me that the reason for this is that we propose to have open boundaries for trade and if we put any sort of stopper on this it may be seen to be a non-tariff barrier. We should stop listeria at the starting point. We should not allow any company in any country to sell cheese to Australia unless it has been cleared, in exactly the same way that we clear our cheese before it leaves Australia. Why is this not done? If people want to sell us cheese-and they do-let them sell it to us on our terms, not theirs. I have no argument with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. AQIS does as the Government says.

Another point concerns the presentation itself. I draw attention to the fact that at pages F68, 69 and 70 of the Estimates Committee Hansard the answers to the questions are couched in these terms: `I think'; `I do not know'; `Again, I do not have that information'; `I am not aware of any circumstances'; `I do not believe'; `I think'; `I regret that I cannot tell you'; `I should think that if we got'; `I have no information'; `I think'; `I think'; and `We believe'. I would have thought that, in a relatively small operation like quarantine, the officers in charge would have known more than they admitted. Whether they were told by the Minister not to answer questions, as happened with other departments, I do not know, but I do not accept in Estimates committees that every question asked should be prefixed by, `I think'.

I would like to know the answers to the questions that we asked because, if we do not get the answers through the Estimates committees, we cannot expect the Minister to give them to us in this place. In future, I would like to see the questions answered in that forum. Even when we came to one of these patches, the Chairman came to their aid, I think at page 64, when he said:
Senator Archer, we have probably gone as far as we can on this issue. . . Perhaps this is an issue which you can bring up in the Committee of the Whole.

The Committee of the Whole is not the forum in which we should obtain this fundamental basic operational information. We have 60 million tonnes of toxic ballast water, containing exotic seaweeds, dino flagellates, et cetera, so how bad will we let things get before we do something about the problem? Will we wait until some international meeting or conference is held or until we submit a paper to some meeting? How much do we depend on having the proceedings carried out in a satisfactory manner? As far as I am concerned, the procedure is quite inadequate and the presentation at the Estimates Committee was less than satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not understand Senator Archer to be asking me any direct questions and, because that is my understanding and I believe that he used this opportunity to make a political speech about what he sees as his version of imperfections in the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, I do not propose to answer any questions.
—Please may I accept your invitation?
—I was not inviting you. It is for you to initiate and not for me to invite.
—Does the Minister have any explanation in respect of any of the issues that I raised before I go through them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite prepared to answer any of the criticisms raised by Senator Archer. The most fundamental criticism he raises is that he has not been able to obtain answers to a series of questions and that he does not know the answers. It may well be that he has not inquired or properly sought the information, because the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is, indeed, a very transparent organisation which maintains a heavy publishing regime of reports and discussion papers about its activities. AQIS is in constant consultation with industry groups as to what it does, so that its operations can be understood and seen for what they are-nothing more or less than quarantine and inspection operations.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the allegation that AQIS is somehow lowering the standards, I do not think it is good enough to say it is simply not a criticism of AQIS. It is a criticism of AQIS. By extension it is a criticism of the Government but directly it is a criticism of AQIS's professional standards and one that needs to be refuted. Many of the allegations that have been made are untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the cheese?

—What about the cheese? Let me come to the cheese when I deal with all the other misrepresentations that have been made, because there is a myriad of them and we could spend all day replying to each one.
—That is entirely up to you, buster.

—It may be entirely up to how far Senator Archer wants to push what is a fairly simplistic idea that he tried to develop in his address just a minute ago. Let me take the example he used in relation to the contamination of a shipment of nashi fruit. This is an example that the honourable senator and Mr Lloyd have both used as an indication of failure on the part of AQIS. What the honourable senator said about that shipment is not true. That shipment came in as a trial shipment. AQIS detected some contamination of part of that shipment, which is proof that the detection standards of AQIS work, it is effective and does discover problems. As a consequence of that, that element of the shipment was quarantined and was not allowed admission to Australia. Rather than citing that as an indication of AQIS's inability to do its job, it would be honest and objectively true to say that it is an example of AQIS succeeding. Yet just last week, in a press release by Bruce Lloyd, we had the citation of that and a series of other events as blunders. They are not blunders; they are successes. Its purpose is to detect problems. When it detects problems, for the finger to be then waved at it as therefore having failed because the goods have got that far shows that the world is on its head; that is a topsy-turvy view of reality.
