SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some time I have been pursuing in the Senate the question of the legality of the action of the Department of Defence in providing Defence Force aircraft to commercial airlines while not charging full cost recovery, as well as the procedures which led to this decision. On 23 August this year the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, directed his Department in writing to `provide assistance to the domestic civil airlines in maintaining civil air transport during the current difficulties'. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Prime Minister intends that the airlines should retain responsibility for ticketing and seat allocation and that the Commonwealth would recover from the airlines the full costs of operating these services.

This direction was entirely consistent with a Defence Instruction (General) which set out the procedures that the Defence Force must follow in cases of aid to the civil community such as the airline charters. This document required full cost recovery unless the Department had sought and received a waiver from the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). This document has the force of law under the Defence Act and is mandatory for the Department, unless the Minister overrules it. I seek leave to table advice from the office of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to the Department of Defence on the force of law of Defence Instructions (General).
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that on or about 24 August Mr Hugh White, the Senior Private Secretary to the Defence Minister, Mr Beazley, together with officials from the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and representatives from the airlines, met in Canberra to negotiate the charters. I am informed that the Royal Australian Air Force had already asked for $12,000 per hour for the charter of the 707 aircraft and that such request had been rejected by the airlines. I am also informed that at the Canberra meeting the Government suggested a rate of $5,100 per hour for the charter of this aircraft but that this was refused by both airlines. I am further informed that a representative from Australian Airlines Ltd accepted a rate of $4,000 per hour but that this was not accepted by the representative from Ansett Airlines of Australia, who said that he would have to refer the matter to his Melbourne bosses. I am further informed that the Prime Minister then received a communication from Sir Peter Abeles in which he was advised that Ansett would meet a charter rate for this aircraft of $1,500 plus the fuel costs of approximately $2,000 per hour.

SPEECH.PARA: On 24 August Mr Hugh White, to whom I referred previously, advised the Department of Defence by telephone that the charter rate would be $1,500 per hour for the 707, $800 per hour for the HS748 and $970 per hour for the C130. On 28 August he confirmed that telephone conversation in writing to the Department, saying that the Prime Minister had agreed to a schedule of maintenance charges as I have just set out above. It appears that at no time has the Minister for Defence given a direction to his Department to overrule his own direction of 23 August or to overrule the application of the departmental Defence Instruction (General), both of which required full cost recovery. The Defence Force is thus in the situation of unlawfully chartering its aircraft at less than full cost recovery.

A departmental schedule of Determination No. 18 of 1989 sets out the direct costs and the full costs of all aircraft types as at September 1989. The full costs per hour of the 707 are shown as $12,031; the HS748 as $3,256; and the C130 as $4,983. Even the list of direct costs shows that the 707 is $8,866; the HS748 is $2,095; and the C130 is $3,061. On 31 August, the Minister for Defence told my colleague, Mr Carlton, in Question Time in the other place that this operation is being conducted on a non-subsidised basis. He also told Mr Carlton that if there was a gap between what was being paid and the actual cost he would apply for additional funding in the Additional Estimates. He said:
. . . however that is not anticipated as the likely outcome.

But the Minister already knew that this was not the case. Only five days later, on 5 September, he wrote to the Prime Minister referring to the fact that the Prime Minister had agreed to the schedule of hourly charges to be levied by the Department of Defence on the airlines, and further pointed out that `the adequacy of these charges to cover the RAAF's actual maintenance expenses could not be determined'. He also pointed out the following:

. . . the RAAF has had to cancel a number of its own scheduled services because its aircraft are under charter to the airlines, consequently Defence has been required to pay fares to airlines for Defence personnel to travel on RAAF aircraft.
The Minister then asked for confirmation of an agreement to supplementation being made available to Defence in the context of the 1989-90 Additional Estimates review.
In a letter to Mr Beazley dated 18 September the Prime Minister said:

I confirm our earlier discussions about being prepared, at an appropriate time after the conclusion of the dispute to consider a level of supplementation for the Defence Portfolio in the context of the 1989/90 Additional Estimates Review.
Clearly that lukewarm statement is no commitment to supplement the Defence budget, but if it is to be supplemented it will be with taxpayers' funds. Why should it be supplemented by the taxpayers?

Senator Richardson said last night in answer to my question that the taxpayer should provide the supplementation because it was in the public benefit. But I ask: Why is it in the public benefit? The public benefit is served by the provision of the Defence Force aircraft. The airlines should pay full cost recovery of such aircraft. They already have the benefit of the waiver of charges by the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority. Neither do they have to pay any navigation or landing charges on the chartered Defence Force aircraft. They are receiving full economy fares for every seat sold on a Defence Force aircraft. Why should they also be massively subsidised by the taxpayers in their charters of Defence Force aircraft? The amount of the subsidy must be at least $25m and is probably considerably greater. It is a national disgrace and as a result of this I referred the matter to the Auditor-General last Friday for investigation. I understand that the inquiry is now being commenced. The Prime Minister in answer to a question today in the House of Representatives failed to answer the essential points raised in the question. Any right-thinking Australian would have to be concerned at a misuse of taxpayers' funds and an abuse of Government process in order to again provide financial largess to the Prime Minister's friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks tonight in the adjournment debate regarding the South Australian election result. What has prompted me to speak tonight is that last Sunday and Monday Liberal Party officials in South Australia made a number of statements to the press in a background briefing that it did not look likely that the South Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government would be re-elected. The two-party preferred vote was, in fact, quite different. They claimed that the two-party preferred vote in South Australia would be Liberal, 52 per cent, Labor, 48 per cent and, therefore, that the Australian Labor Party win was unfair and that the electoral boundaries in South Australia were biased in favour of the Labor Party. I believe that the Liberal Party claim is absolutely wrong. The more likely two-party preferred result will be: Labor, 50.4 per cent; Liberal, 49.6 per cent. This is calculated on the following basis: at the close of counting on Sunday night and as reported in the Australian on Monday morning, 27 November, the first preference votes were cast as follows in South Australia-ALP, 41.8 per cent; Liberal, 42.9 per cent; Democrats, 10.2 per cent; others, 5.1 per cent. The others included two successful Independent Labor candidates, the Call to Australia Party candidates, the successful National Party candidate, plus some other National Party candidates, as well as a range of Independent candidates and very minor party candidates.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the scrutineers-I think that this is scrutineers from both major parties-the Labor Party is getting just less than 60 per cent of Australian Democrat preferences, and the Liberal Party just over 40 per cent. Amongst the others, the Labor Party received the preferences of the Independent Labor candidates and some other minor candidates. The Liberal Party received the preferences overwhelmingly of the Call to Australia, something around 85 per cent on average, and about 80 per cent of the National Party preferences.

Using these calculations, the Labor Party, after distribution of preferences, will receive a two-party preferred vote of 50.4 per cent, and the Liberals, 49.6 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. Until the actual count is conducted on a two-party preferred basis in all electorates in South Australia, as will occur in accordance with the State Electoral Act, nobody can be absolutely certain of the two-party preferred vote to the final decimal point, but one thing is certain: there is no way the Liberal Party can claim 52 per cent of the two-party preferred vote, even allowing for an error in the above calculations. It will still be about 50 : 50 between the two major parties.

I accept the fact that my calculations could be in error, but I do not believe that they would be that much in error. I wanted to speak tonight to lay to rest the misinformation, as I would call it, put round by Liberal Party officials in South Australia that they have been somehow cheated by the electoral system in South Australia. I can understand their chagrin at losing the election, but if my calculations are correct-and I believe they are-the party with the majority two-party preferred vote narrowly won the election. Last night counting of absentee votes in key marginal seats in South Australia confirmed that the almost certain result will be 24 seats for the labor Party, including two Independents; and 23 seats for the Liberal Party, including one National Party member.

I point out to the Senate that as a result of this election victory, by the time the four-year term is completed at the end of 1993, it will mean that for the last 29 years there will have been 24 years of a Labor Government in South Australia. The two years that the Liberals were in office were as a result of the gerrymander. I think that shows pretty conclusively that the Labor Party does have the continuing support of the people of South Australia.

There is one other matter I want to conclude on in respect of the election in South Australia. It concerns opinion polls. I know that we, as politicians, are becoming more and more obsessed by the predictions of opinion polls leading up to an election. I note that both sides obviously employ private opinion pollsters to advise them what the results will be, what the issues are, the tactics, and so on. I think that is all fair enough in the political process. What has been happening in Australia over the last 10 years is that, more and more, media outlets are using public opinion polls to make news stories.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Rod Cameron has raised to an art form.

—During the election campaign in South Australia, they were used by the media to become major news stories in themselves. Senator Alston has interjected about Rod Cameron. Rod Cameron is on the record as saying that he believes that far too much emphasis is given publicly to public opinion polls to try to affect election results.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw the attention of the Senate in particular to the Morgan gallup polls that were published in the Bulletin leading up to the South Australian election. I must say that I have always held the view that the Morgan gallup polls conducted between elections and during election campaigns have little credibility. Certainly in South Australia the poll taken about 10 days before the election and published in the Bulletin magazine on the Wednesday before the election showed that a close finish was likely. In fact, the headline in the Bulletin was `Close finish likely in SA'. It showed that from October-November to 18 and 19 November the first preference Labor vote had dropped from 49 per cent to 45 per cent, support for the Liberal-National Party had gone up by 7 per cent, and support for the Australian Democrats had dropped by 4 per cent.

A Morgan gallup poll taken only on the Thursday before polling day and published in the Adelaide Advertiser last Saturday, election day, claimed that the Liberal-National Party State-wide vote was at 48 per cent, the Labor vote at 40 per cent and the Australian Democrats at 10 per cent. There seems to be no mention of `other'. One thing is for certain: the final result of the election bore no relationship to what Gary Morgan's poll predicted. Certainly the Liberal-National Party vote was overstated by something like 5 per cent, and in South Australia 5 per cent would be around 50,000 voters. The Labor vote was understated by nearly 2 per cent, which is about 18,000, and the projected Australian Democrats vote was almost dead accurate. As I say, there was no mention of `other'.

If that poll had indicated the true result of the election, the Liberal Party would have clearly won. In the final result, as I said earlier, the Liberal Party did not get 48 per cent; it got 42 per cent. With a 48 per cent first preference vote and getting nearly half the Australian Democrats' votes alone, the Liberal Party would have got 52 or 53 per cent, which would have won it the extra two or three seats it needed to win the election with a comfortable majority.

I want to mention another point about the Morgan gallup poll, the spokesperson for which is Garry Morgan. For the last month or so the Bulletin has published the Morgan gallup poll every fortnight. It gets considerable publicity and becomes a news story in itself, which other news media pick up. Every fortnight it shows that there can be quite considerable changes in the political support for various parties in Australia. I must say that in my view some of the swings in political support defy description and credibility. There are about 10.3 million people on the electoral roll in Australia, so every one percentage point change in an opinion poll indicates that approximately 100,000 people have changed their preference on how they vote. The recent Morgan gallup polls published in the Bulletin showed that, for example, between 14 to 21 October and 28 October to 4 November the likely Labor vote went up by 2 per cent. That means that 200,000 people changed their support to the Labor Party. In the same period the Liberal Party support dropped from 46 per cent to 42 per cent, a change of intention by 400,000 people. Support for the Australian Democrats went up by one per cent, indicating an increase of 100,000 votes. Others went up from 4 per cent to 5 per cent-again another 100,000. In that poll in a two-week period we have approaching 800,000 people shifting from one party to the other. That means that nearly 10 per cent of the voters in one fortnight have changed their opinion as to how they will vote.

That particular poll showed quite a substantial drop in the Liberal Party vote. Honourable senators may well remember that when it came out there was quite wide speculation about the story. It became a major news story in itself. Then, lo and behold, we get another poll taken two weeks later which shows that there has again been a significant change. From that date until 11-18 November Labor stayed the same at 43 per cent but the Liberal-National Party coalition jumped 3 per cent. Again, that is basically 300,000 people changing their vote. The Democrats dropped 200,000, or from 10 per cent to 8 per cent, and others dropped from 5 per cent to 4 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't there a margin of error allowed in each of these polls?

—I want to come to that. I know that a margin of error is allowed. But it seems to me that, when Mr Morgan is interviewed about these polls, he often gives such definitive accounts as, `This particular poll means so and so'; `the Government is in trouble'; `the Opposition is in trouble'; or `there has been a dramatic slide in the popularity of the Leader of the Opposition or of the Prime Minister'. The next week a change occurs of several percentage points and Mr Morgan makes an absolutely opposite statement. All I say is that it defies credibility that someone can say that in a two-week period hundreds of thousands of people in Australia change their vote and in the next fortnight change it again. Even allowing for the statistical error, I think that Mr Morgan does not give enough emphasis to the fact that there are margins of error and does not give enough emphasis to the fact that, in the longer term, polling between elections ought to be done with a little more caution before extrapolating the result. I also think that the media generally should make every effort to keep in context that these polls are indicating every fortnight massive changes in public opinion. I do not mind whether it is coming to the Labor Party or away from it.
—Tell us what the real polls are.

—All I want to say is that, in my eight years as a party secretary in South Australia, I never believed that opinion was changing so dramatically backwards and forwards. If I had taken notice of that I would have been schizophrenic in trying to assess and to run an election campaign and to anticipate political issues. I just wanted to bring that to the attention of the Senate. I hope there will be a bit more of an informed debate in the community about opinion polls as we lead up to the next Federal election. I hope that they do not publicly play the role they have played in previous campaigns. Sometimes those polls have been used as news stories to successfully help the Labor Party and, sometimes, the Liberal Party. I do not think that it adds to the political debate over issues in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: As I started by talking about the South Australian election, I hope that the Senate will forgive me for offering my congratulations to the Labor Premier of South Australia, John Bannon, on being re-elected for this third term, albeit, I accept, only narrowly. As people say about football premierships: if a team wins a premiership by a point it still receives the trophy and it is still written up as a win. We in South Australia are delighted that John Bannon and the Labor Government have been re-elected. We in South Australia look forward to another great four years of Labor rule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just start by responding to what Senator Schacht had to say because I found his remarks very interesting. In many ways his assessment is probably more accurate than that of some of the pollsters. One thing that struck a discordant note with me was the suggestion that somehow the media was almost making these stories up in a vacuum. As I understand it, the reality is that what Morgan tends to do is to do his best to explain why there appears to be a trend in one direction or another. I suppose that, were we to be put in the same position, short of saying `We do not know', we would try to identify some of the recent factors which would tend to explain such a movement, although I concede quite readily that more allowance should be made for those necessary statistical fluctuations.

SPEECH.PARA: Over time I have also had the distinct impression that Rod Cameron is a past master at providing the news media with a whole set of stories designed to indicate to leading political journalists, particularly from the Australian Financial Review, and the more formative opinion-makers that Labor research is indicating the following, or that what might otherwise have appeared to be a clever move on the part of the Opposition leader was shown up in Labor polling to be quite counterproductive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tony Eggleton does the same.

—That may be so, but all I am really saying is that I think Senator Schacht might have been a little harsh on Morgan and a little generous to Cameron. It certainly might become a game that two can play.
—He is not on the media every fortnight.

—Of course he is not, and I am not necessarily saying that his public statements are the ones that I would be most suspicious about. I strongly suspect that not only Cameron but also Bob Hogg are in the business of regularly providing disinformation of sorts to the media, designed to indicate that somehow there is a real agenda that others are not aware of, or that somehow trends are being picked up by Labor polling that are simply not obvious to anyone else in the community. That is designed to destabilise and put off people who might be pursuing another political strategy. I will not say any more than that, but it seems to me that there is a grain of truth in what the honourable senator had to say about not taking polls at face value. I am a little jaundiced about how a lot of those political stories find their way into the media.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal with another matter entirely, and this relates to the ongoing conduct of Mrs Kelly, `the Minister for Getting her Face in the Paper'. I must say, having received some answers to questions on notice, that my concerns are in no way allayed about the way in which she consistently abuses her rights of office. Indeed, she has been quite shameless in her self-promotional activities in the electorate. The Senate might recall when this matter first arose, and those members of the Senate who are occasional residents of Canberra have perhaps received in the mail an important message to telephone customers from Ros Kelly. That was the way in which the letter was addressed. It had a Telecom stamp on the outside, and subsequently we learned that Mrs Kelly bribed Telecom by having half the cost of that mail-out done in her office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I think the word `bribe' is inappropriate.
—I will put it in quotes, if it makes--
—No, I ask that it be withdrawn.
—The point of order is upheld. It is an inappropriate expression to use in the Senate and Senator Alston might find another definition of his expression.
—Perhaps it is a bit too blunt. I withdraw the expression.

—I raise a further point of order. The words `perhaps it is a bit too blunt' should be withdrawn as well. They reflect the inference that the original offending term is nonetheless still true and therefore they should be withdrawn.
—For my clarification, did you withdraw unqualifiedly, Senator Alston?

—I withdrew unequivocally. Nonetheless, I wish to make it clear that Mrs Kelly's conduct has been reprehensible in these circumstances. It is quite clear from the answers she has provided that not only does she have in her office a machine capable of folding approximately 1,000 letters a day but also that on occasions the machine has been made available to colleagues for similar purposes. That seems to me to be an abuse of a facility that is not generally available. If it is necessary for those purposes, it ought to be generally available. After all, there are three Labor members for Canberra and only one non-Labor member. I would have thought it was a very uneven contest already, without Mrs Kelly being given that additional advantage.
—Does it sign the mail as well?

—The unfortunate aspect of all this is that Mrs Kelly brought such pressure to bear on people in the Telecom office that they were forced to co-sign this notice which went out to all people in the 062 area. Of course, the letter was signed by Mrs Kelly, as Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, and a Mr Ken Williamson, Telecom Customer Services Manager. One of the questions I asked was:

SPEECH.PARA: Did the Minister advise the Board of Telecom Australia of the nature and extent of her proposed involvement in the recent mail-out to residents . . .
The answer was:
My participation in the project was at the request of the Canberra District Telecom Customer Services Manager, Ken Williamson.

It is clear from an interview that Mr Williamson gave to Margot Kingston in the Sydney Morning Herald, which appeared on 6 October, that Mr Williamson was a very reluctant participant. He said, for example, that he had dealings with Mrs Kelly at least once a week. He said:
My file regarding Ros Kelly is about five inches thick.
Ros Kelly is doing something every three or four weeks regarding Telecom in Canberra.
Finally, Mr Williamson said:
Telecom had made the digit decision two years before Mrs Kelly became minister, and that it was a purely operational decision.
The article goes on to say:
Mrs Kelly had subsidised-
if that is a more felicitous expression for the benefit of Senator Cook-
the letter drop.
To quote Mr Williamson again, he said:
Telecom didn't pay 100 per cent. We used their folding machine and their staff volunteered to assist . . .

I regard that as a disgraceful misuse of facilities. To put the sort of pressure on Telecom, which was obviously brought to bear by the reluctance that is evident in Mr Williamson's remarks, I think is further evidence of the shamelessness of Mrs Kelly's self-promotional stunts. I also note the appalling contradiction in terms of modesty because I asked Mrs Kelly:

Since April 1989 on any and what occasion has the Minister written to any and what Government business enterprise offering to: (a) launch new service offerings; (b) open new premises; or (c) generally publicise this or any other activity; if so, what responses have been received to date.
The very modest answer is:
None; participation in such activities is by invitation.

That coyness might be understandable, but it is in marked contrast to a statement that Senator Button made in the Senate on 6 October when he talked about Mrs Kelly having launched a Telecom public awareness campaign. He said:

I am informed that Telecom expects the public awareness campaign to be the most effective due to the high public profile . . . of Mrs Kelly. The Minister has made herself available to all government business enterprises in her portfolio to launch new service offerings, to open new premises and to generally publicise the good work they are doing. This is a most appropriate activity for a Minister.

I think it is an outrage! Mrs Kelly is sitting back hoping for an invitation and Senator Button is standing up and telling the Senate, with a straight face, that she has made herself available to do all these sorts of obvious electoral activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously in Canberra.

—Of course; it has nothing to do with the welfare of Telecom. There are a myriad of issues in this portfolio-it is a very difficult, complex and technical area. The structural adjustment committee of Cabinet will be considering tomorrow a very important Bureau of Transport and Communications report on the nature, the extent and the cost of Telecom's community service obligations and the cross-subsidies that are in place to support them.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom has been mounting a very determined rearguard campaign to suppress that. Mr Willis, in his usual form, has been sitting on it for about three months. Mrs Kelly ought to be in the forefront of this debate; she ought to be explaining to the public why that report has not been made public. If the figure is as low as the industry believes-and the published figures have not been denied-she should be explaining why Telecom could not be exposed to substantially greater levels of competition than it experiences at the moment. But no. Instead of Mrs Kelly concentrating on the real issues we have this disgraceful campaign of wandering around the electorate self-promoting, wherever possible, and using Telecom as a mere vehicle for her own publicity-seeking activities.

I regard these answers simply as confirmation of the highly political nature of Mrs Kelly's activities. I think it is contemptuous of the Parliament that she should have such a folding machine installed and that she should be using it to subsidise these blatantly political activities in pathetic attempts at self-promotion.

All that Mrs Kelly seems to have contributed to the portfolio are such gems as `presentation of cordless telephone to Woden Valley Hospital; national launch of Telecom Plus at the Hyatt Hotel; launch of public awareness campaign on Canberra's telephone number change; launch of Telecom's electronic white pages service at Tuggeranong Hyperdome' and a number of other activities outside the electorate. She has spent an inordinate amount of time on these things. As Mr Williamson said, she is doing something every three or four weeks regarding Telecom in Canberra. She is using Telecom for her own political purposes. It is not surprising that there are those in the electorate who are increasingly regarding her more as a plastic piranha than a genuine representative of the people. The sooner that Mrs Kelly can get back to the real game and concentrate on some of the very serious policy issues that are crying out to be resolved and which have been shamefully neglected by Mr Willis, who seems to be overwhelmed on about 10 fronts at the same time, and the sooner that Mrs Kelly ceases to use that folding machine for political purposes and assisting her colleagues, the better off the residents of Canberra will be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I noticed that Senator Alston's name was not on the list and I wondered whether he had some special dispensation from the Chair to speak when he did.
—I am sure, Senator Dunn, that you are not intending to reflect upon the Chair--
—No.

—Thank you. Please resume your seat while I am speaking. The procedure is that a basic list is provided and the Chair is guided by it, but that is the extent of the guidance provided to the Chair. The Chair seeks to ensure that the call is given to a senator from one side of the chamber and then one from the other side, and Independents are appropriately fitted in. That is the position, and I suggest that the honourable senator get on with the matters she wishes to raise in this adjournment debate.
—On a point of order, and having heard your explanation, Mr Acting Deputy President: I would ask Senator Dunn to withdraw her comments and not to reflect upon the Chair.
—I do not think that is a point of order. I think Senator Dunn was raising the matter because she did not know how the system worked, rather than seeking to imply any bias in the Chair.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I certainly was not intending to reflect upon the Chair.

SPEECH.PARA: I made a brief visit to the Australian International Defence Export Exhibition (AIDEX) today where I saw many clever and sophisticated devices for killing people and a number of other devices for preventing the first lot from effectively killing oneself. It reminded me of the intense competition between shell and armour manufacturers at the turn of the century-a futile competition that is still going on with ever more sophisticated and expensive materials. Although I was not able to visit every stall, I was impressed by the number of foreign companies and Australian subsidiaries of multinational companies that were represented. Senator Jenkins referred to this subject in a notice of motion this morning and, objectively considered, it is absurd to believe that Australia will wrest meaningful profits out of the hands of these fully qualified merchants of death.

The large international arms trading companies probably see Australia as the gateway to the South Pacific arms marketplace, but I predict that the profits to Australia from their dealings in our region will only be crumbs and that we will pay a high moral price for these benefits. If Australia were to obstruct lucrative deals by multinational companies, those companies would easily be able to complete the deals through their other branches, possibly while still using components made in Australia. We may already be compromised in this respect by our offsets programs. Components produced in Australia for foreign weapons systems as part of an offsets program, grommets for instance, may end up in use for fighting in wars of which our Government may disapprove. The products of Australian manufacturers may end up helping to kill people on the other side of the world without our Government having any control over the matter.

Another troubling aspect of some of these companies was raised by Senator Vallentine at Question Time today. She pointed out that several of these companies had been involved in corrupt and criminal activities in other countries. In reply, Senator Richardson said they had not yet been caught doing anything illegal in this country. However, we do not allow people with serious criminal records to freely enter our country and I do not see why companies that behave in the same way should be treated any differently.

When speaking in April this year to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, I referred to several strong statements made by a former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden. Mr Hayden strongly opposed an indiscriminate expansion in Australia's arms trade but, for all practical purposes, Mr Hayden has gone and he now signs the documents that Mr Beazley puts before him.

However, it seemed that Mr Hayden's was not the only voice advocating a principled approach. Our former Ambassador for Disarmament, Richard Butler, was active in promoting United Nations (UN) scrutiny of conventional arms transfers and the conventional arms trade generally. At the defence conference held in Canberra last December he commented that this stance was not popular. In looking at the UN resolution 43/75S entitled `Conventional Disarmament on a Regional Scale' I notice that, while Australia voted for this resolution and no nation voted against it, the United States abstained. Was Richard Butler's concern about the growth in the conventional arms trade and its effects on the poverty and debt of Third World countries the action of a maverick peacenik? It appears not. Mr Hayden spoke in favour of this position before the General Assembly and so did our current Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. I referred to this in a question I asked today, but let me quote the words of Senator Evans at more length:

The quest for greater security through higher and higher levels of conventional arms is only too well known to us all. The International Conference on Disarmament and Development provided ample evidence. It is a simple proposition that more arms do not equal greater security. They feed the appetite of instability and the coffers of those who choose to supply arms at levels that are well beyond those needed for self-defence.

I was, therefore, rather disappointed in the answer that Senator Evans gave to my question today on what measures Australia had taken in support of the United Nations resolutions on the conventional arms trade. While I support the Government's initiatives on chemical weapons and its other disarmament activities, as far as they go, I regard the absence of any specific follow-up on the conventional arms resolutions to be a grave deficiency. In the past there was a tendency to disregard the United Nations, but recent events have put it back in the forefront of international peacemaking activity and, just as we are supporting United Nations peacemaking efforts in Namibia, it is clearly Australia's duty to support its other initiatives, especially in this case where we were instrumental--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I understand that Senator Dunn was referring to the lunchtime activities she went to today, but I now find it surprising that she finds it necessary to read her speech. I draw your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, to standing order 406.

—Senator Dunn, while standing order 406 uses the masculine gender in its terminology, it certainly says that a senator may not read his speech. I know that you have copious notes before you, but it would help the Chair if you would use them as notes rather than in the precise form in which you appear to be presenting them.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I will do that. I am very concerned that Australia's independence and integrity will be seriously compromised by such arms exhibitions as the Australian International Defence Export Exhibition that we have in Canberra at the moment. Our military alliances, particularly our support of the nuclear war fighting strategy of the United States, is one particular case in point. We have a very good reputation in international forums in some areas. I notice that Senator Gareth Evans seemed to imply just as much today when he answered my question in Question Time. However, he omitted to mention the support Australia still gives to the United States nuclear war fighting systems, which I will not go into today, but which I have raised many times in this forum. Our reputation is now further at risk because of our increase in arms exports which have been made possible by the relaxation of regulations under the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill which was passed this year.

SPEECH.PARA: This is very regrettable because the profits that Mr Beazley seems to be hoping for will never eventuate. I wonder whether the cumbersome bureaucracy referred to in the report of the Cooksey Review of Australia's Defence Cooperation Programs and Policy on Export of Defence Equipment has actually limited Australia's military exports as much as the Minister would like us to believe. I doubt it. Skilful commercial operators have learnt how to get around these official obstacles. I will give the Senate a couple of examples in a moment. We probably have most of the market share we are ever going to get without using the black market tactics. It is very difficult to sell arms and military components to our friends and allies, unless we have already purchased their arms at crippling prices when we get some offset business. In Cooksey's report there is an advice from Comsteel about that company's difficulties in penetrating the United States market. Despite its moral sacrifices in the name of deterrence and the alliance, Australia enjoys no favoured status in this area of trade.

There is considerable growth in indigenous arms industries in countries that might be seen as potential customers; the market for many weapons is already grossly oversupplied. Other companies are well established and will resist Australian intrusion into their territory. For example, Carrington Slipways has already had experience of the underhand methods of arms traders when it tried to market its catamaran minehunter in the Persian Gulf. Honourable senators will remember that all sorts of sneaky tricks were used by French, British and Italian traders to try to keep it out.

The technology of military systems is essentially the same technology used to manufacture other goods. That was very evident at AIDEX today. The effort and money being expended on trying to export arms would be just as effectively spent building toasters or some other piece of equipment for export. There is no reason to expect Australian arms exports to be any more successful than exports of other manufactured products unless we are going to sell arms to desperate purchasers through the black market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, have been appalled by the Australian International Defence Export Exhibition (AIDEX) 89 currently being held in Canberra. I think that it is a blight on our national capital and a shame that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) wants to engage Australian industry in becoming a merchant of death. Obviously, the opposition to AIDEX was not expected, but it has been sustained. There is a constant witness for disarmament and peace at the gates of the exhibition, and I commend the people who are there making their protest non-violently.

SPEECH.PARA: Today a very interesting turn of events occurred. This afternoon, the media were banned from the exhibition. Obviously, the exhibitors are feeling under pressure, perhaps because they did not get quite the free ride that they had expected from the media-that is, with some notable exceptions: a reporter from the Pacific Defence Reporter and one from the Australian newspaper are still there, so any print journalist considered to be sufficiently on side is allowed to be at the exhibition. However, the electronic media have been banned as of this afternoon. That is a very interesting turn of events. I hope that arms bazaars such as AIDEX 89 will soon be a thing of the past.

What I want to talk about this evening is the future. It is time that the people of Australia, particularly those in the Senate-I am afraid that politicians are often the last to pick up on new ideas-understood that what the world is witnessing is an enormous paradigm shift which is of such momentous proportions that it could be likened to the move after the printing press was invented prior to which time the monks in the monasteries, the only ones, generally speaking, who could read and write, had access to information and therefore access to power. An enormous shift took place with the invention of the printing press when education became more generally available to more people.

Then the agrarian revolution occurred when enclosures meant that many people who had farmed their own plots of land were engaged in cooperative processes. Another huge paradigm shift was the industrial age. Then came the information age that we are in now. That was another huge paradigm shift. We are actually seeing the end of the industrial era occurring before our very eyes in the latter part of the twentieth century.

Something that we need to take account of and prepare for-yet another change which is emerging right now-has been called by various names. I will refer to it as the ecological age. It has occurred only in the last decade, or perhaps the last two decades. There has been an increasing awareness of planet earth as one living organism-all life forms being interdependent on each other. I guess it was first manifested once satellite photographs were taken of planet earth from outer space. The astronauts out there had a very different picture of the planet earth than human beings had seen before. There are no boundaries and no lines on maps; there was just a swirling mass. They saw it as a complete living organism and an entity-their home. The astronauts who have been privileged to be in outer space and to see those amazing pictures of planet earth have been very different people since that experience. It has transformed their understanding of what it is to be part of planet earth and to be a human being living in cooperation with other living forms.
Somebody who has articulated this notion very clearly is James Lovelock. I quote from the preface of his book Gaia, where he introduces this hypothesis:

. . . the concept of mother earth, or, as the Greeks called her long ago, Gaia, has been widely held throughout history and has been the basis of a belief which still co-exists with the great religions. As a result of the accumulation of evidence about the natural environment and the growth of the science of ecology, there have recently been speculations that the biosphere may be more than just the complete range of all living things within their natural habitat of soil, sea and air. Journeys into space did more than present the Earth in a new perspective. They also sent back information about its atmosphere and its surface which provided a new insight into the interactions about the living and the inorganic parts of the planet. From this has arisen the hypothesis, the model, in which the Earth's living matter, air, oceans and land surface, form a complex system which can be seen as a single organism and which has the capacity to keep our planet a fit place for life.

What has also become clear in the last decade or so is that human beings are on the endangered species list. This is a very uncomfortable place for us to be. It is the first time in human history that we actually have found ourselves collectively on the endangered species list. We need to remove ourselves from that endangered species list, and it is possible if we follow the warnings that have very clearly been given to us by eminent scientists from all around the globe and from different scientific persuasions-someone like David Suzuki, who says that we have about 10 years in which to change the direction of the way we live on planet earth, otherwise we are harming our home to such an extent that it will not be habitable. So it is very real to say that we are on the endangered species list.

To remove ourselves from that list there are many things we must do. First of all, we must recognise that interdependence of all life forms which James Lovelock talks about in this book Gaia. Secondly, we must recognise basic human rights, not only in physical terms but in political terms as well-the right to self-determination, in particular. It is very interesting that what we are seeing sweeping through eastern Europe is a great democratisation. But we must not be smug about this and consider that what is happening in eastern Europe is the demolition of one ideology to be replaced by another ideology which has been current, that is, the Western or the capitalist ideology. We have to get beyond both communism and capitalism in order to sustain life on planet earth. So self-determination for the people of eastern Europe is most important. It is most important that we respect their right to find the appropriate systems for them, just a we respect the rights of people in our own region for self-determination, particularly those on our very doorstep, such as the East Timorese people, whose rights to self-determination are so often ignored by both government and opposition in this country.

Thirdly, we need to move beyond the constraints of present ideology, to move away from the need we have created for ourselves, particularly in the capitalist world, that is, rampant consumerism and exploitation. We have mindlessly exploited people and planet earth, which is our home. We have to learn to be more careful consumers. It is very evident that people want to be more careful consumers once they understand the risks that are involved in continuing with the rampant consumerism we have been accustomed to. Capitalism has taught us that we must consume more and more. We only have to look at the pressure that is applied to our children by advertisements on television to realise how powerful a force that is. That kind of rampant consumerism has to stop. There is a limit to the earth's resources which we must understand.

In terms of being careful consumers, which I think a lot of people now want to be, I recommend to honourable senators the Green Consumer Guide which has recently been published by the Australian Conservation Foundation and Choice magazine. It is a very worthwhile document because it gives people lots of practical suggestions about the goods they can buy and the services they can use which will not exploit the capital of planet earth. It suggests that we live off the interest. There is a great difference between the two.

This is a challenge for the world community. We are not suggesting, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, would have us believe, that environmentalists are wanting us to return to the age of the cave dwellers; not at all. There is a confusion between standard of living and quality of life. I think that we can have a much better quality of life if we reduce our consumerism. This is also a time when spiritual values are coming to the fore, to replace the materialistic values which we have tried and found wanting. It is very true to say that wealthy people are often not happy or fulfilled people. Again, I am not suggesting that we all have to live in dire poverty, far from it, but I think that if we understand that there is more to life than material values and recognise the intrinsic spiritual values which we all possess but which a lot of people do not yet want to recognise, we will come a lot closer to respecting each other and all life forms on planet earth and we will have a much better chance of sustaining ourselves in the future.

We also need to recognise that the old economic order is changing, that the growth economy which is still so sought after, particularly in the capitalist world, means a continuation of the exploitation which could be our undoing. We have got to move away from that. We need to look at the concept of a sustainable economy which involves, of course, the concept of sustainable development. There are a lot of different definitions of that, and we must be careful to understand that when we are talking about sustainability we are talking about living off the interest of the earth's resources and not squandering the capital, so that we do not take, take, take from the finite resources of planet earth to the extent that we have nothing left. It is a very important concept.

I recommend Hazel Henderson's very creative work written in 1978. It is interesting that a lot of the thinking that is now becoming mainstream goes back about 10 years. That is about how long it takes for new ideas to filter through to the international community to become general currency. Her book is called Creating Alternative Futures. She is an economist who has a lot of very important things to say about the new approach to the economy which we must take if we are to survive. Hazel Henderson insists that the concept of wealth:
. . . must shed some of its present connotations of capital and material accumulation and give way to a redefinition as human enrichment.

She also says that profit must be redefined to mean only the creation of real wealth, rather than private or public gain won at the expense of social or environmental exploitation. She also says that economics:
. . . has enthroned some of our most unattractive predispositions: material acquisitiveness, competition, gluttony, pride, selfishness, short-sightedness and just plain greed.

They are not very attractive qualities. I think that even the economic rationalists among us would have to admit, when one calls a spade a spade, that they are not very attractive qualities. She goes on to say:

A fundamental economic problem that has resulted from the imbalance of our values . . . is our obsession with unlimited growth. Continuing economic growth is accepted as dogma by virtually all economists and politicians, who assume that it is the only way to ensure that material wealth will trickle down to the poor.

However, it has been proven over and over again that the trickle-down theory does not work. The massive social injustices which are still evident on a huge scale globally are as a result of that attempt to trickle down the wealth from the top. In fact, we have to have a bubble-up theory-exactly the opposite. High rates of growth not only do little to ease urgent social and human problems but in many countries have been accompanied by increasing unemployment and a general deterioration of social conditions. Hazel Henderson also points out that the global obsession with growth has resulted in a remarkable similarity between the capitalist and communist economies. She says:

The fruitless dialectic between capitalism and communism will be exposed as irrelevant since both systems are based on materialism . . . both are dedicated to industrial growth and technologies with increasing centralism and bureaucratic control.

So, as I said earlier, we have got to get beyond those two ideological divines and the constraints that they place upon us. They are really becoming increasingly irrelevant, and I think that present events in eastern Europe are showing that.

As a global community we must also recognise that the huge growth in population, which could be an enormous strain on the earth's resources in the future, is largely created by social inequities. Social justice must be improved, especially where women's rights are concerned. That is generally accompanied by a fall in population growth. These issues are all interconnected, and that is the important essence of what I am saying tonight.

In respect of women's rights, which have not been acknowledged by the international community, I refer to Marilyn Waring's book, which is called Counting for nothing: what men value and what women are worth. Marilyn Waring was a National Party representative in the New Zealand Parliament for 10 years before she resigned in protest over her country's attitude to nuclear warship visits. In fact, she caused the downfall of the Government there in 1984. She is a very brave woman indeed. She is also an international economist of high repute. What she says about the international system of general accounting exemplifies what I have been saying about the value of women's work, which is generally not recognised, not counted in the system of national accounting, according to the systems which the United Nations uses. It is a gross oversight that must be corrected.

At the moment women do 80 per cent of the work that is done in the world on a daily basis, but they get very little recognition for that. When that is recognised in the systems of general accounting there will be a huge change in the whole economic structure. It is also important when we are looking at the economy and employment situations that we take on board the notion of a basic general income level. This is not akin to an unemployment benefit. This would be a income that everybody would get, or a general living allowance that everybody would be entitled to, and then people who earned money over and above that would be taxed on that extra money which they earned. Every human being should be entitled to a basic living income.

That notion is part of a new economic theory which we really need to research a lot more and to take on board, because the present economic systems are obviously being proven to be totally inadequate for the present crises in which governments around the world find themselves, with huge debts, particularly in Third World countries, which have little chance of keeping up with the interest payments on the huge debts that they are suffering at the moment, let alone of paying them back. It is not only Third World countries that are experiencing that problem. At the moment the United States is the greatest debtor nation in the world. So, whatever system is operating at the moment is obviously not working.

Another realisation that we must make if we are going to look seriously to the future in a creative way is to move away from militarisation, which is a gross waste of human resources. At times it has been said that nearly 50 per cent of the world's scientists have been engaged in weapons research of one kind or another. That is an enormous waste of resources. Imagine if those scientists turned their activities to finding solutions to some of the global crises which are now facing us as a global community-environmental problems in particular.

The corollary of disarmament, of course, is non-violence and that is the way of the future. We must learn to solve our problems non-violently, from the personal level, to the community level, to the international level. That is the way of the future-not as we are seeing our Government do at the moment, spending more on militarisation when, in fact, we are not threatened at all by anybody, and encouraging a defence industry which we will have to get out of at some time in the future because it is not going to be successful and because it is morally bankrupt as well. That is the major reason why I oppose the growing arms industry and the Government's push for a growing arms industry in this country.

We must also understand that full employment is a thing of the past. Under the present economic system, whether one looks at the communist system or the capitalist system, we will never again create a situation in which everybody has employment, in the traditional sense of the word-that is, a paid job. This is where this notion of a guaranteed basic income is very important.

James Robertson has written a useful book called Future Work. In that he details a lot of very creative ideas about a new concept which he calls `own work' in which people will find many creative things to do with their time and skills in their own communities which are not necessarily jobs in the traditional sense. People would not go away from their own home or community to work for somebody else but would create a lot of own work in their own living space. The local employment trading system (LETS) program that I was talking about a few days ago is an example of that kind of creativity where people in a local community actually share their skills and resources-the products of their gardens, for example. They do not exchange money but there is a bartering system.

That kind of concept needs to be looked at very creatively and needs to be taken seriously by our economic planners. We will not ever regain full employment; so we need to make sure that our education and training for young people do not produce in them a great sense of guilt when they do not find the jobs that are not there in the job market. People can feel quite fulfilled without having to go out to work in a full time earning capacity. There will be a lot more job sharing or own work where people are more creative in the use of their own time and there is not the negative imaging attached to being unemployed in the way that we use the term at the moment.

Basically I have been talking about the four tenets of green politics-not in order of importance but as part of a holistic picture. The first is participatory democracy. This is a very important concept. We in Australia have a relative democracy, I would say. I am very grateful that we do but it falls short of a fully participating democracy, partly perhaps because we have compulsory voting. People go and vote at election time and then in between elections sit back and complain about the government no matter what kind of government it is. People do not take enough personal responsibility to make their elected representatives accountable. There is not a great desire in the community generally to get involved-not only in Federal and State politics but even at the local level, which should be the most important and powerful level of politics as it applies to people's everyday lives. Encouraging participatory democracy is a very important tenet of green politics.

The concept of social justice-sharing the resources better in our community-is also fundamentally important. We can do away with a lot of the divisions that exist and we can do away with a lot of the conflict that continually arises because of a lack of social justice. In this case I must make particular reference to minority groups and, in the Australian context, especially to Aboriginal people, the indigenous people of this country, who have had a very raw deal for 200 years. It is time they were able to determine for themselves how they fit into the community which we have imposed on them.

The third area-as I said, not in order of importance-is environmental custodianship. This means taking care of the resources of our planet for the use of future generations so that we are not exploiting them all now and leaving nothing for the people who will follow after us. The idea of custodianship is very important in green politics. We do not own the earth or the resources of the planet earth. We are looking after them. They are in our care to be passed on to future generations. The fourth tenet is disarmament and non-violence, about which I have said plenty in this chamber over the 4 1/2 years that I have been here.

I think all of these issues are inextricably linked. They all add up to a whole. We are now seeing a revolution in this latter part of the twentieth century which will see humanity move beyond the industrial age. There is a massive paradigm shift which seems to have escaped many politicians, bureaucrats and business people. But they will not be able to ignore the change for long. The green age has begun. It is increasingly apparent that we must use carefully our precious resources if we are to ensure the viability of the world economy. And the economy and the environment are inextricably linked; they are one. It is encouraging occasionally to hear politicians even in this place talk about the very close nexus between the two.

Other major green concerns like participatory democracy, social justice and disarmament are also firmly on the international political agenda. This is indeed encouraging. Green issues are surfacing everywhere and at all levels of society. Politicians who are blinkered in their vision risk being left behind. Sometimes I feel quite worried about the kind of dialogue that goes on in this place and in the House of Representatives. Green thinking does not preclude development and certainly is not a call for a return to the cave, but it is about responsible development. Emerging green values represent a turning point in human history as significant as the earlier changes that transformed people's lives. This is another transformation that we are privileged to witness. We had better realise that it is an enormous challenge and an enormous opportunity at the same time. It is a difficult transitional phase right now but it does present great opportunities for creativity in solving some of the problems it presents. It is understandable that the current establishment will find these changes disturbing. It is understandable that those heralding the change will be criticised. My plea is for each group to listen to the other.

The 1980s will go down in history as a remarkable decade. Who would have thought at the beginning of the 1980s, when President Reagan was still talking about the evil empire in referring to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, that such a change would take place between the two superpowers. Of course, the advent of Mikhail Gorbachev had a lot to do with that. It is indeed encouraging that the disarmament process is under way-not that we should rest on our laurels about that. If we are resting on our laurels, we are wearing them in the wrong place.

It is also very interesting that, while we are seeing the disarmament process begin, we have to understand that weapons of mass destruction were deliberately created. Scientists actually sat at drawing boards and planned those weapons of mass destruction-nuclear, chemical and biological. They tested them, and they have been used. That was deliberate action by scientists at the behest of their governments. On the other hand, the problems that are now drawing the peoples of the world to work together, such as the greenhouse effect and ozone depletion, were not planned by any human beings. They are problems that have snuck up on an unsuspecting globe bent on industrial development and as a result of great industrialisation, but they are being dealt with and treated as urgent.

However, I point out that there is a great difference between the two sets of problems-one planned, deliberate and a great waste of human resources; the other unplanned but requiring urgent attention. Urgent attention to the first problem-the disarmament question-could provide many of the resources we need to solve the environmental problem. There is a great connection between the two. The planned problems need to be dispensed with and could be dispensed with. In dispensing with the planned problem of militarisation, we could provide the funding necessary to deal with the unplanned environmental problems.

Therefore, we are being forced-some people very reluctantly-to think globally and act locally. The one world or none campaign, run by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid in the latter part of this year, is spot on; it is absolutely right for the end of this decade because it draws together and connects these various issues of development, disarmament, foreign aid, and Australia's possible role and international responsibilities. We are indeed a very privileged nation. When we consider all the nations on the face of the earth, we are amongst the most privileged. We could be a model in so many ways, with greater democracy and greater participation, moving away from the strangle hold of the two-party system. The election of the five independent greens in Tasmania is perhaps a model for the future.

We could move towards greater social justice. With only about 17 million people and abundant resources in this country we have the opportunity to provide for the needs of everyone, if we are prepared to share the resources. However, it requires a generosity of spirit. Moreover, we need leadership and vision in this country so that the generosity of spirit will be forthcoming from Australians. I believe it is there, but perhaps untapped.

We can also lead or provide a model for the world in environmental management. We can be wise custodians of our resources and also responsible in terms of our international trading obligation. We do not have to make the same mistakes as other countries have made before us; we can learn from their mistakes. We can learn in the areas of science, technology, industry, employment and education. We need to look to future prospects and engage in positive production for the future. There is so much to engage in that has positive relevance to the future, unlike what we are seeing the Government promoting at the moment-defence industries.

Amory Lovins was in this Parliament building today talking about energy conservation and the great industrial opportunities there are in conserving energy. This is the message which our Government really needs to hear. We could also be a model for the world in terms of disarmament and non-violence. We have a great opportunity there if only we would break clear of the debilitating nuclear alliance in which we are engaged. My plea is for visionary planning and the Commission for the Future is a step in the right direction. Working together we could create a society which is relevant to the changes which will be thrust upon us. It would be a shame if we were dragged unwillingly into the twenty-first century without being prepared. We need to act now to ensure that our children are not casualties of our short-sightedness. Let us give our young people the hope for the future which they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been five speakers in the adjournment debate tonight. I propose to comment on three of them. The first is very brief. I reject the allegations made by Senator Newman against the Minister for Defence, Kim Beazley.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tambling

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they were about the Prime Minister, not Mr Beazley. Senator COOK-I thank Senator Tambling for the intervention. In that case I doubly reject them. I simply commend the second speech made by Senator Chris Schacht. It was a perceptive analysis of the role of opinion polls in politics and the weight we should place on their findings and how we should view them. It is Senator Alston's speech that I wish to deal with for a few minutes. Senator Alston made a remarkable speech, remarkable in the sense that it was strange, odd and peculiar-a speech attacking in envious but nonetheless scurrilous ways the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, Mrs Ros Kelly. Senator Alston attacked Mrs Kelly and made a series of charges or allegations against her. I sat, rapt as I was in Senator Alston's rhetoric, listening to this extraordinary flurry of condemnation unwind and I made assiduous notes about what he was saying in relation to Mrs Kelly.

INTERJECT.PARA: It seems that her list of offences is: one, she is successful at achieving a high recognition rate in Canberra. Her second offence, according to Senator Alston, is that she is popular and is sought after for press commentary. According to Senator Alston her third offence is that her photograph often appears in the newspaper. One could make a subsidiary offence; that is, that she is indeed photogenic. A fourth offence is that she has a folding machine in her office, which allows her to efficiently circulate material to her electorate. Her fifth offence is that she is assiduous is taking up Telecom Australia matters on behalf of her constituents. Her sixth offence is that her Telecom file is over large. In fact, it can be measured at between five and six inches thick. Her seventh offence is that she is alleged to have sent material out under her constituency office that Telecom should have sent out under its own name. Her eighth offence is that her popularity offends Senator Alston. Her ninth offence is that she does something every three or four weeks in Canberra about Telecom. Her tenth offence is that her folding machine's existence is particularly offensive because, according to Senator Alston, other members of parliament probably have access to it.

They are the charges. This is the shocking indictment of the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. One is astounded by this retinue of allegations. All I can say is: big deal! They amount to so much sound and fury signifying sour grapes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale of Boeing Aircraft to Vietnam

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 3 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government proposed or considered at any time over the past 5 years the sale of Boeing 727s or other Boeing aircraft to Vietnam.
(2) At what level was this considered.
(3) Was the possible sale of the aircraft discussed with the Vietnam Government.
(4) At what stage and at what level were these discussions.
(5) Was there at any stage a Cabinet or Ministerial decision to proceed with the sale of these aircraft.
(6) Did the Government receive any representations from the United States Government or Boeing Corporation concerning the possible sale of aircraft to Vietnam.
(7) What was the nature of these representations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No, but the Government was approached by an Australian businessman who sought approval in a letter dated 29 July 1986 for his purchasing a Boeing aircraft then registered in Australia for a leasing arrangement with Vietnam. The then Minister for Foreign Affairs was informed of the proposal and of relevant policy considerations including the possible application of the United States Export Administration Act and its related controls over trade with Vietnam, including the re-export of United States origin goods to that country. The matter was not finalised because the businessman concerned was not able to purchase the aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 October 1989 (Hansard, page 1755), Senator Coulter asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister confirm that as an alkalising agent one would expect the agents, CN and CS, to be mutagens and carcinogens and that because they have been used principally as riot control agents they have escaped proper toxicological tests? Will he undertake the necessary investigations so that we can be more properly informed? Is he aware that in the literature one can find at least six cases of death resulting from exposure to tear gas?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Further to Senator Cook's response in the Senate on 5 October 1989, I am informed that:

The data concerning the mutagenicity of CS are equivocal. There have been some literature reports of mutagenicity in bacterial assays, although other reports have failed to confirm this. The majority of literature reports suggest that CS is negative in mutagenicity assays.
A search of the medical science literature from 1977-1989 revealed no studies on the mutagenicity of CN.

I am advised that there are reports in the literature of six deaths resulting from excessive exposure to tear gas in confined spaces. In these instances, the agent involved appears to have been CN. I have not been advised of any confirmed reports of death resulting from exposure to CS.
